Where an area of floor or roof is intended for 2 or more occupancies at different times, the value to be used from et001029 shall be the greatest value for any of the occupancies concerned.
One- and two-way floor slabs shall have no reduction for tributary area applied to live load.
An area used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of less than 4.8 kPa and roofs designed for the minimum loading specified in et001029 shall have no reduction for tributary area.

Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 80 m2 and either used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of 4.8 kPa or more, or used for storage, manufacturing, retail stores, garages or as a footbridge, the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in ea004586 multiplied by0.5+20/Awhere A is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.

Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 20 m2 and used for any use or occupancy other than those indicated in Sentences es007847 and es007850, the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in ea004586 multiplied by0.3+9.8/Bwhere B is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.

Where the specified live load for a floor is reduced in accordance with es007850 or es007851, the structural drawings shall indicate that a live load reduction factor for tributary area has been applied and which structural elements are impacted by this factor.

The specified live load due to possible concentrations of load resulting from the use of an area of floor or roof shall not be less than that listed in et000153 applied over the loaded area noted and located so as to cause maximum effects, except that for occupancies not listed in et000153, the concentrations of load shall be determined in accordance with ea004585

The floor assembly and other structural elements that support fixed seats in any building used for assembly occupancies accommodating large numbers of people at one time, such as grandstands, stadia and theatre balconies, shall be designed to resist a horizontal force equal to not less than 0.3 kN for each metre length of seats acting parallel to each row of seats, and not less than 0.15 kN for each metre length of seats acting at right angles to each row of seats, based on the assumption that these forces are acting independently of each other.

National Article Title: Crane-Supporting Structures and Impact of Machinery and Equipment
National Sentence Text: The minimum specified load due to equipment, machinery or other objects that may produce impact shall be the sum of the weight of the equipment or machinery and its maximum lifting capacity, multiplied by an appropriate factor listed in et000160

National Article Title: Crane-Supporting Structures and Impact of Machinery and Equipment
National Sentence Text: Crane-supporting structures shall be designed for the appropriate load combinations listed in ea004574

National Article Title: Crane-Supporting Structures and Impact of Machinery and Equipment
National Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied normal to the top of the rails equal to not less than 20% of the sum of the weights of the lifted load and the crane trolley (excluding other parts of the crane).

National Article Title: Crane-Supporting Structures and Impact of Machinery and Equipment
National Sentence Text: The force described in es001507 shall be equally distributed on each side of the runway and shall be assumed to act in either direction.

National Article Title: Crane-Supporting Structures and Impact of Machinery and Equipment
National Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied parallel to the top of the rails equal to not less than 10% of the maximum wheel loads of the crane.

Bleacher seats shall be designed for a uniformly distributed live load of 1.75 kN for each linear metre or for a concentrated load of 2.2 kN distributed over a length of 0.75 m, whichever produces the most critical effect on the supporting members.
Bleachers shall be checked by the erector after erection to ensure that all structural members, including bracing specified in the design, have been installed.
Telescopic bleachers shall be provided with locking devices to ensure stability while in use.
Helicopter landing areas on roofs shall be constructed in conformance with the requirements for heliports contained in tc_sor433.

The minimum horizontal specified live load applied outward at the minimum required height of every required guard shall be 3.0 kN/m for open viewing stands without fixed seats and for means of egress in grandstands, stadia, bleachers and arenas, 1.0 kN applied at any point, so as to produce the most critical effect, for access ways to equipment platforms, contiguous stairs and similar areas where the gathering of many people is improbable, and 0.75 kN/m or 1.0 kN applied at any point so as to produce the most critical effect, whichever governs, for locations other than those described in Clauses es007861a and es007861b.
The minimum horizontal specified live load applied inward at the minimum required height of every required guard shall be half that specified in es007861.

Individual elements within the guard, including solid panels and pickets, shall be designed for a horizontal specified live load of 0.5 kN applied outward over an area of 100 mm by 100 mm located at any point on the element or elements so as to produce the most critical effect.

The size of the opening between any two adjacent vertical elements within a guard shall not exceed the limits required by Part 3 when each of these elements is subjected to a horizontal specified live load of 0.1 kN applied in opposite directions in the in-plane direction of the guard so as to produce the most critical effect.
The specified live loads required in es007863 need not be considered to act simultaneously with the loads provided for in Sentences es007861, es014385, es001500 and es007862.

The minimum specified live load applied vertically at the top of every required guard shall be 1.5 kN/m and need not be considered to act simultaneously with the horizontal specified live load provided for in Sentences es007861, es007863 and es007862.

Handrails and their supports shall be designed and constructed to withstand the following minimum specified live loads, which need not be considered to act simultaneously: 0.9 kN applied at any point and in any direction for all handrails, and 0.7 kN/m applied in any direction for handrails not located within dwelling units.

Vehicle guardrails shall be designed for a concentrated load of 22 kN applied horizontally outward at any point 500 mm above the floor surface so as to produce the most critical effect. (See en000197.)
The loads required in es007864 need not be considered to act simultaneously with the loads provided for in ea004591

National Article Title: Loads on Walls Acting As Guards
National Sentence Text: Where the floor elevation on one side of a wall, including a wall around a shaft, is more than 600 mm higher than the elevation of the floor or ground on the other side, the wall shall be designed to resist the appropriate outward lateral design loads prescribed elsewhere in ep001024.1.5 or 0.5 kPa acting outward, whichever produces the more critical effect.

Firewalls shall be designed to resist the maximum effect due to the appropriate lateral design loads prescribed elsewhere in this Section, or a factored lateral load of 0.5 kPa under fire conditions, as described in es001504.

Under fire conditions, where the fire-resistance rating of the structure is less than that of the firewall, lateral support shall be assumed to be provided by the structure on one side only, or another structural support system capable of resisting the loads imposed by a fire on either side of the firewall shall be provided.

National Article Title: Specified Load Due to Rain or to Snow and Associated Rain
National Sentence Text: The specified load on a roof or any other building surface subject to snow and associated rain shall be the snow load specified in ea004594, or the rain load specified in ea004595, whichever produces the more critical effect. (See en001106.)

The specified load, S, due to snow and associated rain accumulation on a roof or any other building surface subject to snow accumulation shall be calculated using the formulaS=IsSsCb CwCsCa+Srwhere Is = importance factor for snow load, as provided in et001032, Ss = 1-in-50-year ground snow load, in kPa, determined in accordance with ep001021.1.3, Cb = basic roof snow load factor in es007868, Cw = wind exposure factor in Sentences es001429 and es007869, Cs = slope factor in Sentences es001431 to es007870, Ca = accumulation factor in es007871, and Sr = 1-in-50-year associated rain load, in kPa, determined in accordance with ep001021.1.3, but not greater than Ss(CbCwCsCa).

The basic roof snow load factor, Cb, shall be determined as follows: Cb=0.8for lc≤70C2w,and Cb=1Cw 1-1-0.8Cw exp-lc C2w-70100forlc >70C2wwhere lc = characteristic length of the upper or lower roof, defined as 2w − w2/l, in m, w = smaller plan dimension of the roof, in m, and l = larger plan dimension of the roof, in m, conform to et000060, using linear interpolation for intermediate values of lcC2w, or be taken as equal to 1 for any roof structure with a mean height of less than 1 + Ss/γ, in m, above grade, where γ is the specific weight of snow determined in accordance with ea000053 (See en000887.)
Except as provided for in es007869, the wind exposure factor, Cw, shall be 1.0.

For buildings in the Low and Normal Importance Categories as set out in et001026, the wind exposure factor, Cw, given in es001429 may be reduced to 0.75 for rural areas only, or to 0.5 for exposed areas north of the treeline, where the building is exposed on all sides to wind over open terrain as defined in es007878a, and is expected to remain so during its life, the area of roof under consideration is exposed to the wind on all sides with no significant obstructions on the roof, such as parapet walls, within a distance of at least 10 times the difference between the height of the obstruction and CbCwSs/γ, in m, where γ is the specific weight of snow on roofs as specified in ea000053, and the loading does not involve the accumulation of snow due to drifting from adjacent surfaces.

Except as provided for in Sentences es001432 and es007870, the slope factor, Cs, shall be 1.0 where the roof slope, α, is equal to or less than 30°, (70° − α)/40° where α is greater than 30° but not greater than 70°, and 0 where α exceeds 70°.

The slope factor, Cs, for unobstructed slippery roofs where snow and ice can slide completely off the roof shall be 1.0 where the roof slope, α, is equal to or less than 15°, (60° − α)/45° where α is greater than 15° but not greater than 60°, and 0 where α exceeds 60°.
Unless otherwise stated in this Subsection, the slope factor, Cs, shall be 1.0 when used in conjunction with accumulation factors for increased snow loads.

The accumulation factor, Ca, shall be 1.0, which corresponds to the uniform snow load case, except that where appropriate for the shape of the roof, it shall be assigned other values that account for increased non-uniform snow loads due to snow drifting onto a roof that is at a level lower than other parts of the same building or at a level lower than another building within 5 m of it horizontally, as prescribed in Articles ea000045, ea000046 and ea000048, increased non-uniform snow loads on areas adjacent to roof projections, such as penthouses, large chimneys and equipment, as prescribed in Articles ea000047 and ea000048, non-uniform snow loads on gable, arch or curved roofs and domes, as prescribed in Articles ea000049 and ea000050, increased snow or ice loads due to snow sliding as prescribed in ea000051, increased snow loads in roof valleys, as prescribed in ea000052, and increased snow or ice loads due to meltwater draining from adjacent building elements and roof projections.

For shapes not addressed in es007871, Ca corresponding to the non-uniform snow load case shall be established based on applicable field observations, special analyses including local climatic effects, appropriate model tests, or a combination of these methods.

A roof or other building surface and its structural members subject to loads due to snow accumulation shall be designed for the specified load given in es007867, distributed over the entire loaded area.

In addition to the distribution mentioned in es001435, flat roofs and shed roofs, gable roofs of 15° slope or less, and arch or curved roofs shall be designed for the specified uniform snow load indicated in es007867, which shall be calculated using the accumulation factor Ca = 1.0, distributed on any one portion of the loaded area and half of this load on the remainder of the loaded area, in such a way as to produce the most critical effects on the member concerned. (See en000178.)

Except as provided in es007874, the specified load, S, due to the accumulation of rainwater on a surface whose position, shape and deflection under load make such an accumulation possible, is that resulting from the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with ep001021.1.3 and applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and all tributary surfaces. (See en000179.)
The provisions of es007873 apply whether or not the surface is provided with a means of drainage, such as rainwater leaders.
Except as provided in es007867, loads due to rain need not be considered to act simultaneously with loads due to snow. (See en001145.)

Where scuppers are provided as secondary drainage systems and where the position, shape and deflection of the loaded surface make an accumulation of rainwater possible, the loads due to rain shall be the lesser of either the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with ep001021.1.3 or a depth of rainwater equal to 30 mm above the bottom of the scuppers, applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and tributary areas.

The drifting load of snow on a roof adjacent to a higher roof shall be taken as trapezoidal, as shown in ea000045f1, and the accumulation factor, Ca, shall be determined as follows:Ca=Ca0-Ca0-1x/xd for0≤x≤xd,orCa=1.0forx>xdwhere Ca0 = peak value of Ca at x = 0 determined in accordance with Sentences es014391 to es014392 and as shown in ea000045f2, x = distance from roof step as shown in ea000045f1, and xd = length of drift determined in accordance with es014390 and as shown in ea000045f1.
The length of the drift, xd, shall be calculated as follows:xd=5CbSsgCa0-1where γ = specific weight of snow as specified in ea000053

Except as provided in es013696, the value of Ca0 for each of Cases I, II and III shall be the lesser ofCa0=bghCbSsandCa0=FCbwhereβ = 1.0 for Case I, and 0.67 for Cases II and III, h = difference in elevation between the lower roof surface and the top of the parapet on the upper roof as shown in ea000045f1, andF=0.35bglcs-5h'pSs+Cb, butF≤5forCws =1.0whereCws = value of Cw applicable to the source of drifting,lcs = characteristic length of the source area for drifting, defined as lcs=2ws-w2sls, where ws and ls are respectively the shorter and longer dimensions of the relevant source areas for snow drifting shown in ea000045f2 for Cases I, II and III, andh'p=hp-0.8 Ssg,but0≤h'p≤lcs5wherehp = height of the roof perimeter parapet of the source area, to be taken as zero unless all the roof edges of the source area have parapets.
Where h ≥5 m, the value of Ca0 for Case I is permitted to be taken as Ca0=25-h20 FCb-1 +1for5m≤h≤25 m,andCa0=1for h>25m
The value of Ca0 shall be the highest of Cases I, II and III, considering the different roof source areas for drifting snow, as specified in Sentences es014391 and es013696 and Figure ea000045f2.

National Article Title: Horizontal Gap between a Roof and a Higher Roof
National Sentence Text: Where the roof of one building is separated by a distance, a, from an adjacent building with a higher roof as shown in ea000045f1, the influence of the adjacent building on the value of the accumulation factor, Ca, for the lower roof shall be determined as follows: if a > 5 m, the influence of the adjacent building on Ca for the lower roof can be ignored, and if a ≤ 5 m, Ca for the lower roof shall be calculated in accordance with ea000045 for values of x ≥ a.

Except as provided in Sentences es014395 and es014396, the accumulation factor, Ca, for areas adjacent to roof-mounted vertical projections shall be calculated in accordance with es014389 using the following values for the peak accumulation factor, Ca0, and the drift length, xd: Ca0 shall be taken as the lesser of 0.67ghCbSs andgl07.5CbSs+1, and xd shall be taken as the lesser of 3.35h and (2/3)l0, whereh = height of the projection, and l0 = longest horizontal dimension of the projection. (See en000888.)
Ca is permitted to be calculated in accordance with ea000045 for larger projections. (See en000890.)
Where the longest horizontal dimension of the roof projection, l0, is less than 3 m, the drift surcharge adjacent to the projection need not be considered.

The drift loads on the lower level roof against the two faces of an outside corner of an upper level roof or roof obstruction shall be extended radially around the corner as shown in ea000048f1 and may be taken as the least severe of the drift loads lying against the two faces of the corner.

The drift loads on the lower level roof against the two faces of an inside corner of an upper level roof or a parapet shall be calculated for each face and the higher of the two loads shall be applied where the drifts overlap as shown in ea000048f2
For all gable roofs, the full and partial load cases defined in ea000641 shall be considered.

For gable roofs with a slope α > 15°, the unbalanced load case shall also be considered by setting the values of the accumulation factor, Ca, as follows: on the upwind side of the roof peak, Ca shall be taken as 0, and on the downwind side of the roof peak, Ca shall be taken as 0.25 + α/20, where 15° ≤ α ≤ 20°, and 1.25, where 20° < α ≤ 90°.
For all gable roofs, the slope factor, Cs, shall be as prescribed in Sentences es001431 and es001432.

For all gable roofs, the wind exposure factor, Cw, shall be as prescribed in Sentences es001429 and es007869 for the full and partial load cases, and 1.0 for the unbalanced load case referred to in es014400.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For all arch roofs, curved roofs and domes, the full and partial load cases defined in ea000641 shall be considered.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For arch roofs, curved roofs and domes with a rise-to-span ratio h/b > 0.05 (see ea000050f1), the load cases provided in Sentences es014405 to es014409 shall also be considered.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For arch roofs with a slope at the edge αe ≤ 30° (see ea000050f1 and et000061), Ca shall be taken as 0 on the upwind side of the peak, and on the downwind side of the peak, taken asCa=xh0.03Cbb2 for0.05<hb ≤0.12andCa=4xCbb forhb>0.12wherex = horizontal distance from the roof peak, h = height of arch, and b = width of arch.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For arch roofs with a slope at the edge αe > 30° (see ea000050f1 and et000061), Ca shall be taken as 0 on the upwind side of the peak, and on the downwind side of the peak, for the part of the roof between the peak and point where the slope α = 30°, taken asCa=xh0.06Cbx30bfor0.05<hb≤0.12,andCa=2xCbx30 forh b>0.1 2wherex, h, b = as specified in es014404, and x30 = value of x where the slope α = 30°, and for the part of the roof where the slope α > 30°, taken asCa=h0.06Cbb for0.05<hb≤0.12, andCa=2Cb forhb>0.12

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es014408, Ca for curved roofs shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for arch roofs stated in Sentences es014405 and es014406.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: Where the slope, α, of a curved roof at its peak is greater than 10°, Ca shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for gable roofs stated in ea000049 using a slope equal to the mean slope of the curved roof.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For domes of circular plan form (see ea000050f2), Ca shall along the central axis parallel to the wind, vary in the same way as for an arch roof with the same rise-to-span ratio, h/b, and off this axis, vary according toCax,y=Cax,01-yrwhereCa(x,y) = value of Ca at location (x,y), Ca(x,0) = value of Ca on the central axis parallel to the wind, x = distance along the central axis parallel to the wind, y = horizontal coordinate normal to the x direction, and r = radius of dome.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For all arch roofs, curved roofs and domes, the slope factor, Cs, shall be as prescribed in Sentences es001431 and es001432.

National Article Title: Arch Roofs, Curved Roofs and Domes
National Sentence Text: For all arch roofs, curved roofs and domes, the wind exposure factor, Cw, shall be as prescribed in et000061

Except as provided in es014413, where an upper roof, or part thereof, slopes downwards with a slope α > 0 towards a lower roof, the snow load, S, on the lower roof, determined in accordance with Articles ea004594 and ea000045, shall be augmented in accordance with Sentence es014414 to account for the additional load resulting from sliding snow.
es014412 need not apply where snow from the upper roof is prevented from sliding by a parapet or other effective means, or the upper roof is not considered slippery and has a slope of less than 20°.

The total weight of additional snow resulting from sliding shall be taken as half the total weight of snow resulting from the uniform load case prescribed in ea004594 with the accumulation factor Ca = 1.0 for the relevant part of the upper roof, the slope factor, Cs, based on the slope of the lower roof, as prescribed in Sentences es001431 and es001432, and the sliding snow distributed on the lower roof such that it is a maximum for x = 0 and decreases linearly to 0 at x = xd, as shown in ea000051f1, where x and xd are as defined in ea000045

National Article Title: Valleys in Curved or Sloped Roofs
National Sentence Text: For valleys in curved or sloped roofs with a slope α > 10°, in addition to the full and partial load cases defined in ea000641, the non-uniform load cases II and III presented in Sentences es014416 and es014417 shall be considered to account for sliding, creeping and movement of meltwater.

National Article Title: Valleys in Curved or Sloped Roofs
National Sentence Text: For case II (see ea000052f1), the accumulation factor, Ca, shall be calculated as follows:Ca=1Cb for0<x≤b/4,andCa=0.5Cb forb/4<x≤b/2wherex = horizontal distance from the bottom of the valley, and b = twice the horizontal distance between the bottom of the valley and the peak of the roof surface in question.

National Article Title: Valleys in Curved or Sloped Roofs
National Sentence Text: For case III (see ea000052f1), Ca shall be calculated as follows:Ca=1.5Cb for0<x≤b/8,andCa=0.5Cb forb/8<x≤b/2wherex, b = as specified in es014416.
For the purposes of calculating snow loads in drifts, the specific weight of snow, γ, shall be taken as 4.0 kN/m3 or 0.43SS + 2.2 kN/m3, whichever is lesser.
Snow removal by mechanical, thermal, manual or other means shall not be used as a rationale to reduce design snow loads.

For lattice structures connected to the building, and other building components or appurtenances involving small width elements subject to significant ice accretion, the weight of ice accretion and the effective area presented to wind shall be as prescribed in csas37.

Where solar panels are installed on a roof, the snow loads, S, shall be determined in accordance with Sentences es013698 to es013702 or with the requirements for roofs without solar panels, whichever produces the most critical effect.

For the purposes of this Article, solar panels shall be classified as Parallel Flush, where the panels are installed parallel to the roof surface with their upper surface less than or equal to CbCwSs/γ above the roof surface, Parallel Raised, where the panels are installed parallel to the roof surface with their upper surface greater than CbCwSs/γ above the roof surface, or Tilted, where the panels are installed at an angle to the roof surface with their highest edge greater than CbCwSs/γ above the roof surface.

For sloped roofs with solar panels, the snow loads, S, shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for roofs without solar panels, except that the slope factor, Cs, shall be taken as 1.0 for roof areas extending upslope from the downslope edge of a panel or array of panels at an angle of 45° from each side edge of the panel or array, and as specified in Sentences es001431 to es007870 for all other roof areas. (See en001294.)

For sloped roofs with Parallel Flush solar panels, the snow loads, S, shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for roofs without solar panels, except that Cs shall be determined in accordance with es013699, where the gap width, wg, between the panels along the roof slope is greater than or equal to the panel width, wp, along the roof slope, the accumulation factor, Ca, shall be taken as 0.0 for the panels, 2.0 for roof areas within a distance of wp downslope from a downslope panel edge, and 1.0 for all other roof areas (see en001295), and where the gap width, wg, between the panels along the roof slope is less than the panel width, wp, along the roof slope, Ca shall be taken as 0.0 for panel areas within a distance of wg downslope from an upslope panel edge, 1.0 for other panel areas, 2.0 for roof areas in gaps between the panels, and 1.0 for all other roof areas (see en001296).

For roofs with Parallel Raised solar panels, the snow loads, S, shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for roofs without solar panels, except that where the roof is flat, Ca shall be taken as 1.0 for the panels, 1.0 for roof areas not under the panels, 1.0 for roof areas under the panels within a distance of min(2hg,2wg) from a panel edge, where hg is the gap height between the lower surface of the panels and the roof surface, and wg is the gap width between the panels, and 0.0 for other roof areas under the panels (see en001297), and where the roof is sloped, the snow loads, S, derived from es013701a shall be used, except that Cs shall be determined in accordance with es013699, S shall be taken as 0.0 on the panels, and S for all roof areas shall be taken as the sum of S on the panels, as derived from es013701a1 and shifted by a distance of wp downslope onto the roof, where wp is the panel width along the roof slope, and S on the roof areas, as derived from Subclauses es013701a2 to es013701a4 (see en001298).

For flat roofs with Tilted solar panels, the snow loads, S, shall be determined in accordance with the requirements for roofs without solar panels, except that Ca shall be taken as 0.0 for the panels, Ca shall be taken as 1.0 for roof areas beyond a distance of 5(h – CbCwSs/γ) from the lowest edge of the panels, where h is the height of the highest edge of the panels above the roof surface, except as provided in Clauses es013702d and es013702e, for roof areas within a distance of 5(h – CbCwSs/γ) from the lowest edge of the panels, Ca shall be taken as 1.25 for (hg – CbCwSs/γ) ≤ 0.3 m, where hg is the gap height between the lowest edge of the panels and the roof surface, 1.294 – 0.1471(hg – CbCwSs/γ) for 0.3 < (hg – CbCwSs/γ) ≤ 2.0 m, and 1.0 for (hg – CbCwSs/γ) > 2.0 m (see en001304), except as provided in es013702e, Ca shall be taken as 2.0 for roof areas within a distance of wph beyond the lowest edge of the panels, where wph is the horizontal projection of the panel width, wp, along the sloped panel edges, and where the panels, panel supports or back plates obstruct snow from sliding under the panels, the load of the increased volume of snow in the gaps between the panels shall be considered to be uniformly distributed. (See en001299.)
The specified wind loads for a building and its components shall be determined using the Static, Dynamic or Wind Tunnel Procedure as stated in Sentences es014422 to es014425.

For the design of buildings that are not dynamically sensitive, as defined in es014431, one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in ea004596, the Dynamic Procedure described in ea000060, or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in ea000063

For the design of buildings that are dynamically sensitive, as defined in es007880, one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Dynamic Procedure described in ea000060, or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in ea000063

For the design of buildings that may be subject to wake buffeting or channelling effects from nearby buildings, or that are very dynamically sensitive, as defined in es014432, the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in ea000063, shall be used to determine the specified wind loads.

For the design of cladding and secondary structural members, one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in ea004596, or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in ea000063
Computational fluid dynamics shall not be used to determine the specified wind loads for a building and its components. (See en000891.)
Except as provided in Sentences es007880 and es014432, a building is permitted to be classified as not dynamically sensitive.

A building shall be classified as dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than 1 Hz and greater than 0.25 Hz, its height is greater than 60 m, or its height is greater than 4 times its minimum effective width, where the effective width, w, of a building shall be taken as w=hiwihiwhere the summations are over the height of the building for a given wind direction, hi is the height above grade to level i, and wi is the width normal to the wind direction at height hi; the minimum effective width is the lowest value of the effective width considering all wind directions.

A building shall be classified as very dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than or equal to 0.25 Hz, or it contains a human occupancy, and its height is more than 6 times its minimum effective width as defined in es007880c.

The specified external pressure or suction due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be calculated as follows:p=IWqCeCtCgCpwhere p = specified external pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, considered positive when the pressure acts towards the surface and negative when it acts away from the surface, IW = importance factor for wind load, as provided in et001033, q = reference velocity pressure, as provided in es007877, Ce = exposure factor, as provided in Sentences es007878 and es014428, Ct = topographic factor, as provided in ea000057, Cg = gust effect factor, as provided in es007879, and Cp = external pressure coefficient, as provided in Articles ea000058 and ea000059

The net wind load for the building as a whole shall be the algebraic difference of the loads on the windward and leeward surfaces, and in some cases, may be calculated as the sum of the products of the external pressures or suctions and the areas of the surfaces over which they are averaged as provided in es007875.

The net specified pressure due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be the algebraic difference, such as to produce the most critical effect, of the external pressure or suction calculated in accordance with es007875 and the specified internal pressure or suction due to wind calculated as follows:pi=IWqCeiCtCgi Cpiwhere pi = specified internal pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, either as a pressure directed towards the surface or as a suction directed away from the surface, IW, q, Ct = as defined in es007875, Cei = exposure factor for internal pressure, as provided in es014428, Cgi = internal gust effect factor, as provided in es014430, and Cpi = internal pressure coefficient, as provided in ea000061
The reference velocity pressure, q, shall be the appropriate value determined in conformance with ep001021.1.3, based on a probability of being exceeded in any one year of 1 in 50.

The exposure factor, Ce, shall be based on the reference height, h, determined in accordance with es014427, for the surface or part of the surface under consideration and shall be (h/10)0.2 but not less than 0.9 for open terrain, where open terrain is level terrain with only scattered buildings, trees or other obstructions, open water or shorelines thereof, 0.7(h/12)0.3 but not less than 0.7 for rough terrain, where rough terrain is suburban, urban or wooded terrain extending upwind from the building uninterrupted for at least 1 km or 20 times the height of the building, whichever is greater, or an intermediate value between the two exposures defined in Clauses es007878a and es007878b in cases where the site is less than 1 km or 20 times the height of the building from a change in terrain conditions, whichever is greater, provided an appropriate interpolation method is used (see en001147).

The reference height, h, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is less than or equal to 20 m and less than the smaller plan dimension, h shall be the mid-height of the roof above grade, but not less than 6 m, for other buildings, h shall be the actual height above grade of the point on the windward wall for which external pressures are being calculated, the mid-height of the roof for pressures on surfaces parallel to the wind direction, and the mid-height of the building for pressures on the leeward wall, and for any structural element exposed to wind, h shall be the mid-height of the element above the ground.

The exposure factor for internal pressures, Cei, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is greater than 20 m and that have a dominant opening, Cei shall be equal to the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated at the mid-height of the dominant opening, and for other buildings, Cei shall be the same as the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated for a reference height, h, equal to the mid-height of the building or6 m, whichever is greater.

Except as provided in Sentences es014429 and es014440, the gust effect factor, Cg, shall be one of the following values: 2.0 for the building as a whole and main structural members, or 2.5 for external pressures and suctions on secondary structural members, including cladding.
For cases where Cg and Cp are combined into a single product, CgCp, the values of Cg and Cp need not be independently specified. (See ea000059)

The internal gust effect factor, Cgi, shall be 2.0, except it is permitted to be calculated using the following equation for large structures enclosing a single large unpartitioned volume that does not have numerous overhead doors or openings:Cgi=1+11+V06950AwhereV0 = internal volume, in m3, and A = total area of all exterior openings of the volume, in m2. (See en000892.)
Except as provided in es014434, the topographic factor, Ct, shall be taken as 1.0.

For buildings on hills or escarpments with a slope, Hh/(2Lh), greater than 0.1 (see ea000057f1), the topographic factor, Ct, shall be calculated as follows:Ct=1+DSCg1+DSwhere DS=DSmax1-xkLh exp-az/LhwhereΔSmax = applicable value from et000062, x = horizontal distance from the peak of the hill or escarpment, Lh = horizontal distance upwind from the peak to the point where the ground surface lies at half the height of the hill or escarpment, or 2Hh (where Hh = height of hill or escarpment), whichever is greater, z = height above ground, and k and α = applicable constants from et000062 based on shape of hill or escarpment.
Applicable values of external pressure coefficients, Cp, are provided in Sentences es014436 to es008944, and ea000059 for certain shapes of low buildings.

For the design of the main structural system, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where H is the height of the building and D is the width of the building parallel to the wind direction: on the windward face,Cp = 0.6 for H/D < 0.25 = 0.27(H/D + 2) for 0.25 ≤ H/D < 1.0, and = 0.8 for H/D ≥ 1.0, on the leeward face,Cp = –0.3 for H/D < 0.25, = –0.27(H/D + 0.88) for 0.25 ≤ H/D < 1.0, and = –0.5 for H/D ≥ 1.0, and on the walls parallel to the wind,Cp = –0.7. (See en000893.)

For the design of roofs, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where x is the distance from the upwind edge of the roof: for H/D ≥ 1.0, Cp = –1.0, and for H/D < 1.0,Cp = –1.0 for x ≤ H, and = –0.5 for x > H. (See en000893.)

For the design of the cladding and of secondary structural elements supporting the cladding, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where W and D are the widths of the building: on walls, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.2, on walls where vertical ribs deeper than 1 m are placed on the facade, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that, within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2D and 0.2W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.4, and on roofs, Cp shall be taken as –1.0, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a roof edge, Cp shall be taken as –1.5, in a zone that is within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2W and 0.2D from a roof corner, Cp shall be taken as –2.3 but is permitted to be taken as –2.0 for roofs with perimeter parapets that are higher than 1 m, and on lower levels of flat stepped roofs, positive pressure coefficients established for the walls of the steps apply for a distance b (see ea000059f4 for the definition of b). (See en000894.)

Except as provided in es008942, for the design of balcony guards, the internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, shall be taken as zero and the value of Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that, within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1W and 0.1D from a building corner, Cp shall be taken as ±1.2.
Where the top of the balcony guard is 2.0 m or less below the roof surface, the values of Cp shall be taken as equal to those determined for parapets in Sentences es008976 and es008943.

To determine the contribution from parapets to the wind loads on the main structural system, the values of Cp shall be taken as on the outer faces, equal to those on the walls below, on the inner face of the windward parapet, equal to that on the upwind edge of a roof surface at the level of the top of the parapet, and on the inner faces of the other parapets, zero.

For the structural design of parapets themselves, the values of Cp shall be taken as equal to those specified in es008976, except that the value of Cp on the inner face of the leeward parapet shall be taken as equal to that on the outer face of the windward parapet.

For the design of cladding on parapets, the values of Cp shall be taken as on the outer vertical surfaces, equal to those on the cladding on the walls below, and on the inner and top surfaces, equal to those on the cladding of a roof surface at the level of the top of the parapet.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of buildings with a height, H, that is both less than or equal to 20 m and less than the smaller plan dimension, the values of the product of the pressure coefficient and gust factor, CgCp, provided in Sentences es014441 to es014448 are permitted to be used.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of the main structural system of the building, which is affected by wind pressures on more than one surface as shown in ea000059f1, the values of CgCp are provided in et000489

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of individual walls and wall cladding, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f2.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of roofs with a slope less than or equal to 7°, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f3.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of flat roofs with steps in elevation, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f4.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of gabled or hipped, single-ridge roofs with a slope greater than 7°, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f5.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For the design of gabled, multi-ridge roofs, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f3 for roofs with a slope less than or equal to 10°, and ea000059f6 for roofs with a slope greater than 10°.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For monosloped roofs, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f3 for roofs with a slope less than or equal to 3°, and ea000059f7 for roofs with a slope greater than 3° and less than or equal to 30°.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: For sawtooth roofs, the values of CgCp are provided in ea000059f3 for roofs with a slope less than or equal to 10°, and ea000059f8 for roofs with a slope greater than 10°.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: The wind loads on balcony guards on low buildings shall be as specified in Sentences es014439 and es008942.

National Article Title: External Pressure Coefficients for Low Buildings
National Sentence Text: The wind loads on parapets on low buildings shall be as specified in Sentences es008976 to es008944.
The internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, for buildings shall be as prescribed in et000063
The internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, for cladding on parapets shall be –0.70 to +0.70. (See en000992.)

For the application of the Dynamic Procedure, the provisions of ea004596 shall be followed, except that the exposure factor, Ce, shall be as prescribed in Sentences es014450 and es014451, and the gust effect factor, Cg, shall be as prescribed in es014452, when determining the wind loads on the main structural system.
For buildings in open terrain, as defined in es007878a, the value of Ce for the design of the main structural system shall be calculated as follows:Ce=h100.28,but1.0≤Ce≤2.5 (See en000895.)
For buildings in rough terrain, as defined in es007878b, the value of Ce for the design of the main structural system shall be calculated as follows:Ce=0.5h12.70.50,but0.5≤Ce ≤2.5 (See en000895.)

For the design of the main structural system, Cg shall be calculated as follows:Cg=1+gpsmwheregp = peak factor calculated as 2lnnT +0.5772lnnT, and σ/μ =KCeHB+ sFb,whereν = average fluctuation rate calculated as fnDsFsF+bB, T = 3 600 s, K = 0.08 for open terrain and 0.10 for rough terrain, CeH = exposure factor evaluated at reference height h = H, B = background turbulence factor, a function of w/H determined from ea000060f1, s = size reduction factor calculated as p31 1+8fnDH3VH11+10fnDWVH, F = gust energy ratio calculated as x201+x204/3, where x0 = (1 220fnD/VH), and β = damping ratio, which shall be determined by a rational method, or may be taken to be 0.01 for steel structures, 0.02 for concrete structures, and 0.015 for composite structures,wherefnD = natural frequency of vibration of the building in the along-wind direction, in Hz, H = height of the building, w = effective width of windward face of the building calculated as hiwihi, where wi = width normal to wind direction at height hi, and VH = mean wind speed at the top of the structure, in m/s, calculated as V̄CeH,whereV̄ = reference wind speed at a height of 10 m, in m/s, calculated as 2IWqr,whereIW = importance factor for wind load, as provided in et001033, q = reference velocity pressure, in Pa, and ρ = air density = 1.2929 kg/m3. (See en000896.)

Except where the wind loads are derived from the combined CgCp values determined in accordance with ea000059, buildings and structural members shall be capable of withstanding the effects of the following loads: the full wind loads acting along each of the 2 principal horizontal axes considered separately, 75% of the wind loads described in es007882a but offset from the central geometric axis of the building by 15% of its width normal to the direction of the force to produce the worst load effect, 75% of the wind loads described in es007882a but with both axes considered simultaneously, and 56% of the wind loads described in es007882a but with both axes considered simultaneously and offset from the central geometric axis of the building by 15% of its width normal to the direction of the force. (See en000184.)

In the design of interior walls and partitions, due consideration shall be given to differences in air pressure on opposite sides of the wall or partition which may result from pressure differences between the windward and leeward sides of a building, stack effects due to a difference in air temperature between the exterior and interior of the building, and air pressurization by the mechanical services of the building.

The effects of wind loads on exterior ornamentations, equipment and appendages, including the increase in exposed area as a result of ice buildup as prescribed in csas37, shall be considered in the structural design of the connections and the building.

Where there are a number of similar components, the net increase in force is permitted to be based on the total area for all similar components as opposed to the summation of forces of individual elements.

National Article Title: Attached Canopies on Low Buildings with a Height H ≤ 20 m
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of this Article, “attached canopy” shall mean a horizontal canopy with a maximum slope of 2% that is attached to a building wall at any height, hc, above ground level.

National Article Title: Attached Canopies on Low Buildings with a Height H ≤ 20 m
National Sentence Text: The specified external wind pressure, p, and the specified net external wind pressure, pnet, for attached canopies on exterior walls of low buildings with a height H ≤ 20 m shall be determined as follows:p=IWqCeCt CgCp,andpnet=IWqCe CtCgCpnetwherep = specified external wind pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the upper or lower surface of the canopy, considered positive when acting towards the surface and negative when acting away from the surface, pnet = specified net external wind pressure acting statically on the canopy, considered positive when acting in a downward direction and negative when acting in an upward direction, IW, q, Ce, Ct = as defined in es007875, CgCp = gust pressure coefficient on the upper or lower surface of the canopy, as given in ea003586f1, and (CgCp)net = net gust pressure coefficient on the canopy, considering simultaneous contributions from the upper and lower surfaces of the canopy, as given in ea003586f2.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: Where solar panels are installed on a roof, the roof wind loads shall account for the wind loads on the solar panels, as determined in accordance with Sentences es013704 to es013709, or shall be determined in the same way as for the roof without solar panels, whichever approach results in the most critical effect.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: For an array of solar panels where the panels are installed close and parallel to the roof surface with their upper surface not more than 250 mm above the roof surface and with gaps around the panels of not less than 6 mm, the net positive or negative pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of a panel or the array shall be calculated as follows:p=IWqCeCtCgCp EgawhereIW, q, Ce, Ct, Cg, Cp = as defined in es007875, determined in the same manner as for the roof cladding, E = edge factor, as provided in es013706, and γa = pressure equalization factor, as provided in es013705.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: The pressure equalization factor, γa, in es013704 shall be for a panel or an array where the panel chord length, Lp, is greater than 2 m or for a panel or an array that is within a distance of 2h2 from the roof edge or ridge, where h2 is the height of the panel's highest point above the roof surface, taken as 1.0, and for other panels or arrays, determined from ea003585f1 based on the area of the panel or array over which the wind load is being calculated.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: The edge factor, E, in es013704 shall be taken as 1.5 within a distance of 1.5Lp from an exposed edge of the array of solar panels, as defined in es013707, and 1.0 elsewhere.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of es013706a, an exposed edge of the array of solar panels shall be considered to occur where the distance to the next row of panels or the distance across a gap in the same row of panels exceeds 4h2 or 1.2 m, whichever is greater, or where the distance to the roof edge exceeds 4h2 or 1.2 m, whichever is greater, and exceeds 0.5h, where h is the reference height of the roof.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: For an array of solar panels mounted on a roof with a slope, α, less than or equal to 7°, where the panels are tilted relative to the roof surface, have a chord length, Lp, not greater than 2 m, and are installed such that the height of their lowest point above the roof surface, h1, is not greater than 0.6 m, the height of their highest point above the roof surface, h2, is not greater than 1.2 m, and their tilt angle relative to the roof surface, ω, is not greater than 35°, or where the panels are installed parallel to the roof surface with their upper surface greater than 250 mm above the roof surface and with gaps not less than 6 mm between the panels, the net positive or negative pressure difference between the upper and the lower surfaces of a panel or the array shall be calculated as follows:pnet=IWqCeCtCgCpnetwhereIW, q, Ce, Ct = as defined in es007875, determined in the same manner as for the roof cladding, and (CgCp)net = net gust pressure coefficient, as provided in es013709.

National Article Title: Roof-Mounted Solar Panels on Buildings of Any Height
National Sentence Text: The net gust pressure coefficient, (CgCp)net, in es013708 shall be calculated as follows: CgCpnet=±gpgcECgCpnwhereγp = parapet factor, determined as the lesser of 1.2 and (0.9 + hpt/h), γc = chord factor, determined as the greater of (0.6 + 0.2Lp) and 0.8, E = as defined in es013704, and (CgCp)n = normalized gust pressure coefficient, determined from ea003585f2 based on ω and AN,wherehpt = height of the parapet above the roof surface, in m, h = reference height of the roof, in m, Lp = panel chord length, in m, ω = panel tilt angle relative to the roof surface, and AN = normalized panel or array area, calculated as AN=1000AmaxL2b,25whereA = panel or array area over which the wind load is being calculated, in m2, and Lb = normalized building length, in m, determined as the lesser of 0.4hWL, h and WS,whereWL = longest horizontal dimension of the building, in m, and WS = smallest horizontal dimension of the building, in m.
Except as provided in Sentences es014457 and es014458, wind tunnel tests on scale models to determine wind loads on buildings shall be conducted in accordance with asce49.

Where an adjacent building provides substantial sheltering effect, the wind loads for the main structural system shall be no lower than 80% of the loads determined from tests referred to in es014456 with the effect of the sheltering building removed as applied to the base shear force for buildings with a ratio of height to minimum effective width, as defined in es007880, less than or equal to 1.0, or the base moment for buildings with a ratio of height to minimum effective width greater than 1.0.

For the design of cladding and secondary structural members, the exterior wind loads determined from the wind tunnel tests shall be no less onerous than those determined by analysis in accordance with ea004596 using the following assumptions: Cg = 2.5 and Cp = ±0.72, where the building's height is greater than 20 m or greater than its minimum effective width, and CgCp = 80% of the values for zones w and r provided in ea000059, where the building's height is less than or equal to 20 m and no greater than its minimum effective width.
Except as permitted in es014459, the deflections and specified loading due to earthquake motions shall be determined according to the requirements of Articles ea004600 to ea003493

Where IEFsSa(0.2,X450) and IEFsSa(2.0,X450) are less than 0.16 and 0.03 respectively, the deflections and specified loading due to earthquake motions are permitted to be determined in accordance with Sentences es014460 to es014472, where IE is the earthquake importance factor and has a value of 0.8, 1.0, 1.3 and 1.5 for buildings in the Low, Normal, High and Post-disaster Importance Categories respectively, Fs is the site coefficient based on the average N̄60 or s̄u, as defined in ea004600, for the top 30 m of soil below the footings, pile caps, or mat foundations and has a value of 1.0 for rock sites or when N̄60 > 50 or s̄u > 100 kPa, 1.6 when 15 ≤ N̄60 ≤ 50 or 50 kPa ≤ s̄u ≤ 100 kPa, and 2.8 for all other cases, and Sa(T,X450) is the 5%-damped spectral acceleration value at period T for site designation X450, as defined in ea004600, determined in accordance with ep001021.1.3 and corresponding to a 2% probability of exceedance in 50 years.

The structure shall have a clearly defined seismic force resisting system (SFRS) to resist the earthquake loads and their effects, and load path (or paths) that will transfer the inertial forces generated in an earthquake to the supporting ground.
An unreinforced masonry SFRS shall not be permitted where IE is greater than 1.0, or the height above grade is greater than or equal to 30 m.
The height above grade of an SFRS designed in accordance with csas136 shall be less than 15 m.
Earthquake forces shall be assumed to act horizontally and independently about any two orthogonal axes.

The specified lateral earthquake force, Vs, at the base of the structure in the direction under consideration shall be calculated as follows:Vs=FsSaTs,X450IEW/RswhereSa(Ts,X450) = value of Sa(Ts,X450) determined by linear interpolation between the values of Sa(0.2,X450 ), Sa(0.5,X450) and Sa(1.0,X450), = Sa(0.2,X450) for Ts ≤ 0.2 s, and = Sa(1.0,X450) for Ts ≥ 1.0 s, W = sum of Wi over the height of the building, where Wi is defined in ea004600, and Rs = 1.5, except Rs = 1.0 for structures where the storey strength is less than that in the storey above and for an unreinforced masonry SFRS,whereTs = fundamental lateral period of vibration of the building, as defined in ea004600, = 0.085(hn)¾ for steel moment frames, = 0.075(hn)¾ for concrete moment frames, = 0.1N for other moment frames, = 0.025hn for braced frames, and = 0.05(hn)¾ for shear walls and other structures,where hn = height, in m, above the base to level n, as defined in ea004600, and N = total number of storeys above exterior grade to level n, as defined in ea004600,except that, in cases where Rs = 1.5, Vs need not be greater than FsSa(0.5,X450)IEW/Rs.

The specified lateral earthquake force, Vs, shall be distributed over the height of the building in accordance with the following formula:Fx=VsWxhx/i=1nWihiwhereFx = force applied through the centre of mass at level x, Wx, Wi = portion of W that is located at or is assigned to level x or i respectively, and hx, hi = height, in m, above the base to level x or i respectively, as defined in ea004600

Accidental torsional effects applied concurrently with Fx shall be considered by applying torsional moments about the vertical axis at each level for each of the following cases considered separately: +0.1DnxFx, and −0.1DnxFx.
Deflections obtained from a linear analysis shall include the effects of torsion and be multiplied by Rs/IE to get realistic values of expected deflections.

The deflections referred to in es014467 shall be used to calculate the largest interstorey deflection, which shall not exceed 0.01hs for post-disaster buildings, 0.02hs for High Importance Category buildings, and 0.025hs for all other buildings, where hs is the interstorey height as defined in ea004600

When earthquake forces are calculated using Rs = 1.5, the following elements in the SFRS shall have their design forces due to earthquake effects increased by 33%: diaphragms and their chords, connections, struts and collectors, tie downs in wood or drywall shear walls, connections and anchor bolts in steel- and wood-braced frames, connections in precast concrete, and connections in steel moment frames.

Except as provided in es014471, where cantilever parapet walls, other cantilever walls, exterior ornamentation and appendages, towers, chimneys or penthouses are connected to or form part of a building, they shall be designed, along with their connections, for a lateral force, Vsp, distributed according to the distribution of mass of the element and acting in the lateral direction that results in the most critical loading for design using the following equation:Vsp=0.9Sa0.2,X450FsIEWpwhere Wp = weight of a portion of a structure as defined in ea004600
The value of Vsp shall be doubled for unreinforced masonry elements.
Structures designed in accordance with this Article need not comply with the seismic requirements stated in the applicable design standard referenced in ep001024.3

The building shall be designed to meet the requirements of this Subsection and of the design standards referenced in ep001024.3
Structures shall be designed with a clearly defined load path, or paths, that will transfer the inertial forces generated in an earthquake to the supporting ground.
The structure shall have a clearly defined SFRS, as defined in ea004600
The SFRS shall be designed to resist 100% of the earthquake loads and their effects. (See en001150.)

All structural framing elements not considered to be part of the SFRS must be investigated and shown to behave elastically or to have sufficient non-linear capacity to support their gravity loads while undergoing earthquake-induced deformations calculated from the deflections determined in ea004611

Stiff elements that are not considered part of the SFRS, such as concrete, masonry, brick or precast walls or panels, shall be separated from all structural elements of the building such that no interaction takes place as the building undergoes deflections due to earthquake effects as calculated in this Subsection, or made part of the SFRS and satisfy the requirements of this Subsection. (See en001151.)

Stiffness imparted to the structure from elements not part of the SFRS, other than those described in es007888, shall not be used to resist earthquake deflections but shall be accounted for in calculating the period of the structure for determining forces if the added stiffness decreases the fundamental lateral period by more than 15%, in determining the irregularity of the structure, except the additional stiffness shall not be used to make an irregular SFRS regular or to reduce the effects of torsion (see en001152), and in designing the SFRS if inclusion of the elements not part of the SFRS in the analysis has an adverse effect on the SFRS (see en001152).

Structural modeling shall be representative of the magnitude and spatial distribution of the mass of the building and of the stiffness of all elements of the SFRS, including stiff elements that are not separated in accordance with es007888, and shall account for the effect of cracked sections in reinforced concrete and reinforced masonry elements, the effect of the finite size of members and joints, sway effects arising from the interaction of gravity loads with the displaced configuration of the structure, and other effects that influence the lateral stiffness of the building. (See en001153.)

For site designation X, as determined in accordance with es007894 or es007895, the peak ground acceleration, PGA(X), the peak ground velocity, PGV(X), and the 5%-damped spectral acceleration values, Sa(T,X), at periods T of 0.2 s, 0.5 s, 1.0 s, 2.0 s, 5.0 s and 10.0 s shall except as provided in es007897, be determined in accordance with ep001021.1.3, and except as provided in ea003493, correspond to a 2% probability of exceedance in 50 years.

Except as provided in es007895, the site designation referred to in es007892 shall be determined using the average shear wave velocity, Vs30, calculated from in situ measurements of shear wave velocity, as follows: for the ground profiles described in et000429, the site designation shall be determined in accordance with the Table, and for all other ground profiles, the site designation shall be XV, where V is the value of Vs30. (See en000983.)

Where Vs30 calculated from in situ measurements is not available, the site designation referred to in es007892 shall be XS, where S is the Site Class determined using the energy-corrected average standard penetration resistance, N̄60, or the average undrained shear strength, s̄u, in accordance with et001034, N̄60 and s̄u being calculated based on rational analysis. (See Notes en001154 and en000983.)
Site-specific geotechnical evaluation is required to determine the values of PGA(XF), PGV(XF) and Sa(T,XF) for site designation XF.

Where structures on liquefiable soils have a fundamental lateral period, Ta, of 0.5 s or less, the site designation X and the corresponding values of Sa(T,X) and PGA(X) are permitted to be determined in accordance with es007892 by assuming that the soils are not liquefiable.
The design spectral acceleration, S(T), shall be determined in accordance with et000430, using log–log or linear interpolation for intermediate values of T. (See en000987.)

Where required for the application of a standard referenced in this Subsection, the acceleration-based site coefficient, Fa, for site designation X shall be taken as S(0.2)/Sa(0.2,X450) and the velocity-based site coefficient, Fv, for site designation X shall be taken as S(1.0)/Sa(1.0,X450).
The earthquake importance factor, IE, shall be determined according to et001037
Buildings shall be assigned a Seismic Category in accordance with et000431.
Structures having any of the features listed in et001040 shall be designated irregular.
Structures not classified as irregular according to es007899 may be considered regular.
Except as required by ea004608, where the Seismic Category is SC3 or SC4, structures designated as irregular must satisfy the provisions referenced in et001040

Analysis for earthquake actions shall be carried out in accordance with the Dynamic Analysis Procedure described in ea004610 (see en001156), except that the Equivalent Static Force Procedure described in ea004609 may be used for structures that meet any of the following criteria: where the Seismic Category is SC1 or SC2, regular structures that are less than 60 m in height and have a fundamental lateral period, Ta, less than 2 s in each of two orthogonal directions as defined in ea004606, or structures with a structural irregularity of Type 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 or 8 as defined in et001040 that are less than 20 m in height and have a fundamental lateral period, Ta, less than 0.5 s in each of two orthogonal directions as defined in ea004606

Earthquake forces shall be assumed to act in any horizontal direction, except that the following shall be considered to provide adequate design force levels in the structure: where components of the SFRS are oriented along a set of orthogonal axes, independent analyses about each of the principal axes of the structure shall be performed, where the components of the SFRS are not oriented along a set of orthogonal axes and the Seismic Category is SC1 or SC2, independent analyses about any two orthogonal axes is permitted, or where the components of the SFRS are not oriented along a set of orthogonal axes and the Seismic Category is SC3 or SC4, analysis of the structure independently in any two orthogonal directions for 100% of the specified earthquake loads applied in one direction plus 30% of the specified earthquake loads in the perpendicular direction, with the combination requiring the greater element strength being used in the design.

National Article Title: SFRS Force Modification Factors and General Restrictions
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Articles ea000065 and ea000067, the values of Rd and Ro and the corresponding system restrictions shall conform to et001038 and the requirements of this Subsection.

National Article Title: SFRS Force Modification Factors and General Restrictions
National Sentence Text: When a particular value of Rd is required by this Article, the corresponding Ro shall be used.

National Article Title: SFRS Force Modification Factors and General Restrictions
National Sentence Text: For combinations of different types of SFRS acting in the same direction in the same storey, RdRo shall be taken as the lowest value of RdRo corresponding to these systems.

National Article Title: SFRS Force Modification Factors and General Restrictions
National Sentence Text: For vertical variations of RdRo, excluding rooftop structures not exceeding two storeys in height whose weight is less than the greater of 10% of W and 30% of Wi of the level below, the value of RdRo used in the design of any storey shall be less than or equal to the lowest value of RdRo used in the given direction for the storeys above, and the requirements of es007939 must be satisfied. (See en001158.)

National Article Title: SFRS Force Modification Factors and General Restrictions
National Sentence Text: If it can be demonstrated through testing, research and analysis that the seismic performance of a structural system is at least equivalent to one of the types of SFRS defined in et001038, then such a structural system will qualify for values of Rd and Ro corresponding to the equivalent type in that Table. (See en001159.)

Except as required by es007910b, structures with a Type 6 irregularity, Discontinuity in Capacity - Weak Storey, as described in et001040, are not permitted unless the Seismic Category is SC1 and the forces used for design of the SFRS are multiplied by RdRo.

Post-disaster buildings shall not have Type 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 9 or 10 irregularities as described in et001040, where the Seismic Category is SC3 or SC4, not have a Type 6 irregularity as described in et001040, have an SFRS with an Rd of 2.0 or greater, where they are constructed with concrete or masonry shear walls, have no storey with a lateral stiffness that is less than that of the storey above it, and where they are constructed with other types of SFRS, have no storey for which the interstorey deflection under lateral earthquake forces divided by the interstorey height, hs, is greater than that of the storey above it.

High Importance Category buildings shall not have Type 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 9 or 10 irregularities as described in et001040, where the Seismic Category is SC4, not have a Type 6 irregularity as described in et001040, have an SFRS with an Rd of at least 2.0 where the Seismic Category is SC4, and 1.5 otherwise, where they are constructed with concrete or masonry shear walls, have no storey with a lateral stiffness that is less than that of the storey above it, and where they are constructed with other types of SFRS, have no storey for which the interstorey deflection under lateral earthquake forces divided by the interstorey height, hs, is greater than that of the storey above it.

Where the fundamental lateral period, Ta, is greater than or equal to 1.0 s and IES(1.0) is greater than 0.25, shear walls that are other than wood-based and form part of the SFRS shall be continuous from their top to the foundation and shall not have Type 4 or 5 irregularities as described in et001040

For buildings in Seismic Category SC3 or SC4 that are constructed with more than 4 storeys of continuous wood construction, timber SFRSs consisting of shear walls with wood-based panels or of braced or moment-resisting frames as defined in et001038 within the continuous wood construction shall not have Type 4 or 5 irregularities as described in et001040 (See en000899.)

For buildings in Seismic Category SC3 or SC4 that are constructed with more than 4 storeys of continuous wood construction, timber SFRSs consisting of moderately ductile or limited ductility cross-laminated timber shear walls, platform-type construction, as defined in et001038 within the continuous wood construction shall not have Type 4, 5, 6, 8, 9 or 10 irregularities as described in et001040 (See en000899.)

The ratio α for a Type 9 irregularity as described in et001040 shall be determined independently for each orthogonal direction using the following equation:a=QG/QywhereQG = gravity-induced lateral demand on the SFRS at the critical level of the yielding system, and Qy = the resistance of the yielding mechanism required to resist the earthquake loads, which need not be taken as less than Ro multiplied by the specified lateral earthquake force as determined in ea004609 or ea004610, as appropriate. (See en000900.)
For buildings with a Type 9 irregularity as described in et001040 and where IES(0.2) is equal to or greater than 0.5, deflections determined in accordance with ea004611 shall be multiplied by 1.2.

For buildings where the value of α, as determined in accordance with es014476, exceeds twice the appropriate limit specified in et001040 for a Type 9 irregularity and where IES(0.2) is equal to or greater than 0.5, a Non-linear Dynamic Analysis of the structure shall be carried out in accordance with ea004610 and the following criteria: the analysis shall account for the effects of the vertical response of the building mass, the analysis shall account for the effects of the vertical response of building components that undergo a vertical displacement when displaced laterally, the analysis shall use vertical ground motion time histories that are compatible with horizontal ground motion time histories scaled to the target response spectrum and that are applied concurrently with the horizontal ground motion time histories, the largest interstorey deflection at any level of the building as determined from the analysis shall not be greater than 60% of the appropriate limit stated in es007932, and the results of an analysis using the ground motion time histories in es014478c multiplied by 1.5 shall satisfy the non-linear acceptance criteria. (See en000901.)

The design of buildings in Seismic Category SC3 or SC4 with a Type 10 irregularity as described in et001040 shall satisfy the following requirements: the structure shall be designed to resist the additional earthquake forces due to the vertical accelerations of the mass supported by inclined vertical members (see en000984), and the effects of the horizontal and vertical movements of inclined vertical members, while undergoing earthquake-induced deformations, on the floor systems they support shall be considered in the design of the building and accounted for in the application of es007890.

National Article Title: Equivalent Static Force Procedure for Structures Satisfying the Conditions of Article 4.1.8.7.
National Sentence Text: The static loading due to earthquake motion shall be determined according to the procedures given in this Article.

National Article Title: Equivalent Static Force Procedure for Structures Satisfying the Conditions of Article 4.1.8.7.
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es014479, the fundamental lateral period, Ta, in the direction under consideration in es007913, shall be determined as: for moment-resisting frames that resist 100% of the lateral earthquake forces and where the frame is not enclosed by or adjoined by more rigid elements that would tend to prevent the frame from resisting lateral forces: 0.085(hn)3/4 for steel moment frames, 0.075(hn)3/4 for concrete moment frames, or 0.1N for other moment frames, 0.025hn for braced frames, 0.05(hn)3/4 for shear wall and other structures, or other established methods of mechanics using a structural model that complies with the requirements of es007891, except that for moment-resisting frames, Ta shall not be taken as greater than 1.5 times that determined in es007914a, for braced frames, Ta shall not be taken as greater than 2.0 times that determined in es007914b, for shear wall structures, Ta shall not be taken as greater than 2.0 times that determined in es007914c, for other structures, Ta shall not be taken as greater than that determined in es007914c, and for the purpose of calculating the deflections, the period without the upper limit specified in Subclauses es007914d1 to es007914d5 may be used, except that, for walls, coupled walls and wall-frame systems, Ta shall not exceed 4.0 s, and for moment-resisting frames, braced frames, and other systems, Ta shall not exceed 2.0 s. (See en001160.)

National Article Title: Equivalent Static Force Procedure for Structures Satisfying the Conditions of Article 4.1.8.7.
National Sentence Text: For single-storey buildings with steel deck or wood roof diaphragms, the fundamental lateral period, Ta, in the direction under consideration is permitted to be taken as 0.05(hn)3/4 + 0.004L for shear walls, 0.035hn + 0.004L for steel moment frames and steel braced frames, or the value obtained from methods of mechanics using a structural model that complies with the requirements of es007891, except that Ta shall not be greater than 1.5 times the value determined in es014479a or es014479b, as applicable, where L is the shortest length of the diaphragm, in m, between adjacent vertical elements of the SFRS in the direction perpendicular to the direction under consideration.
