National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es002375, if a fire alarm system is required in a building that is not sprinklered, fire detectors shall be installed in the following spaces: storage rooms not within dwelling units, service rooms not within dwelling units, janitors' rooms rooms in which hazardous substances are to be used or stored (see en001115), elevator hoistways, chutes and dumbwaiter shafts, and laundry rooms in buildings of residential occupancy, but not those within dwelling units.

National Article Title: Rooms and Spaces Requiring Heat Detectors or Smoke Detectors
National Sentence Text: Heat detectors and smoke detectors described in es002374 are not required in dwelling units or in sprinklered buildings in which the sprinkler system is electrically supervised and equipped with a water flow alarm.

National Article Title: Smoke Detectors in Recirculating Air-Handling Systems
National Sentence Text: Except for a recirculating air system serving not more than one dwelling unit, where a fire alarm system is required to be installed, every recirculating air-handling system shall be designed to prevent the circulation of smoke upon a signal from a duct-type smoke detector where such system supplies more than one suite on the same floor or serves more than 1 storey.

National Article Title: Portions of Buildings Considered as Separate Buildings
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es002378, where a vertical fire separation having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 h separates a portion of a building from the remainder of the building and there are no openings through the fire separation other than those for piping, tubing, wiring and conduit, the requirements for fire alarm and detection systems may be applied to each portion so separated as if it were a separate building.

National Article Title: Portions of Buildings Considered as Separate Buildings
National Sentence Text: The permission in es002377 to consider separated portions of a building as separate buildings does not apply to service rooms and storage rooms.
Central vacuum cleaning systems serving more than one suite or storey in buildings equipped with a fire alarm system shall be designed to shut down upon activation of the fire alarm system.
A fire alarm system is not required in a storage garage conforming to ea000333 provided there are no other occupancies in the building.

Except as permitted by ea000015, smoke alarms conforming to ulcs531 shall be installed in each dwelling unit, each sleeping room not within a dwelling unit, and ancillary spaces and common spaces not in dwelling units in a house with a secondary suite.
The sound patterns of smoke alarms shall meet the temporal patterns of alarm signals (see en000061), or be a combination of temporal pattern and voice relay.

Within dwelling units, sufficient smoke alarms shall be installed so that there is at least one smoke alarm installed on each storey, including basements, and on any storey of a dwelling unit containing sleeping rooms, a smoke alarm is installed in each sleeping room, and in a location between the sleeping rooms and the remainder of the storey, and if the sleeping rooms are served by a hallway, the smoke alarm shall be located in the hallway. (See en000294.)
A smoke alarm required by es002383 shall be installed in conformance with ulcs553.
Smoke alarms required in ea001190 and es002383 shall be installed on or near the ceiling.

Except as provided in Sentences es002386 and es016041, smoke alarms described in es002382 shall be installed with permanent connections to an electrical circuit (see en000067), have no disconnect switch between the overcurrent device and the smoke alarm, and in case the regular power supply to the smoke alarm is interrupted, be provided with a battery as an alternative power source that can continue to provide power to the smoke alarm for a period of no less than 7 days in the normal condition, followed by 4 minutes of alarm.
Where the building is not supplied with electrical power, smoke alarms are permitted to be battery-operated.

Suites of residential occupancy are permitted to be equipped with smoke detectors in lieu of smoke alarms, provided the smoke detectors are capable of independently sounding audible signals with a sound pressure level between 75 dBA and 110 dBA within the individual suites (see also en000062), except as permitted in es016042, are installed in conformance with ulcs524, and form part of the fire alarm system. (See en001508.)

Smoke detectors permitted to be installed in lieu of smoke alarms as stated in es016041 are permitted to sound localized alarms within individual suites, and need not sound an alarm throughout the rest of the building.
Where more than one smoke alarm is required in a dwelling unit, the smoke alarms shall be interconnected so that the activation of any one alarm causes all alarms within the dwelling unit to sound.

Smoke alarms in a house with a secondary suite shall be wirelessly interconnected or interconnected by hard-wiring so that the activation of any one smoke alarm causes all smoke alarms within the house with a secondary suite to sound. (See en000858.)

Except as permitted in es016071, a manually operated device shall be incorporated within the circuitry of a smoke alarm installed in a dwelling unit so that the signal emitted by the smoke alarm can be silenced for a period of not more than 10 min, after which the smoke alarm will reset and sound again if the level of smoke in the vicinity is sufficient to re-actuate it.

Suites of residential occupancy equipped with smoke detectors installed to ulcs524, which are part of the fire alarm system in lieu of smoke alarms as permitted in es016041, need not incorporate the manually operated device required in es016070.

Where instructions are necessary to describe the maintenance and care required for smoke alarms to ensure continuing satisfactory performance, they shall be posted in a location where they will be readily available to the occupants for reference.

Except where a fire alarm system is installed or required in a building, smoke detectors forming part of a residential fire warning system installed in conformance with ulcs540 are permitted to be installed in lieu of all smoke alarms required by Articles ea001190 and ea001191, provided that the fire warning system is capable of sounding audible signals as stated in Articles ea005064 and ea001193, is powered as stated in ea001192, and is equipped with a silencing device as stated in ea005006

Except as provided in es002391, a window or access panel providing an opening not less than 1 100 mm high and 550 mm wide and having a sill height of not more than 900 mm above the floor shall be provided on the second and third storeys of every building in at least one wall facing on a street if such storeys are not sprinklered.
Access panels required in es002389 shall be readily openable from both inside and outside or be glazed with plain glass.
Access panels required in es002389 need not be provided in buildings containing only dwelling units where there is no dwelling unit above another dwelling unit, or houses with a secondary suite.

Except for basements in houses with a secondary suite or basements serving not more than one dwelling unit, each basement that is not sprinklered that exceeds 25 m in length or width shall be provided with direct access to the outdoors to at least one street.

Access required in es002392 may be provided by a door, window or other means that provides an opening not less than 1 100 mm high and 550 mm wide, the sill height of which shall not be more than 900 mm above the floor.
Access required in es002392 may also be provided by an interior stair accessible from the outdoors.
Access for fire department equipment shall be provided to each building by means of a street, private roadway or yard. (See Notes en000295 and en000070.)

Where access to a building as required in es002395 is provided by means of a roadway or yard, the design and location of such roadway or yard shall take into account connection with public thoroughfares, weight of firefighting equipment, width of roadway, radius of curves, overhead clearance, location of fire hydrants, location of fire department connections and vehicular parking.

Portable extinguishers shall be installed in all buildings, except within dwelling units, in conformance with the appropriate provincial or territorial regulations or municipal bylaws or, in the absence of such regulations or bylaws, the nrcc-nfc.

National Article Title: Freeze Protection of Fire Protection Systems
National Sentence Text: Equipment forming part of a fire protection system that may be adversely affected by freezing temperatures and that is located in an unheated area shall be protected from freezing.
Except as provided in Articles ea001201 to ea001208, construction camps shall conform to Subsections ep001029.10.1 to ep001029.10.20

Except for sleeping rooms within dwelling units, sleeping rooms in construction camps shall be separated from each other and from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having not less than a 30 min fire-resistance rating.

National Article Title: Floor Assemblies between the First and Second Storey
National Sentence Text: Except in a dwelling unit, a floor assembly in a construction camp building separating the first storey and the second storey shall be constructed as a fire separation having not less than a 30 min fire-resistance rating.
Walkways of combustible construction connecting buildings shall be separated from each connected building by a fire separation having not less than a 45 min fire-resistance rating.
Construction camp buildings shall be separated from each other by a distance of not less than 10 m except as otherwise permitted in Subsections ep001029.10.14and ep001029.10.15

Except in dwelling units and except as provided in es002405, the surface flame-spread rating of wall and ceiling surfaces in corridors and walkways, exclusive of doors, shall not exceed 25 over not less than 90% of the exposed surface area and not more than 150 over the remaining surface area.

Except within dwelling units, corridors that provide access to exit from sleeping rooms and that have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 45 min shall have a flame-spread rating conforming to the appropriate requirements in ep001029.10.17

Except in dwelling units, corridors providing access to exit from sleeping rooms in construction camp buildings with sleeping accommodation for more than 10 persons shall be provided with a smoke detector connected to the building alarm system.

Each construction camp building shall be provided with portable fire extinguishers in conformance with the appropriate provincial or territorial regulations or municipal bylaws or, in the absence of such regulations or bylaws, in conformance with the nrcc-nfc.

Every construction camp building providing sleeping accommodation for more than 30 persons shall be provided with a hose station that is protected from freezing and is equipped with a hose of sufficient length so that every portion of the building is within reach of a hose stream.
Hose stations required in es002408 shall be located near an exit.

Hoses referred to in es002408 shall be not less than 19 mm inside diam and shall be connected to a central water supply or to a storage tank having a capacity of not less than 4 500 L with a pumping system capable of supplying a flow of not less than 5 L/s at a gauge pressure of 300 kPa.

Except as required in es002412, natural gas and propane cooktops and ovens shall be installed in accordance with the applicable provincial or territorial regulations or municipal bylaws or, in the absence of such regulations or bylaws, with csab149.1. (See also ea001835)
Clearances for and protection around gas, propane and electric ranges shall be not less than those provided in Articles ea001210 and ea001211
Except as provided in es002414, framing, finishes and cabinetry installed directly above the location of the cooktop shall be not less than 750 mm above the level of cooktop burners or elements.

The vertical clearance described in es002413 for framing, finishes and cabinets located directly above the location of the cooktop may be reduced to 600 mm above the level of the elements or burners, provided the framing, finishes and cabinets are noncombustible, or are protected by a metal hood that projects 125 mm beyond the framing, finishes and cabinets.

Except as provided in Sentences es002416 and es002417, combustible wall framing, finishes or cabinets within 450 mm of the area where the cooktop is to be located shall be protected above the level of the heating elements or burners by gypsum board not less than 9.5 mm thick, or any material providing a fire-resistance rating of not less than 10 min and a flame-spread rating of not more than 25.
Counter-top splash boards or back plates that extend above the level of heating elements or burners need not be protected as described in es002415.
Except for cabinetry described in ea001210, cabinetry located not less than 450 mm above the level of the heating elements or burners need not be protected as described in es002415.

Except as provided in Sentences es016185 and es002420, a dwelling unit shall be separated from every other space in a building in which noise may be generated by a separating assembly and adjoining constructions, which together provide an apparent sound transmission class (ASTC) rating of not less than 47, or a separating assembly providing a sound transmission class (STC) rating of not less than 50 and adjoining constructions that conform to ea001885 (See en000738)

Where a house contains a secondary suite, each dwelling unit shall be separated from every other space in the house in which noise may be transmitted by construction whose joist spaces are filled with sound-absorbing material of not less than 150 mm nominal thickness, whose stud spaces are filled with sound-absorbing material, having a resilient channel on one side of the separation spaced 400 or 600 mm o.c., and having not less than 12.7 mm thick gypsum board on ceilings and on both sides of walls, construction providing an STC rating of not less than 43, or a separating assembly and adjoining constructions, which together provide an ASTC rating of not less than 40. (See en001521.)
Construction separating a dwelling unit from an elevator shaft or refuse chute shall have an STC rating of not less than 55.
The STC ratings shall be determined in accordance with astme413 using the results from measurements carried out in accordance with astme90.
The ASTC ratings shall be determined in accordance with astme413 using the results from measurements carried out in accordance with astme336 or calculated in accordance with ea000076 or ea000077

Compliance with the required STC ratings shall be demonstrated through measurements carried out in accordance with es002418, or the construction of separating assemblies conforming to et000261 or et000456, as applicable.

Compliance with the required ASTC ratings shall be demonstrated through measurements or calculations carried out in accordance with es008850, or the construction of separating assemblies conforming to et000261 or et000456, as applicable, that have an STC rating of not less than 50 in conjunction with flanking assemblies constructed in accordance with ea001885 (see en000739).
This Article applies where the required protection is provided in accordance with es002419b and compliance is demonstrated in accordance with es008852b.

Flanking wall assemblies connected to a separating floor or ceiling assembly shall be constructed with concrete or concrete block having a mass per area greater than 200 kg/m2, or gypsum board finish that is supported on wood or steel framing, and ends or is interrupted where it meets the structure of the separating floor or ceiling assembly.

Flanking wall and ceiling assemblies connected to a separating wall assembly shall be constructed with concrete or concrete block having a mass per area greater than 300 kg/m2, or gypsum board finish that is supported on wood or steel framing, and ends or is interrupted where it meets the structure of the separating wall assembly or, for double-stud walls, where it meets the space between the two lines of studs.

Flanking floor assemblies connected to a separating wall assembly shall be constructed with concrete having a mass per area greater than 300 kg/m2, or in accordance with ep001029.16, or supported on joists or trusses that are not continuous across the junction and are covered with floor treatments in accordance with et000089 for the applicable wall construction.

National Article Title: Removal of Topsoil and Organic Matter
National Sentence Text: The topsoil and vegetable matter in all unexcavated areas under a building shall be removed.

National Article Title: Removal of Topsoil and Organic Matter
National Sentence Text: In localities where termite infestation is known to be a problem, all stumps, roots and other wood debris shall be removed from the soil to a depth of not less than 300 mm in unexcavated areas under a building.

National Article Title: Removal of Topsoil and Organic Matter
National Sentence Text: The bottom of every excavation shall be free of all organic material.
Excavations shall be kept free of standing water.
The bottom of excavations shall be kept from freezing throughout the entire construction period.
Excavations for foundations shall extend to undisturbed soil.
Except as provided in Sentences es002430 to es008294, the minimum depth of foundations below finished ground level shall conform to et000178

Where a foundation is insulated in a manner that will reduce heat flow to the soil beneath the footings, the foundation depth shall conform to that required for foundations containing no heated space. (See en000299.)
The minimum depth of foundations for exterior concrete steps with more than 2 risers shall conform to Sentences es002427, es002428and es002431.
Concrete steps with 1 and 2 risers are permitted to be laid on ground level.

The foundation depths required in es002427 are permitted to be decreased where experience with local soil conditions shows that lesser depths are satisfactory, or where the foundation is designed for lesser depths.

The foundation depths required by es002427 do not apply to foundations for buildings that are not of masonry or masonry veneer construction, and whose superstructure conforms to the requirements of the deformation resistance test in csaz240.2.1 or accessory buildings that are not of masonry or masonry veneer construction, not more than1 storey in height, not more than55 m2 in building area, and where the distance from finished ground to the underside of the floor joists is not more than 600 mm.

The foundation depths required by es002427 do not apply to foundations for decks and other accessible exterior platforms of not more than 1 storey, not more than 55 m2 in area, where the distance from finished ground to the underside of the joists is not more than 600 mm, not supporting a roof, and not attached to another structure, unless it can be demonstrated that differential movement will not adversely affect the performance of that structure.

Where decks or other accessible exterior platforms are supported on surface foundations supported on other than coarse-grained soil with good drainage or rock, access to the foundation positions to permit re-levelling of the platform shall be provided by passageways with a clear height under the platform of not less than 600 mm and a width of not less than 600 mm, or by installing the decking in a manner that allows easy removal.
Backfill shall be placed to avoid damaging the foundation wall, the drainage tile, externally applied thermal insulation and waterproofing or dampproofing of the wall.
Backfill shall be graded to prevent drainage towards the foundation after settling.
Backfill that is within 600 mm of the foundation shall be free of deleterious debris and boulders larger than 250 mm diam. (See en001233.)

Except as provided in es008298, backfill shall not contain pyritic material or material that is susceptible to ice lensing in concentrations that will damage the building to a degree that would adversely affect its stability or the performance of assemblies. (See en001209.)

Backfill with material of any concentration that is susceptible to ice lensing is permitted where foundation walls are cast-in-place concrete, concrete block insulated on the exterior, or concrete block protected from the backfill by a material that serves as a slip plane. (See en001209.)

The soil in trenches beneath footings for sewers and watermains shall be compacted by tamping up to the level of the footing base, or shall be filled with concrete having a strength not less than 10 MPa to support the footing.
This Section presents measures to control the ingress of water, moisture and soil gas.
ep001029.13.2 applies to below-ground walls and floors-on-ground where drainage is provided in accordance with ep001029.14 over and along the entire below-ground portion of the foundation wall.
ep001029.13.3 applies to below-ground walls, floors-on-ground and roofs of underground structures that are subject to hydrostatic pressure.
ep001029.13.4 applies to walls, roofs and floors that are in contact with the ground.

Except as provided in ea004787, where the exterior finished ground level is at a higher elevation than the ground level inside the foundation walls, exterior surfaces of foundation walls below ground level shall be dampproofed.
Except as provided in es002439 and ea004787, floors-on-ground shall be dampproofed.

Dampproofing required in es002438 need not be provided for floors in garages, floors in unenclosed portions of buildings, or floors installed over not less than 100 mm of coarse clean granular material containing not more than 10% of material that will pass a 4 mm sieve.

Materials installed to provide required dampproofing shall be capable of protecting assemblies against moisture transfer from the ground, compatible with adjoining materials, and resistant to mechanisms of deterioration that may reasonably be expected, given the nature, function and exposure of the materials.

Except as otherwise specified in this Section, materials used for exterior dampproofing shall conform to one of the following standards: astmd1227 Type III, Class I, astmd4479m Type III, cgsb-51.34 or csaa123.4,or have a water vapour permeance of not more than 43 ng/(Pa×s×m2) when tested in accordance with Procedure A (wet cup) of astme96m and consist of one of the following material types: a vapour-resistant coating, a cold-fluid-applied or hot-rubberized bituminous dampproofing membrane, a liquid-applied or spray-applied asphalt-based emulsion dampproofing, or a type III hot-applied asphalt.
The area in which dampproofing is to be carried out shall be kept free of water during the application and curing of the dampproofing system.
The surface to be dampproofed shall be prepared in accordance with the instructions of the dampproofing material manufacturer.
Where the dampproofing material is to be applied on insulating concrete form (ICF) walls, the instructions of the ICF wall manufacturer shall be followed.
Unit masonry walls to be dampproofed shall be parged on the exterior face below ground level with not less than 6 mm of mortar conforming to ep001029.20 coved over the footing.

Concrete walls to be dampproofed shall have holes and recesses sealed with cement mortar or a mastic or sealant that is suitable for vertical applications and compatible with the dampproofing material.

The surface required to be dampproofed shall be clean and dry and free of ice, snow, frost, dust, dirt, oil, grease, cracks, projections and depressions, loose particles and debris that could be detrimental to the performance of the material to be applied.
Exterior dampproofing shall be applied from finished ground level to the top of the exterior of the footing.

Unless otherwise stated in this Subsection, dampproofing shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions with regard to surface priming, conditions during application, application quantity and rate, and curing times.
Joints, cracks and penetrations shall be sealed to maintain the continuity of the dampproofing, where the dampproofing material is not capable of bridging such discontinuities.

The interior surface of foundation walls below ground level shall be protected by means that minimize the ingress of moisture from the foundation wall into interior spaces, where a separate interior finish is applied to a concrete or unit masonry wall that is in contact with the soil, or wood members are placed in contact with such walls for the installation of insulation or finish.

Except as provided in es016074, where the protection of interior finishes required in es002450 consists of membranes or coatings, the membrane or coating shall extend from the basement floor surface up to the highest extent of the interior insulation or finish, but not higher than the exterior finished ground level, and no membrane or coating with a permeance less than 170 ng/(Pa×s×m2) shall be applied to the interior surface of the foundation wall above ground level between the insulation and the foundation wall.

Where insulation functions as both moisture protection for interior finishes and as a vapour barrier in accordance with ep001029.25.4, it shall be applied over the entire interior surface of the foundation wall.

Where dampproofing is installed below the floor, it shall consist of polyethylene not less than 0.15 mm thick with joints lapped not less than 100 mm, type S roll roofing with joints lapped not less than 100 mm, or rigid extruded/expanded polystyrene with sealed or ship-lapped joints that has sufficient compressive strength to support the floor assembly, and a water vapour permeance complying with es007689a.

Where dampproofing is installed between a floor-on-ground and a finished floor, it shall consist of rigid extruded/expanded polystyrene with sealed or ship-lapped joints that has sufficient compressive strength to support the floor assembly, and a water vapour permeance complying with es007689b, or polyethylene not less than 0.05 mm thick with joints lapped not less than 100 mm.
Where hydrostatic pressure occurs, waterproofing is required for assemblies separating interior space from the ground to prevent the ingress of water into building assemblies and interior spaces.
Waterproofing is required for roofs of underground structures to prevent the ingress of water into building assemblies and interior spaces.

Materials installed to provide required waterproofing shall be compatible with adjoining materials, and resistant to mechanisms of deterioration that may reasonably be expected, given the nature, function and exposure of the materials.

Materials used for exterior waterproofing shall conform to astmd1227 in which case, they shall be installed in accordance with es002457, astmd3019 where non-fibered and non-asbestos-fibered (Types I and III) asphalt roll roofing are permitted, astmd4479m in which case, they shall be installed in accordance with es002457 and with reinforcing material, astmd4637m astmd4811m astmd6878m cgsb37-gp-9ma where a primer is required, cgsb-37.50 cgsb-37.54 cgsb37-gp-56m cgsb-37.58 csaa123.2 csaa123.4, in which case, they shall be installed with reinforcing material, or csaa123.17.
Surfaces to be waterproofed shall be prepared in accordance with the instructions of the waterproofing material manufacturer.
Where the waterproofing material is to be applied on ICF walls, the instructions of the ICF wall manufacturer shall be followed.
Unit masonry walls that are to be waterproofed shall be parged on exterior surfaces below ground level with not less than 6 mm of mortar conforming to ep001029.20 coved over the footing.
Concrete walls that are to be waterproofed shall have all holes and recesses sealed with mortar or waterproofing material.

Surfaces required to be waterproofed shall be clean and dry and free of ice, snow, frost, dust, dirt, oil, grease, cracks, projections and depressions, loose particles and debris that could be detrimental to the performance of the waterproofing material.

Unless otherwise stated in this Subsection, waterproofing shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions with regard to surface priming, conditions during application, the required number of layers of reinforcing fabric on foundation, footings, floors, walls and structural slabs, application quantity and rate, and curing times.
Waterproofing shall be continuous across joints and at junctions between different building elements.
The waterproofed surface shall be protected with a suitable material to minimize mechanical damage during backfilling.
The area in which the waterproofing is to be carried out shall be kept free of water during the application and curing of the waterproofing system.

Basement floors-on-ground to be waterproofed shall have a system of membrane waterproofing provided between 2 layers of concrete, each of which shall be not less than 75 mm thick, with the floor membrane made continuous with the wall membrane to form a complete seal.

This Subsection applies to wall, roof and floor assemblies separating conditioned space from the ground, and the rough-in to allow the future protection of conditioned space that is separated from the ground by a wall, roof or floor assembly.
This Subsection addresses the leakage of soil gas from the ground into the building.
All wall, roof and floor assemblies separating conditioned space from the ground shall be protected by an air barrier system conforming to ep001029.25.3

Unless the space between the air barrier system and the ground is designed to be accessible for the future installation of a subfloor depressurization system, dwelling units and buildings containing residential occupancies shall be provided with the rough-in for a radon extraction system conforming to ea001239

Where buildings are used for occupancies other than those described in es016374, protection from radon ingress and the means to address high radon concentrations in the future shall conform to ea001239, or Parts 5 and 6 (see ea004636 and ea004646). (See en001577.)

National Article Title: Providing for the Rough-in for a Subfloor Depressurization System
National Sentence Text: Floors-on-ground shall be provided with a rough-in for subfloor depressurization consisting of a gas-permeable layer, an inlet and an outlet as described in es016377, or clean granular material and a pipe as described in es016378.

National Article Title: Providing for the Rough-in for a Subfloor Depressurization System
National Sentence Text: The rough-in referred to in es016376a shall include a gas-permeable layer installed in the space between the air barrier and the ground to allow the depressurization of that space, an inlet that allows for the effective depressurization of the gas-permeable layer (see en001578), and an outlet in the conditioned space that permits connection to depressurization equipment, is sealed to maintain the integrity of the air barrier system, and is clearly labeled to indicate that it is intended only for the removal of radon from below the floor-on-ground.

National Article Title: Providing for the Rough-in for a Subfloor Depressurization System
National Sentence Text: The rough-in referred to in es016376b shall include clean granular material installed below the floor-on-ground in accordance with es002563, and a pipe not less than 100 mm in diameter installed through the floor, such that its bottom end opens into the granular layer required in es016378a at or near the centre of the floor and not less than 100 mm of granular material projects beyond the terminus of the pipe measured along its axis (see en001578), its top end permits connection to depressurization equipment and is provided with an airtight cap, and the pipe is clearly labeled near the cap and, if applicable, every 1.8 m and at every change in direction to indicate that it is intended only for the removal of radon from below the floor-on-ground.
This Section applies to subsurface drainage and to surface drainage.
Drainage for crawl spaces shall conform to ep001029.18
Drainage requirements beneath floors-on-ground shall conform to ep001029.16

Unless it can be shown to be unnecessary, the bottom of every exterior foundation wall shall be drained by drainage tile or pipe laid around the exterior of the foundation in conformance with ep001029.14.3 or by a layer of gravel or crushed rock in conformance with ep001029.14.4

Where mineral fibre insulation or crushed rock backfill is provided adjacent to the exterior surface of a foundation wall, the insulation or backfill shall extend to the footing level to facilitate the drainage of ground water to the foundation's drainage system (see en000304), and any pyritic material in the crushed rock shall be limited to a concentration that will not damage the building to a degree that would adversely affect its stability or the performance of assemblies (see es008297 and en001209).
Drain tile and drain pipe for foundation drainage shall conform to astmc4 astmc412m astmc444m astmc700 bnq3624-115, csab182.1 or csag401.
Drain tile or pipe used for foundation drainage shall be not less than 100 mm in diam.
Drain tile or pipe shall be laid on undisturbed or well-compacted soil so that the top of the tile or pipe is below the bottom of the floor slab or the ground cover of the crawl space.
Drain tile or pipe with butt joints shall be laid with 6 mm to 10 mm open joints.
The top half of joints referred to in es002489 shall be covered with sheathing paper, 0.10 mm polyethylene or No. 15 asphalt or tar-saturated felt.

The top and sides of drain pipe or tile shall be covered with not less than 150 mm of crushed stone or other coarse clean granular material containing not more than 10% of material that will pass a 4 mm sieve.

Granular material used to drain the bottom of a foundation shall consist of a continuous layer of crushed stone or other coarse clean granular material containing not more than 10% of material that will pass a 4 mm sieve, and no pyritic material in a concentration that will damage the building to a degree that would adversely affect its stability or the performance of assemblies (see en001209).

Granular material described in ea004798 shall be laid on undisturbed or compacted soil to a minimum depth of not less than 125 mm beneath the footing of the building and extend not less than 300 mm beyond the outside edge of the footings.
The bottom of an excavation drained by a granular layer shall be graded so that the entire area described in ea001249 is drained to a sump conforming to ea001253
Where because of wet site conditions soil becomes mixed with the granular drainage material, sufficient additional granular material shall be provided so that the top 125 mm are kept free of soil.
Foundation drains shall drain to a sewer, drainage ditch or dry well.
Where a sump pit is provided it shall be not less than 750 mm deep, not less than 0.25 m2 in area, and provided with a cover.
Covers for sump pits shall be designed to resist removal by children, and to be airtight in accordance with es003108.
Where gravity drainage is not practical, an automatic sump pump shall be provided to discharge the water from the sump pit described in es002497 into a sewer, drainage ditch or dry well.
Dry wells may be used only when located in areas where the natural groundwater level is below the bottom of the dry well.
Dry wells shall be not less than 5 m from the building foundation and located so that drainage is away from the building.
The building shall be located or the building site graded so that water will not accumulate at or near the building.

National Article Title: Drainage away from Wells or Septic Disposal Beds
National Sentence Text: Surface drainage shall be directed away from the location of a water supply well or septic tank disposal bed.
Every window well shall be drained to the footing level or other suitable location.
Where runoff water from a driveway is likely to accumulate or enter a garage, a catch basin shall be installed to provide adequate drainage.
Downspouts shall conform to ea001635

Except as provided in Articles ea001261 and ea004800, this Section applies to concrete or unit masonry foundation walls and concrete footings not subject to surcharge on stable soils with an allowable bearing pressure of 75 kPa or greater, and for buildings of wood-frame or masonry construction, wood-frame foundation walls and wood or concrete footings not subject to surcharge on stable soils with an allowable bearing pressure of 75 kPa or greater, and for buildings of wood-frame construction, and flat insulating concrete form foundation walls and concrete footings not subject to surcharge (see en001236) on stable soils with an allowable bearing pressure of 75 kPa or greater, and for buildings of light-frame or flat insulating concrete form construction that are not more than 2 storeys in building height, with a maximum floor-to-floor height of 3 m.
Foundations for applications other than as described in es008325 shall be designed in accordance with ep001029.4
Buildings erected on permafrost shall have foundations designed by a designer competent in this field in accordance with the appropriate requirements of ep001024.

Where the superstructure of a detached building conforms to the requirements of the deformation resistance test in csaz240.2.1 the foundation shall be constructed in conformance with the remainder of this Section, or csaz240.10.1.
Concrete shall conform to ep001029.3
Concrete block shall conform to csaa165.1 and shall have a compressive strength over the average net cross-sectional area of the block of not less than 15 MPa.
Mortar, grout, mortar joints, corbelling and protection for unit masonry shall conform to ep001029.20

For concrete block foundation walls required to be reinforced, mortar shall be Type S, conforming to csaa179, grout shall be coarse, conforming to csaa179, and placement of grout shall conform to csaa371.
Where pier-type foundations are used, the piers shall be designed to support the applied loads from the superstructure.

Where piers are used as a foundation system in a building of 1 storey in building height, the piers shall be installed to support the principal framing members and shall be spaced not more than 3.5 m apart along the framing, unless the piers and their footings are designed for larger spacings.
The height of piers described in es002518 shall not exceed 3 times their least dimension at the base of the pier.

Where concrete block is used for piers described in es002518, they shall be laid with cores placed vertically, and where the width of the building is 4.3 m or less, placed with their longest dimension at right angles to the longest dimension of the building.
Foundations of wood-frame construction shall conform to csas406 or Part 4. (See en000305.)

Footings shall be provided under walls, pilasters, columns, piers, fireplaces and chimneys that bear on soil or rock, except that footings may be omitted under piers or monolithic concrete walls if the safe loadbearing capacity of the soil or rock is not exceeded.
Footings shall rest on undisturbed soil, rock or compacted granular fill.

Granular fill shall not contain pyritic material in a concentration that will damage the building to a degree that would adversely affect its stability or the performance of assemblies. (See also ea004697 and en001209.)

National Article Title: Application of Footing Width and Area Requirements
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es008333, the minimum footing width or area requirements provided in Articles ea004805 to ea004808 shall apply to footings, where the footings support foundation walls of masonry, concrete, or flat insulating concrete form walls, above-ground walls of masonry, flat insulating concrete form walls or light wood-frame construction, and floors and roofs of light wood-frame construction, the span of supported joists does not exceed 4.9 m, and the specified live load on any floor supported by the footing does not exceed 2.4 kPa (see et001029).

National Article Title: Application of Footing Width and Area Requirements
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es008333, where the span of the supported joists exceeds 4.9 m, footings shall be designed in accordance with ep001024.2

National Article Title: Application of Footing Width and Area Requirements
National Sentence Text: Where the specified live load exceeds 2.4 kPa, footings shall be designed in accordance with ep001024.2
Except as provided in Sentences es008333 and es008334 and in Articles ea004806 to ea004808, the minimum footing width or area shall comply with et000179

Where the supported joist span exceeds 4.9 m in buildings with light wood-frame walls, floors and roofs, strip footing widths shall be determined according to ep001024.2, or the following formulaW=w×Ssjs/storeys×4.9where W = minimum footing width, w = minimum width of footings supporting joists not exceeding 4.9 m, as defined by et000179, Σ sjs = sum of the supported joist spans on each storey bearing on an exterior wall whose load is transferred to the footing, or sum of half of the supported joist spans on each storey bearing on both sides of an interior wall whose load is transferred to the footing, and storeys = number of storeys supported by the footing. (See en000306.)

Where a foundation rests on gravel, sand or silt in which the water table level is less than the width of the footings below the bearing surface, the footing width for walls shall be not less than twice the width required by Sentences es008332 and es008333, and Articles ea004806 and ea004807, and the footing area for columns shall be not less than twice the area required by Sentences es008332 and es008333 and ea004808

National Article Title: Adjustments to Footing Widths for Exterior Walls
National Sentence Text: The strip footing widths for exterior walls shown in et000179 shall be increased by 65 mm for each storey of masonry veneer over wood-frame construction supported by the foundation wall, 130 mm for each storey of masonry construction supported by the foundation wall, and 150 mm for each storey of flat insulating concrete form wall construction supported by the foundation wall.

National Article Title: Adjustments to Footing Widths for Interior Walls
National Sentence Text: The minimum strip footing widths for interior loadbearing masonry walls shown in et000179 shall be increased by 100 mm for each storey of masonry construction supported by the footing.

National Article Title: Adjustments to Footing Widths for Interior Walls
National Sentence Text: Footings for interior non-loadbearing masonry walls shall be not less than 200 mm wide for walls up to 5.5 m high and the width shall be increased by 100 mm for each additional 2.7 m of height.

National Article Title: Adjustments to Footing Area for Columns
National Sentence Text: The footing area for column spacings other than shown in et000179 shall be adjusted in proportion to the distance between columns.
Footing thickness shall be not less than the greater of 100 mm, or the width of the projection of the footing beyond the supported element.
Where step footings are used, the vertical rise between horizontal portions shall not exceed 600 mm, and the horizontal distance between risers shall not be less than 600 mm.

National Article Title: Flat Wall Insulating Concrete Form Units
National Sentence Text: Flat wall insulating concrete form units shall conform to ulcs717.1.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Except as required in es008340, the thickness of foundation walls made of unreinforced concrete block, concrete core in flat wall insulating concrete forms or solid concrete and subject to lateral earth pressure shall conform to et001056 for walls not exceeding 3.0 m in unsupported height.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: The concrete core in flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall be not less than the greater of 150 mm, or the thickness of the concrete in the wall above.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: The thickness and reinforcing of foundation walls made of reinforced concrete block and subject to lateral earth pressure shall conform to et001057 and Sentences es008343 to es008348, where the walls are laterally supported at the top, average stable soils are encountered, and wind loads on the exposed portion of the foundation are no greater than 0.70 kPa.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: For concrete block walls required to be reinforced, continuous vertical reinforcement shall be provided at wall corners, wall ends, wall intersections, at changes in wall height, at the jambs of all openings and at movement joints, extend from the top of the footing to the top of the foundation wall, and where foundation walls are laterally supported at the top, have not less than 50 mm embedment into the footing, if the floor slab does not provide lateral support at the wall base.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: For concrete block walls required to be reinforced, a continuous horizontal bond beam containing not less than one 15M bar shall be installed along the top of the wall, at the sill and head of all openings greater than 1.20 m in width, and at structurally connected floors.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: In concrete block walls required to be reinforced, all vertical bar reinforcement shall be installed along the centre line of the wall.

National Article Title: Foundation Wall Thickness and Required Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: In concrete block walls required to be reinforced, ladder- or truss-type lateral reinforcement not less than 3.8 mm in diameter (no. 9 ASWG) shall be installed in the bed joint of every second masonry course.

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Top
National Sentence Text: Sentences es008350 to es008352 pertain to lateral support for walls described in es008339.

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Top
National Sentence Text: Foundation walls shall be considered to be laterally supported at the top if such walls support a solid masonry superstructure or flat insulating concrete form wall, the floor joists are embedded in the top of the foundation walls, the floor system is anchored to the top of the foundation walls with anchor bolts, in which case the joists may run either parallel or perpendicular to the foundation walls, or they extend from the footing to no more than 300 mm above the finished ground level and are backfilled on both sides such that the difference in elevation between the finished ground levels on either side of the wall is no more than 150 mm.

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Top
National Sentence Text: Unless the wall around an opening is reinforced to withstand earth pressure, the portion of the foundation wall beneath an opening shall be considered laterally unsupported if the opening is more than 1.2 m wide, or the total width of the openings in the foundation wall constitutes more than 25% of the length of the wall.

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Top
National Sentence Text: For the purposes of es008351, the combined width of the openings shall be considered as a single opening if the average width is greater than the width of solid wall between them.

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Top
National Sentence Text: Flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall be considered to be laterally supported at the top if the floor joists are installed according to ea004835

National Article Title: Foundation Walls Considered to be Laterally Supported at the Bottom
National Sentence Text: Flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall be considered to be laterally supported at the bottom where the foundation wall supports backfill not more than 1.2 m in height, is supported at the footing by a shear key and at the top by the ground floor framing, or is doweled to the footing with not less than 15M bars spaced not more than 1.2 m o.c., or 10M bars spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Foundation Walls
National Sentence Text: Horizontal reinforcement in flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall consist of one 10M bar placed not more than 300 mm from the top of the wall, and 10M bars at 600 mm o.c., and be located in the inside half of the wall section, and with a minimum cover of 30 mm from the inside face of the concrete.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Foundation Walls
National Sentence Text: Vertical reinforcement in flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall be provided in accordance with et001058 for 150 mm walls, et001059 for 190 mm walls, and et001060 for 240 mm walls, located in the inside half of the wall section with a minimum cover of 30 mm from the inside face of the concrete wall, and where interrupted by wall openings, placed not more than 600 mm from each side of the openings.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Foundation Walls
National Sentence Text: Cold joints in flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall be reinforced with no less than one 15M bar spaced at not more than 600 mm o.c. and embedded 300 mm on both sides of the joint.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Foundation Walls
National Sentence Text: Reinforcing around openings in flat insulating concrete form foundation walls shall comply with ea004833 or ea004834
Exterior foundation walls shall extend not less than 150 mm above finished ground level.
Where the top of a foundation wall is reduced in thickness to permit the installation of floor joists, the reduced section shall be not more than 350 mm high and not less than 90 mm thick.

Where the top of a foundation wall is reduced in thickness to permit the installation of a masonry exterior facing, the reduced section shall be not less than 90 mm thick, and tied to the facing material with metal ties conforming to es002711 spaced not more than 200 mm o.c. vertically, and 900 mm o.c. horizontally.
The space between wall and facing described in es002543 shall be filled with mortar.
Corbelling of masonry foundation walls supporting cavity walls shall conform to ea001379
Crack control joints shall be provided in foundation walls more than 25 m long at intervals of not more than 15 m.
Joints required in es002546 shall be designed to resist moisture penetration and shall be keyed to prevent relative displacement of the wall portions adjacent to the joint.
Interior masonry foundation walls not subject to lateral earth pressure shall conform to ep001029.20

Except as permitted in es002550, foundation walls of hollow masonry units supporting floor joists shall be capped with not less than 50 mm of concrete, solid masonry units that are 100% solid and not less than 50 mm high, or semi-solid or hollow solid masonry units that have the top course completely filled with mortar, grout or concrete.

Capping required in es002549 need not be provided in localities where termites are not known to occur, when the joists are supported on a wood plate not less than 38 mm by 89 mm, and when the siding overlaps the foundation wall not less than 12 mm.
Not less than 190 mm depth of solid masonry shall be provided beneath beams supported on masonry.
Where the beam referred to in es002551 is supported below the top of the foundation walls, the ends of such beams shall be protected from the weather.
Pilasters shall be provided under beams that frame into unit masonry foundation walls 140 mm or less in thickness.
Pilasters required in es002553 shall be not less than 90 mm by 290 mm and shall be bonded or tied into the wall.
The top 200 mm of pilasters required in es002553 shall be solid masonry with the cells of hollow or semi-solid units filled with mortar, grout or concrete.
Concrete block foundation walls shall be parged on the exterior face below ground level as required in ep001029.13
Exterior surfaces of concrete block foundation walls above ground level shall have tooled joints, or shall be parged or otherwise suitably finished.
All form ties shall be removed at least flush with the concrete surface.
This Section applies to floors supported on ground or on granular fill that do not provide structural support for the superstructure.
Floors-on-ground that support loads from the superstructure shall be designed in conformance with ep001024.
All spaces within dwelling units, except crawl spaces, shall be provided with a floor-on-ground, where access is provided to the space, and a floor supported by the structure is not provided.
Dampproofing and waterproofing shall conform to ep001029.13

Except as provided in es002564, not less than 100 mm of coarse clean granular material containing not more than 10% of material that will pass a 4 mm sieve shall be placed beneath floors-on-ground. (See also ep001029.13.4 and en000300)

Granular material need not be installed under slabs in garages, carports or accessory buildings, or buildings of industrial occupancy where the nature of the process contained therein permits or requires the use of large openings in the building envelope even during the winter.

Material that is susceptible to changes in volume due to variations in moisture content or chemical-microbiological oxidation shall not be used as fill beneath floors-on-ground in a concentration that will damage the building to a degree that would adversely affect its stability or the performance of assemblies. (See also ea004697 and en001209.)
Material that is susceptible to changes in volume due to freezing shall not be used as fill beneath floors-on-ground that will be subjected to freezing temperatures. (See also ea004697 and en001209.)
Except as provided in es002566, fill beneath floors-on-ground shall be compacted.
Fill beneath floors-on-ground need not be compacted where the material is clean coarse aggregate containing not more than 10% of material that will pass a 4 mm sieve.
Except as provided in ea001296 or where it can be shown to be unnecessary, ingress of water underneath a floor-on-ground shall be prevented by grading or drainage.
Where groundwater levels may cause hydrostatic pressure beneath a floor-on-ground, the floor-on-ground shall be a poured concrete slab, and designed to resist such pressures.
When floor drains are required (see ep001029.31), the floor surface shall be sloped so that no water can accumulate.
The finished surface of concrete floor slabs shall be trowelled smooth and even.
Dry cement shall not be added to the floor surfaces to absorb surplus water.

When a topping course is provided for a concrete floor slab, it shall consist of 1 part cement to 2.5 parts clean, well graded sand by volume, with a water/cement ratio approximately equal to that of the base slab.
When concrete topping is provided, it shall not be less than 20 mm thick.
Concrete slabs shall not be less than 75 mm thick exclusive of concrete topping.
A bond-breaking material shall be placed between the slab and footings or rock.
Floors-on-ground constructed of wood shall conform to csas406.

This Section applies to columns used to support beams carrying loads from not more than 2 wood-frame floors where the supported length of joists bearing on such beams does not exceed 5 m, and the live load on any floor does not exceed 2.4 kPa (see et001029), beams or header joists carrying loads from not more than 2 levels of wood-frame balconies, decks or other accessible exterior platforms, or 1 level plus the roof, where the supported length of joists bearing on such beams or joists does not exceed 5 m, the sum of the specified snow and occupancy loads does not exceed 4.8 kPa (see es008099 for the determination of load on platform-type constructions), and the platform serves only a single suite of residential occupancy, or carport roofs (see ep001029.35).
Columns for applications other than as described in es008361 shall be designed in accordance with ep001024.
Columns shall be centrally located on a footing conforming to ep001029.15
Columns shall be securely fastened to the supported member to reduce the likelihood of lateral differential movement between the column and the supported member. (See also ea004844)
Except as permitted by es008364, columns shall be laterally supported to resist racking directly, or by connection to the supported members. (See en001237.)

Columns need not be provided with lateral support as described in es008363, where the distance from finished ground to the underside of the joists is not more than 600 mm, and the columns support a deck with no superstructure.
Except as permitted in es002582, steel pipe columns shall have an outside diameter of not less than 73 mm and a wall thickness of not less than 4.76 mm.
Columns of sizes other than as specified in es002581 are permitted to be used where the loadbearing capacities are shown to be adequate.

Except as permitted in es002584, steel columns shall be fitted with not less than 100 mm by 100 mm by 6.35 mm thick steel plates at each end, and where the column supports a wooden beam, the top plate shall extend across the full width of the beam.
The top plate required in es002583 need not be provided where a column supports a steel beam and provision is made for the attachment of the column to the beam.
Exterior steel columns shall be treated on the outside surface with at least one coat of rust-inhibitive paint.
Where the imposed load does not exceed 36 kN, adjustable steel columns shall conform to cgsb-7.2.
Steel columns other than those described in es008366 shall be designed in accordance with Part 4.
The width or diameter of a wood column shall be not less than the width of the supported member.

Except as provided in ea001857, columns shall be not less than 184 mm for round columns and 140 mm by 140 mm for rectangular columns, unless calculations are provided to show that lesser sizes are adequate.
Wood columns shall be either solid, glued-laminated or built-up.

Built-up columns shall consist of not less than 38 mm thick full-length members bolted together with not less than 9.52 mm diam bolts spaced not more than 450 mm o.c., or nailed together with not less than 76 mm nails spaced not more than 300 mm o.c.
Glued-laminated columns shall conform to ep001024.3
Wood columns shall be separated from concrete in contact with the ground by 0.05 mm polyethylene film or Type S roll roofing.
Unit masonry columns shall be built of masonry units conforming to csaa165.1 and having a compressive strength over the net area of the block of not less than 15 MPa.
Unit masonry columns shall be not less than 290 mm by 290 mm or 240 mm by 380 mm in size.
Concrete shall conform to ep001029.3
Concrete columns shall be not less than 200 mm by 200 mm for rectangular columns and 230 mm diam for circular columns.
This Section applies to crawl spaces whose exterior walls have less than 25% of their total area above exterior ground level open to the outdoors.
Foundations enclosing crawl spaces shall conform to ep001029.15

Crawl spaces shall be considered to be heated where the space is used as a hot air plenum, contains heating ducts that are not sealed and insulated to minimize heat loss to the space, or is not separated from heated space in accordance with ep001029.25
Heating of heated crawl spaces shall conform to ep001029.33
Insulation, an air barrier system and a vapour barrier shall be installed in the walls of heated crawl spaces in accordance with ep001029.25

An access opening of not less than 500 mm by 700 mm shall be provided to each crawl space where the crawl space serves a single dwelling unit, and not less than 550 mm by 900 mm for other crawl spaces.
Access openings shall be fitted with a door or hatch, except when the crawl space is heated and the access opening into the crawl space is from an adjacent heated space.
Unheated crawl spaces shall be ventilated by natural or mechanical means.
Where an unheated crawl space is ventilated by natural means, ventilation shall be provided to the outside air by not less than 0.1 m2 of unobstructed vent area for every 50 m2 of floor area.
Vents shall be uniformly distributed on opposite sides of the building, and designed to prevent the entry of snow, rain and insects.
Heated crawl spaces shall be ventilated in accordance with ep001029.32

Where equipment requiring service such as plumbing cleanouts, traps and burners is located in crawl spaces, an access way with a height and width of not less than 600 mm shall be provided from the access door to the equipment and for a distance of 900 mm on the side or sides of the equipment to be serviced.
Except where it can be shown to be unnecessary, the ingress of water into a crawl space shall be controlled by grading or drainage.
Drainage of foundation walls shall conform to ea004797
Drainage of the ground cover or floor-on-ground in the crawl space shall conform to ep001029.16.3
Drains shall conform to ep001029.14

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Unheated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: Where a crawl space is unheated, a ground cover shall be provided consisting of not less than 50 mm of asphalt, 100 mm of 15 MPa Portland cement concrete, Type S roll roofing, or 0.10 mm polyethylene.

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Unheated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: Joints in sheet-type ground cover required in es002613 shall be lapped not less than 100 mm and weighted down.

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Heated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: Where a crawl space is heated, a ground cover consisting of not less than 0.15 mm polyethylene sheet conforming to cgsb-51.34 shall be installed as part of an air barrier system in accordance with ep001029.25.3

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Heated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: The ground cover required in es002615 shall have its joints lapped not less than 300 mm, and be sealed and evenly weighted down, or be covered with concrete not less than 50 mm thick.

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Heated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: The perimeter of the ground cover required in es002615 shall be sealed to the foundation wall. (See Notes en000300, en000301, and en000302.)

National Article Title: Ground Cover in Heated Crawl Spaces
National Sentence Text: All penetrations of the ground cover required in es002615 shall be sealed against air leakage. (See ep001029.25.3)

National Article Title: Crawl Spaces as Warm Air Plenums
National Sentence Text: Only crawl spaces under 1-storey portions of dwelling units shall be used as warm-air plenums.

National Article Title: Crawl Spaces as Warm Air Plenums
National Sentence Text: Enclosing material in crawl spaces described in es002618, including insulation, shall have a surface flame-spread rating not greater than 150.

National Article Title: Crawl Spaces as Warm Air Plenums
National Sentence Text: Combustible ground cover in crawl spaces described in es002618 shall be protected beneath each register opening with noncombustible material.

National Article Title: Crawl Spaces as Warm Air Plenums
National Sentence Text: The noncombustible register protection described in es002620 shall extend not less than 300 mm beyond the projection of the register opening, and have up-turned edges. (See en000307.)

Except where it can be shown to be unnecessary, where insulation is installed between a ceiling and the underside of the roof sheathing, a space shall be provided between the insulation and the sheathing, and vents shall be installed to permit the transfer of moisture from the space to the exterior. (See en000308.)
Except as provided in es002624, the unobstructed vent area shall be not less than 1/300 of the insulated ceiling area.
Where the roof slope is less than 1 in 6 or in roofs that are constructed with roof joists, the unobstructed vent area shall be not less than 1/150 of the insulated ceiling area.

Required vents may be roof type, eave type, gable-end type or any combination thereof, and shall be distributed uniformly on opposite sides of the building, with not less than 25% of the required openings located at the top of the space, and with not less than 25% of the required openings located at the bottom of the space.
Except where each joist space is separately vented, roof joist spaces shall be interconnected by installing purlins not less than 38 mm by 38 mm on the top of the roof joists.
Vents shall comply with csaa93.
Except as provided in es008370, not less than 63 mm of space shall be provided between the top of the insulation and the underside of the roof sheathing.

At the junction of sloped roofs and exterior walls, where preformed baffles are used to contain the insulation, the baffles shall provide an unobstructed air space, between the insulation and the underside of the roof sheathing, that is not less than 25 mm in dimension, and of sufficient cross area to meet the attic or roof space venting requirements of ea004820, and extend vertically not less than 50 mm above the top of the insulation.
Ceiling insulation shall be installed in a manner that will not restrict the free flow of air through roof vents or through any portion of the attic or roof space.
The lower portion of a mansard or gambrel style roof need not be ventilated.
The upper portion of roofs described in es002631 shall be ventilated in conformance with Articles ea001328 to ea004821

Every attic or roof space shall be provided with an access hatch where the open space in the attic or roof space measures 3 m2 or more in area, 1 m or more in length or width, and 600 mm or more in height over at least the area described in Clauses es002633a and es002633b. (See en001783.)

The hatch required in es002633 shall be not less than 550 mm by 900 mm except that, where the hatch serves not more than one dwelling unit, the hatch may be reduced to 0.32 m2 in area with no dimension less than 500 mm.
Hatchways to attic or roof spaces shall be fitted with doors or covers.

Except as provided in ea001334, this Section applies to unreinforced masonry and masonry veneer walls not in contact with the ground, where the height of the walls constructed on the foundation walls does not exceed 11 m, and the roof or floor assembly above the first storey is not of concrete construction, and flat insulating concrete form walls not in contact with the ground that (see en001236) have a maximum floor-to-floor height of 3 m, are erected in buildings not more than 2 storeys in building height, and are erected in locations where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is not greater than 0.4 (see en000309).

For walls other than those described in es008373, or where the masonry walls or insulating concrete form walls not in contact with the ground are designed for specified loads on the basis of ultimate and serviceability limit states, ep001024.3.2 shall apply.

In locations where the spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.55, loadbearing elements of masonry buildings more than 1 storey in building height shall be reinforced with not less than the minimum amount of reinforcement required by ep001029.20.15

In locations where the spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.35 but less than or equal to 0.55, loadbearing elements of masonry buildings 3 storeys in building height shall be reinforced with not less than the minimum amount of reinforcement required by ep001029.20.15
Masonry units shall comply with astmc73 astmc126 astmc212 csaa82 csaa165.1 csaa165.2 or csaa165.3.
Used bricks shall be free of old mortar, soot or other surface coating and shall conform to ea001335
Glass blocks shall not be used as loadbearing units or in the construction of fireplaces or chimneys.
Masonry made with cellular concrete shall not be used in contact with the soil or exposed to the weather.
Stone shall be sound and durable.

National Article Title: Concrete Blocks Exposed to the Weather
National Sentence Text: Concrete blocks exposed to the weather shall have density and water absorption characteristics conforming to concrete types A, B, C, or D described in csaa165.1.
The compressive strength of concrete blocks shall conform to et000181
Cementitious materials and aggregates for mortar and grout shall comply with csaa179.
Water and aggregate shall be clean and free of significant amounts of deleterious materials.
Lime used in mortar shall be hydrated.
If lime putty is used in mortar, it shall be made by slaking quicklime in water for not less than 24 h or soaking hydrated lime in water for not less than 12 h.
Mortar types shall be in accordance with et001061.
Mortar for glass block masonry shall be Type S Portland cement-lime where exposed to the exterior, or Type S or N where protected from the exterior.
Mortar shall be mixed within the proportion limits provided in et001062, with sufficient water to bring the mixture to a consistency adequate for laying masonry units.
Grout shall be mixed within the proportion limits provided in et001063, with sufficient water to provide a suitable flow to fill all voids completely, without excessive segregation or bleeding.

Except as provided in es008382, mortar shall be used and placed in final position within 1.5 h after mixing when the air temperature is 25°C or higher, or within 2.5 h after mixing when the air temperature is less than 25°C.

Mortar and grout containing a set-control admixture shall be manufactured off-site in a batching plant and shall be used and placed in final position within a time not exceeding the useful life stipulated by the manufacturer.
Grout used for reinforced masonry shall be placed in accordance with the requirements of csaa371.
Except as provided in es002657, mortar joint thickness for burned clay brick and concrete masonry units shall be 10 mm.
Permitted tolerances in head and bed joints shall be not more than ± 5 mm.
Hollow masonry units shall be laid with mortar applied to head and bed joints of both inner and outer face shells.

Vertically aligned webs of hollow masonry units shall be laid in a full bed of mortar under the starting course, in all courses of columns, and where adjacent to cells or cavities that are to be filled with grout.
Except for head joints left open for weep holes and ventilation, solid masonry units shall be laid with full head and bed joints.
All masonry shall be supported on masonry, concrete or steel, except that masonry veneer walls may be supported on foundations of wood frame constructed in conformance with es008327. (See en001239.)
Every masonry wall shall be at least as thick as the wall it supports, except as otherwise permitted in ea001379
Masonry over openings shall be supported by steel, masonry or reinforced concrete lintels, or masonry arches.
Steel angle lintels supporting masonry veneer above openings shall conform to et000183, and have a bearing length not less than 90 mm.
Steel angle lintels supporting masonry other than veneer, masonry and reinforced concrete lintels, and masonry arches shall be designed in accordance with ep001024 to support the imposed load.
Steel angle lintels supporting masonry shall be prime painted or otherwise protected from corrosion.

Masonry exterior walls, other than cavity walls, in 1-storey buildings and the top storeys of 2- and 3-storey buildings shall be not less than 140 mm thick, provided the walls are not more than 2.8 m high at the eaves and 4.6 m high at the peaks of gable ends.
The exterior walls of the bottom storeys of 2-storey buildings, and exterior walls of the bottom 2 storeys of 3-storey buildings shall be not less than 190 mm thick.
In exterior walls composed of more than one wythe, each wythe shall be not less than 90 mm thick.
Cavity walls shall be made with not less than 90 mm wide units if the joints are raked and not less than 75 mm wide units if the joints are not raked.
The width of a cavity in a cavity wall shall be not less than 50 mm and not greater than 150 mm.

The minimum thickness of cavity walls above the supporting base shall be 230 mm for the top 7.6 m and 330 mm for the remaining portion, except that where 75 mm wide units are used, the wall height above the top of the foundation wall shall not exceed 6 m.
The thickness of loadbearing interior walls shall be determined on the basis of the maximum lateral support spacing as provided in Sentences es002724 and es002725.

The thickness of interior non-loadbearing walls shall be determined on the basis of the maximum lateral support spacing as provided in Sentences es002724 and es002725, and in any case, not less than 65 mm.
Except for masonry veneer where each masonry unit is supported individually by the structural backing, masonry veneer shall consist of solid masonry units not less than 75 mm thick.
Veneer described in es008386 over wood-frame walls shall have not less than a 25 mm air space behind the veneer.
Masonry veneer less than 90 mm thick shall have unraked joints.
Masonry veneer shall conform to ep001024.3.2, where the masonry units are required to be individually supported by the structural backing.
The height of parapet walls above the adjacent roof surface shall be not more than 3 times the parapet wall thickness.

Parapet walls shall be solid masonry with the cells of hollow or semi-solid units filled with mortar, grout, or concrete, and that extends from the top of the parapet to not less than 300 mm below the adjacent roof level.
Slab and panel facings of precast concrete and natural or artificial stone shall conform to ep001024.3.2
Except as permitted in es002683 and ea001358, the depth of any chase or recess shall not exceed one third the thickness of the wall, and the width of the chase or recess shall not exceed 500 mm.
Except as permitted in es002683 and ea001358, no chase or recess shall be constructed in any wall 190 mm or less in thickness.
Recesses may be constructed in 190 mm walls provided they do not exceed 100 mm in depth, 750 mm in height and 500 mm in width.

Chases and recesses shall be not less than 4 times the wall thickness apart, and 600 mm away from any pilaster, cross wall, buttress or other vertical element providing required lateral support for the wall.

Chases or recesses that do not conform to the limits specified in Articles ea001355 to ea001357 shall be considered as openings, and any masonry supported above such a chase or recess shall be supported by a lintel or arch as provided in ea001348

National Article Title: Chases or Recesses Cut into Walls
National Sentence Text: Chases and recesses shall not be cut into walls made with hollow units after the masonry units are in place.

Except as permitted in es002688, loadbearing walls of hollow masonry units supporting roof or floor framing members shall be capped with not less than 50 mm of solid masonry or have the top course filled with concrete.
Capping required in es002687 may be omitted where the roof framing is supported on a wood plate not less than 38 mm by 89 mm.
Floor joists supported on cavity walls shall be supported on solid masonry units not less than 57 mm high.
Floor joists described in es002689 shall not project into the cavity.

Roof and ceiling framing members bearing on cavity walls shall be supported on solid masonry units not less than 57 mm high that bridge the full thickness of the wall, or a wood plate not less than 38 mm thick, bearing not less than 50 mm on each wythe.
The bearing area under beams and joists shall be sufficient to carry the supported load.
In no case shall the minimum length of end bearing of beams supported on masonry be less than 90 mm.
The length of end bearing of floor, roof or ceiling joists supported on masonry shall be not less than 40 mm.
Beams and columns supported on masonry walls shall be supported on pilasters where the thickness of the masonry wall or wythe is less than 190 mm.
Not less than 190 mm depth of solid masonry or concrete shall be provided under the beam or column referred to in es002695.
Pilasters required in es002695 shall be bonded or tied to masonry walls.
Concrete pilasters required in es002695 shall be not less than 50 mm by 300 mm.
Unit masonry pilasters required in es002695 shall be not less than 100 mm by 290 mm.

National Article Title: Projection of Masonry Veneer Beyond Supporting Members
National Sentence Text: Masonry veneer of solid masonry units resting on a bearing support shall not project more than one third of the thickness of the veneer. (See en000310.)

National Article Title: Projection of Masonry Veneer Beyond Supporting Members
National Sentence Text: Where the masonry veneer described in es002701 is rough stone masonry, the projection shall be measured as the average projection of the units, and the thickness of the veneer shall be measured as the average thickness of the veneer.

National Article Title: Joints to be Offset or Reinforced
National Sentence Text: Vertical joints in adjacent masonry courses shall be offset unless each wythe of masonry is reinforced with the equivalent of not less than 2 corrosion-resistant steel bars of 3.76 mm diam placed in the horizontal joints at vertical intervals not exceeding 460 mm.

National Article Title: Joints to be Offset or Reinforced
National Sentence Text: Where joints in the reinforcing referred to in es002703 occur, the bars shall be lapped not less than 150 mm.

National Article Title: Bonding or Tying of Other than Masonry Veneer
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in ea001369 regarding masonry veneer, masonry walls that consist of 2 or more wythes shall have the wythes bonded or tied together with masonry bonding units as described in ea001367 or with metal ties as described in ea001368
Where wythes are bonded together with masonry units, the bonding units shall comprise not less than 4% of the wall surface area.
Bonding units described in es002706 shall be spaced not more than 600 mm vertically and horizontally in the case of brick masonry and 900 mm o.c. in the case of block or tile.
Units described in es002706 shall extend not less than 90 mm into adjacent wythes.
Where 2 or more wythes are tied together with metal ties of the individual rod type, the ties shall conform to the requirements in Sentences es002711 to es002714.
Other ties may be used where it can be shown that such ties provide walls that are at least as strong and as durable as those made with the individual rod type.

Metal ties of the individual rod type shall be corrosion-resistant, have a minimum cross-sectional area of not less than 17.8 mm2, and have not less than a 50 mm portion bent at right angles at each end.
