Metal ties of the individual rod type shall extend from within 25 mm of the outer face of the wall to within 25 mm of the inner face of the wall, be completely embedded in mortar except for the portion exposed in cavity walls, and be staggered from course to course.

Where 2 or more wythes in walls other than cavity walls and masonry veneer/masonry backing walls are tied together with metal ties of the individual rod type, the space between wythes shall be completely filled with mortar.

Ties described in es002713 shall be located within 300 mm of openings and spaced not more than 900 mm apart around openings, and spaced not more than 900 mm apart horizontally and 460 mm apart vertically at other locations.

Except as required in Sentences es002716 and es002717, where the inner and outer wythes of cavity walls are tied with individual wire ties, the ties shall be spaced not more than 900 mm apart horizontally and 400 mm apart vertically.
Within 100 mm of the bottom of each floor or roof assembly where the cavity extends below the assemblies, the ties described in es002715 shall be spaced not more than 600 mm apart horizontally.
Within 300 mm of any openings, the ties described in es002715 shall be spaced not more than 900 mm apart.

Masonry veneer 75 mm or more in thickness and resting on a bearing support shall be tied to masonry backing or to wood framing members with straps that are corrosion-resistant, not less than 0.76 mm thick, not less than 22 mm wide, shaped to provide a key with the mortar, pre-bent during manufacture to a right angle within 6 mm of the fastener hole, fastened with corrosion-resistant wood screws conforming to es002862 that have a minimum diameter of 4.16 mm (No. 8) and a wood penetration of not less than 38 mm, or corrosion-resistant common spiral nails conforming to es002861 that are not less than 76 mm long and have a wood penetration of not less than 63 mm, and spaced in accordance with et000184
Where hot-dipped, zinc-coated straps are used to meet the requirements of es002718, they shall be pre-bent and pre-drilled or pre-punched prior to hot-dip, zinc-coated galvanizing.
Masonry veneer individually supported by masonry or wood-frame backing shall be secured to the backing in conformance with ep001024.3.2

Glass block shall have horizontal joint reinforcement of 2 corrosion-resistant bars of not less than 3.76 mm diam or expanded metal strips not less than 75 mm wide spaced at vertical intervals of not more than 600 mm for units 200 mm or less in height, and installed in every horizontal joint for units higher than 200 mm.
Reinforcement required in es002721 shall be lapped not less than 150 mm.
Masonry walls shall be laterally supported by floor or roof construction or by intersecting masonry walls or buttresses.

The spacing of supports required in es002723 shall be not more than 20 times the wall thickness for all loadbearing walls and exterior non-loadbearing walls, and 36 times the wall thickness for interior non-loadbearing walls.
In applying es002724, the thickness of cavity walls shall be taken as the greater of two-thirds of the sum of the thicknesses of the wythes, or the thickness of the thicker wythe.

Floor and roof constructions providing lateral support for walls as required in es002723 shall be constructed to transfer lateral loads to walls or buttresses approximately at right angles to the laterally supported walls.

National Article Title: Anchorage to Floor or Roof Assemblies where Masonry Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Where required to receive lateral support (see ep001029.20.10), masonry walls shall be anchored to each floor or roof assembly at maximum intervals of 2 m, except that anchorage to floor joists not more than 1 m above grade may be omitted.

National Article Title: Anchorage to Floor or Roof Assemblies where Masonry Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Anchors required in es002727 shall be corrosion-resistant and be not less than the equivalent of 40 mm by 4.76 mm thick steel straps.

National Article Title: Anchorage to Floor or Roof Assemblies where Masonry Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Anchors required in es002727 shall be shaped to provide a mechanical key with the masonry and shall be securely fastened to the horizontal support to develop the full strength of the anchor.

National Article Title: Anchorage to Floor or Roof Assemblies where Masonry Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: When joists are parallel to the wall, anchors required in es002727 shall extend across not less than 3 joists.

National Article Title: Bonding and Tying Intersecting Masonry Walls where Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Where required to provide lateral support, intersecting walls shall be bonded or tied together.

National Article Title: Bonding and Tying Intersecting Masonry Walls where Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Where bonding is used to satisfy the requirements of es002731, 50% of the adjacent masonry units in the intersecting wall, distributed uniformly over the height of the intersection, shall be embedded in the laterally supported wall.

National Article Title: Bonding and Tying Intersecting Masonry Walls where Walls Require Lateral Support
National Sentence Text: Where tying is used to satisfy the requirements of es002731, the ties shall be corrosion-resistant metal, equivalent to not less than 4.76 mm by 40 mm steel strapping, spaced not more than 800 mm o.c. vertically, and shaped at both ends to provide sufficient mechanical key to develop the strength of the ties.

National Article Title: Anchoring Intersecting Wood-Frame Walls to Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Wood-frame walls shall be anchored to masonry walls that they intersect with not less than 4.76 mm diam corrosion-resistant steel rods spaced not more than 900 mm o.c. vertically.

National Article Title: Anchoring Intersecting Wood-Frame Walls to Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Anchors required in es002734 shall be fastened to the wood framing at one end and shaped to provide a mechanical key at the other end to develop the strength of the anchor.

National Article Title: Anchoring Wood-Frame Roof Systems to Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Except as permitted in es002737, roof systems of wood-frame construction shall be anchored to exterior masonry walls by not less than 12.7 mm diam anchor bolts, spaced not more than 2.4 m apart, embedded not less than 90 mm into the masonry, and fastened to a rafter plate of not less than 38 mm thick lumber.

National Article Title: Anchoring Wood-Frame Roof Systems to Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: The roof system described in es002736 is permitted to be anchored by nailing the wall furring strips to the side of the rafter plate.

National Article Title: Anchoring Masonry Cornices, Sills and Trim to Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Cornices, sills or other trim of masonry material which project beyond the wall face shall have not less than 65% of their mass, but not less than 90 mm, within the wall or shall be adequately anchored to the wall with corrosion-resistant anchors.

Where anchor bolts are to be placed in the top of a masonry pier, the pier shall conform to the requirements of es002520 and shall be capped with concrete or reinforced masonry not less than 200 mm thick.
All corbelling shall consist of solid masonry units.

The units referred to in es002740 shall be corbelled so that the horizontal projection of any unit does not exceed 25 mm and the total projection does not exceed one third of the total wall thickness.
Cavity walls of greater thickness than the foundation wall on which they rest shall not be corbelled but may project 25 mm over the outer face of the foundation wall disregarding parging.

Where the foundation wall referred to in es002742 is unit masonry, it is permitted to be corbelled to meet flush with the inner face of a cavity wall provided the projection of each course does not exceed half the height or one third the thickness of the corbelled unit, and the total corbel does not exceed one third of the foundation wall thickness. (See en000311.)

Masonry veneer resting on a bearing support shall not project more than 25 mm beyond the supporting base where the veneer is not less than 90 mm thick, and 12 mm beyond the supporting base where the veneer is less than 90 mm thick.
In the case of rough stone veneer, the projection, measured as the average projection of the stone units, shall not exceed one-third the bed width beyond the supporting base.
Materials used for flashing shall conform to et000185
Aluminum flashing in contact with masonry or concrete shall be effectively coated or separated from the masonry or concrete by an impervious membrane.
Fastening devices for flashing shall be corrosion-resistant and, where metal flashing is used, shall be compatible with the flashing with respect to galvanic action.

Flashing shall be installed in masonry and masonry veneer walls beneath jointed masonry window sills, over the back and top of parapet walls, over the heads of glass block panels, beneath weep holes, and over the heads of window or door openings in exterior walls when the vertical distance between the top of a window or door frame and the bottom edge of the eave exceeds one-quarter of the horizontal eave overhang.
When installed beneath jointed masonry window sills or over the heads of openings, flashing shall extend from the front edge of the masonry up behind the sill or lintel.

National Article Title: Flashing for Weep Holes in Masonry/Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Flashing beneath weep holes in cavity walls and masonry veneer/masonry backing walls shall be bedded not less than 25 mm in the inside wythe, extend to not less than 5 mm beyond the outer face of the building element below the flashing, and be installed with a nominally horizontal slope toward the outside wythe.

National Article Title: Flashing for Weep Holes in Masonry Veneer
National Sentence Text: Flashing beneath weep holes in masonry veneer over masonry backing walls shall conform to the flashing requirements for cavity walls and masonry veneer/masonry backing walls in Article ea001385

National Article Title: Flashing for Weep Holes in Masonry Veneer
National Sentence Text: Flashing beneath weep holes in masonry veneer over wood-frame walls shall be installed so that it extends from a point not less than 5 mm beyond the outer face of the building element below the flashing to a point 150 mm up the wood-frame wall.

National Article Title: Flashing for Weep Holes in Masonry Veneer
National Sentence Text: Where the frame wall is sheathed with a sheathing membrane, a non-wood-based rigid exterior insulating sheathing or a semi-rigid insulating sheathing with an integral sheathing membrane, the flashing shall be installed behind the sheathing membrane or insulating sheathing.

National Article Title: Flashing for Weep Holes in Masonry Veneer
National Sentence Text: Flashing described in es002753 is permitted to conform to the requirements for concealed flashing in et000185
Joints in flashing shall be made watertight.
Weep holes spaced not more than 800 mm apart shall be provided at the bottom of cavities in cavity walls, and cavities or air spaces in masonry veneer walls.
The cavities or air spaces described in es002757 shall include those above lintels over window and door openings required to be flashed in conformance with ea001383

Except as provided in es002761, where the interior finish of the exterior walls of a building is a type that may be damaged by moisture, exterior masonry walls, other than cavity walls or walls that are protected for their full height by a roof of a carport or porch, shall be covered on the interior surface with sheathing membrane conforming to cgsb-51.32 lapped not less than 100 mm at the joints.
In situations described in es002759, flashing shall be provided where water will accumulate, to lead it to the exterior.

Where insulation that effectively limits the passage of water is applied by a waterproof adhesive or mortar directly to parged masonry, the requirements for sheathing membrane in es002759 do not apply.(See en000312.)
Cavity walls shall be constructed so that mortar droppings are prevented from forming a bridge to allow the passage of rain water across the cavity.

National Article Title: Caulking at Door and Window Frames
National Sentence Text: The junction of door and window frames with masonry shall be caulked in conformance with ep001029.27.4
Where no flashing is installed beneath window sills, such sills shall be provided with a drip not less than 25 mm from the wall surface.

National Article Title: Laying Temperature of Mortar and Masonry
National Sentence Text: Mortar and masonry shall be maintained at a temperature not below 5°C during installation and for not less than 48 h after installation.

National Article Title: Laying Temperature of Mortar and Masonry
National Sentence Text: No frozen material shall be used in mortar mix.
The top surface of uncompleted masonry exposed to the weather shall be completely covered with a waterproofing material when construction is not in progress.

Where reinforcement is required in this Section, masonry walls shall be reinforced horizontally and vertically with steel having a total cross-sectional area of not less than 0.002 times the horizontal cross-sectional area of the wall, so that not less than one-third of the required steel area is installed either horizontally or vertically and the remainder in the other direction.
Where reinforcement for masonry is required in this Section, it shall be installed in conformance with the requirements for reinforced masonry as contained in csaa371.
Carbon steel connectors required to be corrosion-resistant shall be galvanized to at least the minimum standards in et000186

National Article Title: Thickness of Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: The thickness of the concrete in flat insulating concrete form walls not in contact with the ground shall be not less than 140 mm, and constant for the entire height of the wall.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Horizontal reinforcement in above-grade flat insulating concrete form walls shall consist of one 10M bar placed not more than 300 mm from the top of the wall, and 10M bars at 600 mm o.c., and be placed in the middle third of the wall section.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Vertical reinforcement in above-grade flat insulating concrete form walls shall consist of 10M bars at 400 mm o.c., and be placed in the middle third of the wall section.

National Article Title: Reinforcement for Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Vertical reinforcement required by es008392 and interrupted by wall openings shall be placed not more than 600 mm from each side of the opening.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: No openings shall occur within 1 200 mm of interior and exterior corners of exterior non-loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Portions of walls above openings in non-loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls shall have a minimum depth of concrete of no less than 200 mm across the width of the opening.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Openings that are more than 600 mm but not more than 3 000 mm in width in non-loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls shall be reinforced at the top and bottom with one 10M bar.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Openings more than 3 000 mm in width in non-loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls shall be reinforced on all four sides with two 10M bars.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Reinforcing bars described in Sentences es008396 and es008397 shall extend 600 mm beyond the edges of the opening.

National Article Title: Openings in Non-Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: The cumulative width of openings in non-loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls shall not make up more than 70% of the length of any wall.

National Article Title: Openings in Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: No openings shall occur within 1 200 mm of interior and exterior corners of exterior loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls.

National Article Title: Openings in Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: In loadbearing flat insulating concrete form walls, lintels shall be provided over all openings wider than 900 mm.

National Article Title: Openings in Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Lintels described in es008400 shall be constructed in accordance with Span Table et001077, et001078 or et001079.

National Article Title: Openings in Loadbearing Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Lintels described in es008400 over openings wider than 1 200 mm shall be reinforced for shear with 10M stirrups at a maximum spacing of half the distance from the bottom reinforcing bar to the top of the lintel.

National Article Title: Framing Supported on Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Floor joists supported on the side of flat insulating concrete form walls shall be supported with joist hangers secured to wood ledger boards.

National Article Title: Framing Supported on Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: The ledger boards referred to in es008404 shall be not less than 38 mm thick, and the depth of the floor joists.

National Article Title: Framing Supported on Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Anchor bolts shall be used to secure ledger boards to flat insulating concrete form walls and shall be embedded in the wall to a depth not less than 100 mm, and spaced in accordance with et001064

National Article Title: Framing Supported on Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Floor joists and building frames supported on the top of flat insulating concrete form walls shall be anchored in conformance with ea001473

National Article Title: Anchoring of Roof Framing to the Top of Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Roof framing supported on the top of flat insulating concrete form walls shall be fixed to the top plates, which shall be anchored to the wall with anchor bolts not less than 12.7 mm in diameter, and spaced at not more than 1 200 mm o.c.

National Article Title: Anchoring of Roof Framing to the Top of Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: The anchor bolts described in es008408 shall be placed in the centre of the flat insulating concrete form wall and shall be embedded no less than 100 mm into the concrete.

National Article Title: Anchoring of Roof Framing to the Top of Flat Insulating Concrete Form Walls
National Sentence Text: Attachment of roof framing to wood top plates shall be in accordance with et000189
Above-ground flat insulating concrete form walls shall be protected from precipitation and damage in conformance with ep001029.27

This Section applies to rectangular masonry or concrete chimneys not more than 12 m in height serving fireplaces or serving appliances having a combined total rated heat output of 120 kW or less, and flue pipes connected to such chimneys.

Chimneys, other than those described in es008412, gas vents and flue pipes serving gas-, oil- or solid-fuel-burning appliances and their associated equipment, including stoves, cooktops, ovens and space heaters, covered by the standards referenced in Sentences es008590 and es008592 shall conform to ep001029.33.10
Chimneys and flue pipes other than those described in Sentences es008412 and es008413 shall conform to ep001026.3
The walls of any chimney or flue pipe shall be constructed so as to be smoke- and flame-tight.
A chimney flue that serves a fireplace or incinerator shall not serve any other appliance.
A chimney flue that serves a solid-fuel-burning appliance shall not be connected to a natural-gas- or propane-fired appliance.

A chimney flue that serves a solid-fuel-burning appliance shall not be connected to an oil-burning appliance unless the solid-fuel-burning appliance is certified for such installation and the installation of both appliances meets the requirements of the relevant standards referenced in ea004889

National Article Title: Connections of More Than One Appliance
National Sentence Text: Except as required by ea004839, where two or more fuel-burning appliances are connected to the same chimney flue, the connections shall be made as described in Sentences es002779 to es008418 and an adequate draft shall be provided for the connected appliances in conformance with the requirements of applicable provincial or territorial regulations or municipal bylaws or, in the absence of such regulations or bylaws, with the requirements of the relevant standards listed in ep001029.33.10

National Article Title: Connections of More Than One Appliance
National Sentence Text: Where 2 or more fuel-burning appliances are connected to the same chimney flue, the appliances shall be located on the same storey.

National Article Title: Connections of More Than One Appliance
National Sentence Text: The connection referred to in es002779 for a solid-fuel-burning appliance shall be made below connections for appliances burning other fuels.

National Article Title: Connections of More Than One Appliance
National Sentence Text: The connection referred to in es002779 for a liquid-fuel-burning appliance shall be made below any connections for appliances burning natural gas or propane.
Chimney flues shall not be inclined more than 45° to the vertical.
Except for chimneys serving fireplaces, the size of a chimney flue shall conform to the requirements of the appliance installation standards referenced in Sentences es008590 and es008592.
Where a chimney flue serves only one appliance, the flue area shall be at least equal to that of the flue pipe connected to it.
The size of a chimney flue serving a masonry fireplace shall conform to et000187 or et000188.
The width of an oval chimney flue shall be not less than two-thirds its breadth.
Every masonry or concrete chimney shall have a lining of clay, concrete, firebrick or metal.
Joints of chimney liners shall be sealed to provide a barrier to the passage of flue gases and condensate into the cavity between the liner and the surrounding masonry.
Joints of clay, concrete or firebrick chimney liners shall be struck flush to provide a straight, smooth, aligned chimney flue.
Clay liners shall conform to csaa324.
Liners referred to in es002789 shall be not less than 15.9 mm thick and shall be capable of resisting, without softening or cracking, a temperature of 1 100°C.
Firebrick liners shall conform to astmc27.
Firebrick liners shall be laid with high temperature cement mortar conforming to cgsb-10.3.
Concrete flue liners shall conform to Clause 4.2.6.4 of csaa405.
Metal liners shall be constructed of not less than 0.3 mm thick stainless steel.
Metal liners referred to in es002794 shall only be used in chimneys serving gas- or oil-burning appliances.(See en000314.)
Chimney liners shall be installed when the surrounding masonry or concrete is placed.

National Article Title: Spaces between Liners and Surrounding Masonry
National Sentence Text: A space not less than 10 mm wide shall be left between a chimney liner and surrounding masonry.

National Article Title: Spaces between Liners and Surrounding Masonry
National Sentence Text: The space required in es002797 shall not be filled with mortar.

Chimney liners used in chimneys for solid-fuel-burning appliances shall be laid in a full bed of high temperature cement mortar conforming to cgsb-10.3, or mortar consisting of 1 part Portland cement to 3 parts sand by volume.
Chimney liners used in chimneys for oil- or gas-burning appliances shall be laid in a full bed of mortar consisting of 1 part Portland cement to 3 parts sand by volume.
Chimney liners shall extend from a point not less than 200 mm below the lowest flue pipe connection to a point not less than 50 mm or more than 100 mm above the chimney cap.
Unit masonry shall conform to ep001029.20
Concrete shall conform to ep001029.3
Footings for masonry chimneys and concrete chimneys shall conform to ep001029.15

A chimney flue shall extend not less than 900 mm above the highest point at which the chimney comes in contact with the roof, and 600 mm above the highest roof surface or structure within 3 m of the chimney. (See en000315.)
Except as provided in es002807, chimneys shall be braced in accordance with ep001024.3.2 to provide lateral stability under wind loads.

A chimney need not be laterally braced provided no horizontal outside dimension is less than 400 mm, and the chimney extends not more than 3.6 m above a roof or the masonry wall of which it forms a part. (See en000316.)
The top of a chimney shall have a waterproof cap of reinforced concrete, masonry or metal.
The cap required in es002808 shall slope from the lining and be provided with a drip not less than 25 mm from the chimney wall.
Cast-in-place concrete caps shall be separated from the chimney liner by a bond break and be sealed at that location.
Jointed precast concrete or masonry chimney caps shall have flashing installed beneath the cap extending from the liner to the drip edge.
A cleanout opening with a metal frame and a tight-fitting metal door shall be installed near the base of the chimney flue.
The walls of a masonry chimney shall be built of solid masonry units not less than 75 mm thick.
Flue liners in the same chimney shall be separated by not less than 75 mm of masonry or concrete exclusive of liners where clay liners are used, or 90 mm of firebrick where firebrick liners are used.
Flue liners referred to in es002814 shall be installed to prevent significant lateral movement.
Junctions with adjacent materials shall be adequately flashed to shed water.
The clearance between masonry or concrete chimneys and combustible framing shall be not less than 50 mm for interior chimneys, and 12 mm for exterior chimneys. (See en000317.)
A clearance of not less than 150 mm shall be provided between a cleanout opening and combustible material.
Combustible flooring and subflooring shall have not less than a 12 mm clearance from masonry or concrete chimneys.
All spaces between masonry or concrete chimneys and combustible framing shall be sealed top or bottom with noncombustible material.
Joists or beams may be supported on masonry walls which enclose chimney flues provided the combustible members are separated from the flue by not less than 290 mm of solid masonry.
Except when otherwise specifically stated herein, this Section applies to masonry fireplaces constructed on-site.
Except as otherwise stated in this Section, unit masonry shall conform to ep001029.20 and concrete to ep001029.3
Masonry above openings shall be supported by steel lintels conforming to es002663, reinforced concrete or a masonry arch.
Footings for masonry and concrete fireplaces shall conform to ep001029.15

Where a supply of combustion air is provided directly to the fire chamber of a fireplace, including a factory-built fireplace, the installation shall comply with the “Outdoor Air Supply” requirements provided in csaa405.
Except where a fireplace is equipped with a steel liner, every fireplace shall have a firebrick liner.
Firebrick liners shall be not less than 50 mm thick for the sides and back, and 25 mm thick for the floor.
Firebrick liners shall be laid with high temperature cement mortar conforming to cgsb-10.3.
Joints between a firebrick liner and the adjacent backing masonry shall be offset.
Steel liners for fireplaces shall conform to ulcs639 and shall be installed in accordance with the installation instructions in that standard.

Except as provided in es002833, the thickness of the back and sides of a fireplace, including the thickness of any firebrick liner, shall be not less than 190 mm where a metal liner or a firebrick liner less than 51 mm thick is used.

When a steel fireplace liner is used with an air circulating chamber surrounding the firebox, the back and sides of the fireplace shall consist of solid masonry units not less than 90 mm thick, or hollow masonry units not less than 190 mm thick.
The distance from the back of the fire chamber to the plane of the fireplace opening shall be not less than 300 mm.

Except as required in es002836, fireplaces shall have a noncombustible hearth extending not less than 400 mm in front of the fireplace opening and not less than 200 mm beyond each side of the fireplace opening.

Where the fire chamber floor is elevated more than 150 mm above the hearth, the dimension of the hearth measured perpendicular to the plane of the fireplace opening shall be increased by not less than 50 mm for an elevation above 150 mm and not more than 300 mm, and an additional 25 mm for every 50 mm in elevation above 300 mm.

Except as permitted in es002838, the fire chamber floor and hearth shall be supported on a reinforced concrete slab not less than 100 mm thick at its supports and, if cantilevered, not less than 50 mm thick at its unsupported edge.

A hearth for a fireplace with an opening raised not less than 200 mm from a combustible floor is permitted to be supported on that floor provided the requirements of Clauses 5.3.6.5. to 5.3.6.7. of csaa405, are followed.
The throat of every fireplace shall be equipped with a metal damper sufficiently large to cover the full area of the throat opening.
The sides of the smoke chamber connecting a fireplace throat with a flue shall not be sloped at an angle greater than 45° to the vertical.

The thickness of masonry walls surrounding the smoke chamber shall be not less than 190 mm at the sides, front and back, except that the portions of the back exposed to the outside may be 140 mm thick.
Factory-built fireplaces and their installation shall conform to ulcs610.

Combustible material shall not be placed on or near the face of a fireplace within 150 mm of the fireplace opening, except that where the combustible material projects more than 38 mm out from the face of the fireplace above the opening, such material shall be not less than 300 mm above the top of the opening.

Metal exposed to the interior of a fireplace such as the damper control mechanism shall have not less than a 50 mm clearance from any combustible material on the face of the fireplace where such metal penetrates through the face of the fireplace.

Not less than a 100 mm clearance shall be provided between the back and sides of a fireplace and combustible framing, except that a 50 mm clearance is permitted where the fireplace is located in an exterior wall.

Not less than a 50 mm clearance shall be provided between the back and sides of the smoke chamber of a fireplace and combustible framing, except that a 25 mm clearance is permitted where the fireplace is located in an exterior wall.

The clearance of combustible material above heat-circulating duct outlets from those outlets shall be not less than 300 mm where the combustible material projects not less than 38 mm from the face, and 150 mm where the projection is less than 38 mm.
Fireplace inserts and hearth-mounted stoves vented through the throat of a fireplace shall conform to ulcs628.
The installation of fireplace inserts and hearth-mounted stoves vented through the throat of a fireplace shall conform to csab365.

This Section applies to constructions where wall, floor and roof planes are generally comprised of lumber frames of small repetitive structural members, or engineered components, and where roof and wall planes are clad, sheathed or braced on at least one side, the small repetitive structural members are spaced not more than 600 mm o.c., the constructions do not serve as foundations, the specified live load on supported subfloors and floor framing does not exceed 2.4 kPa, and the span of any structural member does not exceed 12.20 m. (See en001241.)
Where the conditions in es008420 are exceeded for wood constructions, the design of the framing and fastening shall conform to ep001024.3.1
All members shall be so framed, anchored, fastened, tied and braced to provide the necessary strength and rigidity.

Ends of wood joists, beams and other members framing into masonry or concrete shall be treated to prevent decay where the bottom of the member is at or below ground level, or a 12 mm air space shall be provided at the end and sides of the member.
Air spaces required in es002856 shall not be blocked by insulation, vapour barriers or airtight materials.

Except as permitted in es002859, wood framing members that are not pressure-treated with a wood preservative and that are supported on concrete in contact with the ground or fill shall be separated from the concrete by not less than 0.05 mm polyethylene film or Type S roll roofing.
Dampproofing material referred to in es002858 is not required where the wood member is at least 150 mm above the ground.

Except as provided in es013902, connectors in contact with preservative-treated wood shall be made of hot-dipped, zinc-coated galvanized steel with a coating weight not less than Z550 conforming to astma653m, a material that provides an equivalent level of corrosion protection to that provided by the material described in es013900a, or stainless steel.

Fasteners used to attach the connectors referred to in es013900 shall be made of galvanized steel coated with zinc in accordance with astma153m, or a material that provides an equivalent level of performance and is compatible with the connector.

Connectors and fasteners that are in contact with wood that has been treated with a disodium octaborate tetrahydrate (SBX (DOT)) or zinc borate preservative and is installed in a dry interior environment are permitted to be made of uncoated carbon steel. (See en001448.)
Lumber shall conform to ep001029.3.2
Except as provided in es008901 and unless otherwise indicated, nails specified in this Section shall be common steel wire nails or common spiral nails conforming to astmf1667, or csab111.
Nails used to comply with et000189 shall have a diameter not less than that stated in et000555 (See en000837.)
Wood screws specified in this Section shall conform to asmeb18.6.1.(See en000318.)
All nails shall be long enough so that not less than half their required length penetrates into the second member.
Splitting of wood members shall be minimized by staggering the nails in the direction of the grain and by keeping nails well in from the edges.(See en000319.)
Except as provided in es002866, nailing of framing shall conform to et000189

Where the bottom wall plate or sole plate of an exterior wall is not nailed to floor joists, rim joists or blocking in conformance with et000189, the exterior wall is permitted to be fastened to the floor framing by having plywood, OSB or waferboard sheathing extend down over floor framing and fastened to the floor framing by nails or staples conforming to ea001462, or tying the wall framing to the floor framing by galvanized-metal strips 50 mm wide, not less than 0.41 mm thick, spaced not more than 1.2 m apart, and fastened at each end with at least two 63 mm nails.

Where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 0.8 kPa, roof rafters, joists or trusses shall be tied to the wall framing with connectors that will resist a factored uplift load of 3 kN.
Galvanized-steel straps are deemed to comply with es016186, provided they are 50 mm wide, not less than 0.91 mm thick, and fastened at each end with at least four 63 mm nails.
Except as provided in Sentences es016188 to es016189, fastening of sheathing and subflooring shall conform to et000190.

Fastening of roof sheathing and sheathing in required braced wall panels shall conform to et001206, where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure (HWP) is equal to or greater than 0.8 kPa and less than 1.2 kPa and the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is not more than 0.90, or the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.70 and not more than 0.90.

Fastening of roof sheathing and sheathing in required braced wall panels shall conform to et000078, where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure (HWP) is equal to or greater than 0.8 kPa and less than 1.2 kPa and the spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is not more than 1.8, or the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.90 and not more than 1.8.

Fastening of sheathing shall conform to Part 4, where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 1.2 kPa, or for required braced wall panels, where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 1.8.
Staples shall not be less than 1.6 mm in diameter or thickness, with not less than a 9.5 mm crown driven with the crown parallel to framing.
Roofing nails for the attachment of fibreboard or gypsum sheathing shall not be less than 3.2 mm in diameter with a minimum head diameter of 11.1 mm.
Flooring screws shall not be less than 3.2 mm in diameter.

The edges of sheathing in a braced wall panel shall be supported and fastened to wood blocking where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 1.2, or the braced wall panel supports more than a roof of lightweight construction.

Spans provided in this Subsection for joists, beams and lintels supporting floors shall apply only where the floors serve residential areas as described in et001029, or the uniformly distributed live load on the floors does not exceed that specified for residential areas as described in et001029

Spans for joists, beams and lintels supporting floors shall be determined according to ep001024.1.3 where the supported floors serve other than residential areas, or support a uniform live load in excess of that specified for residential areas.

National Article Title: Spans for Joists, Rafters and Beams
National Sentence Text: Except as required in es002874 and ea001513, spans for wood joists and rafters shall conform to the spans shown in Span Tables et000234 to et000240 for the uniform live loads shown in the Tables. (See ea004693)

National Article Title: Spans for Joists, Rafters and Beams
National Sentence Text: Spans for floor joists that are not selected from Span Tables et000234 and et000235 and that are required to be designed for the same loading conditions, shall not exceed the design requirements for uniform loading and vibration criteria. (See en000321.)

National Article Title: Spans for Joists, Rafters and Beams
National Sentence Text: Spans for built-up wood and glued-laminated timber floor beams shall conform to the spans in Span Tables et001070 to et000244. (See ea004693)

National Article Title: Spans for Joists, Rafters and Beams
National Sentence Text: Spans for roof ridge beams shall conform to the spans in Span Table et001073 for the uniform snow load shown. (See Articles ea004693and ea001511)
The spans for steel floor beams with laterally supported top flanges shall conform to et000191 (See en000322.)
Beams described in es002877 shall at least meet the requirements for Grade 350 W steel contained in csag40.21.

Except as permitted in es002880, where a floor is required to support a concrete topping, the joist spans shown in Span Table et000234 or the spacing of the members shall be reduced to allow for the loads due to the topping.

Where a floor is required to support a concrete topping, joist spans are permitted to be selected from Span Table et000235 provided the concrete is 38 to 51 mm thick, is normal weight, is placed directly on the subflooring, and has not less than 20 MPa compressive strength after 28 days.

Where a floor is required to support a concrete topping not more than51 mm thick, the allowable beam spans shown in Span Tables et001070 to et000244 shall be multiplied by 0.8 or the supported length of the floor joists shall be reduced to allow for the loads due to the topping.

Where a roof is required to support an additional uniform dead load from roofing materials such as concrete roofing tile, or materials other than as specified in ep001029.26, such as clay roofing tiles, the additional load shall be allowed for by reducing the spans for roof joists and rafters in Span Tables et000237 to et000240, or the spacing of the members, and the spans for ridge beams and lintels in Span Tables et001073 and et001074 to et000253. (See en000320)

Holes drilled in roof, floor or ceiling framing members shall be not larger than one-quarter the depth of the member and shall be located not less than 50 mm from the edges, unless the depth of the member is increased by the size of the hole.

Floor, roof and ceiling framing members are permitted to be notched provided the notch is located on the top of the member within half the joist depth from the edge of bearing and is not deeper than one-third the joist depth, unless the depth of the member is increased by the size of the notch.

Wall studs shall not be notched, drilled or otherwise damaged so that the undamaged portion of the stud is less than two-thirds the depth of the stud if the stud is loadbearing or 40 mm if the stud is non-loadbearing, unless the weakened studs are suitably reinforced.
Top plates in walls shall not be notched, drilled or otherwise weakened to reduce the undamaged width to less than 50 mm unless the weakened plates are suitably reinforced.
Roof truss members shall not be notched, drilled or otherwise weakened unless such notching or drilling is allowed for in the design of the truss.

Except as required by es002892, building frames shall be anchored to the foundation unless a structural analysis that considers wind and earthquake loads and lateral earth pressures shows that anchorage is not required.

Except as provided in Sentences es016190 to es016191, anchorage shall be provided by embedding the ends of the first floor joists in concrete, or fastening the sill plate to the foundation with not less than 12.7 mm diam anchor bolts spaced not more than 2.4 m o.c.

For buildings with 2 or more floors supported by frame walls that are in areas where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is not greater than 0.70 or the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure (HWP) is equal to or greater than 0.80 kPa but not greater than 1.20 kPa, anchorage shall be provided by fastening the sill plate to the foundation with not less than two anchor bolts per braced wall panel, where all anchor bolts used are not less than 15.9 mm in diameter, located within 0.5 m of the end of the foundation, and spaced not more than 2.4 m o.c, or not less than 12.7 mm in diameter, located within 0.5 m of the end of the foundation, and spaced not more than 1.7 m o.c.

For buildings supported by frame walls that are in areas where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.70 but not greater than 1.8 and the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure (HWP) is not greater than 1.20 kPa, anchorage shall be provided by fastening the sill plate to the foundation with not less than two anchor bolts per braced wall panel located within 0.5 m of the end of the foundation and spaced in accordance with et000079

Anchor bolts referred to in Sentences es002889 to es007802 shall be fastened to the sill plate with nuts and washers, embedded not less than 100 mm in the foundation, and so designed that they may be tightened without withdrawing them from the foundation.
Where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 1.8 or the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 1.2 kPa, anchorage shall be designed according to Part 4.
Except as provided in Sentences es008423 and es008424, exterior columns and posts shall be anchored to resist uplift and lateral movement.

Except as provided in es008424, where columns or posts support balconies, decks, verandas or other exterior platforms, and the distance from finished ground to the underside of the joists is not more than 600 mm, the columns or posts shall be anchored to the foundation to resist uplift and lateral movement, or the supported joists or beams shall be directly anchored to the ground to resist uplift.

Anchorage is not required for platforms described in es008423 that are not more than 1 storey in height, are not more than 55 m2 in area, do not support a roof, and are not attached to another structure, unless it can be demonstrated that differential movement will not adversely affect the performance of the structure to which the platform is attached.

Buildings not more than 4.3 m wide and not more than 1 storey in building height that are not anchored in accordance with es002888 shall be anchored in conformance with the requirements of csaz240.10.1.
Where sill plates provide bearing for the floor system, they shall be not less than 38 mm by 89 mm material.

National Article Title: Levelling and Sealing of Sill Plates
National Sentence Text: Sill plates shall be levelled by setting them on a full bed of mortar, or laid directly on the foundation if the top of the foundation is level. (See also ea001456)

National Article Title: Levelling and Sealing of Sill Plates
National Sentence Text: The joint between the sill plate for exterior walls and the foundation shall be sealed in accordance with ep001029.25.3
Beams shall have even and level bearing and the bearing at end supports shall be not less than 89 mm long, except as stated in the notes to Span Tables et001070 to et000244.
Exterior steel beams shall be shop primed.
Where a beam is made up of individual pieces of lumber that are nailed together, the individual members shall be 38 mm or greater in thickness and installed on edge.
Except as permitted in es002899, where individual members of a built-up beam are butted together to form a joint, the joint shall occur over a support.

Where a beam is continuous over more than one span, individual members are permitted to be butted together to form a joint at or within 150 mm of the end quarter points of the clear spans, provided the quarter points are not those closest to the ends of the beam.
Members joined at quarter points shall be continuous over adjacent supports.

Joints in individual members of a beam that are located at or near the end quarter points shall not occur in adjacent members at the same quarter point and shall not reduce the effective beam width by more than half.
Not more than one butt joint shall occur in any individual member of a built-up beam within any one span.

Except as provided in es002904, where 38 mm members are laid on edge to form a built-up beam, individual members shall be nailed together with a double row of nails not less than 89 mm in length, spaced not more than 450 mm apart in each row with the end nails located 100 mm to 150 mm from the end of each piece.

Where 38 mm members in built-up wood beams are not nailed together as provided in es002903, they shall be bolted together with not less than 12.7 mm diam bolts equipped with washers and spaced not more than 1.2 m o.c., with the end bolts located not more than 600 mm from the ends of the members.
Except when supported on ribbon boards, floor joists shall have not less than 38 mm length of end bearing.
Ribbon boards referred to in es002905 shall be not less than 19 mm by 89 mm lumber let into the studs.
Floor joists may be supported on the tops of beams or may be framed into the sides of beams.

When framed into the side of a wood beam, joists referred to in es002907 shall be supported on joist hangers or other acceptable mechanical connectors, or not less than 38 mm by 64 mm ledger strips nailed to the side of the beam, except that 38 mm by 38 mm ledger strips may be used provided each joist is nailed to the beam by not less than four 89 mm nails, in addition to the nailing for the ledger strip required in et000189

When framed into the side of a steel beam, joists referred to in es002907 shall be supported on the bottom flange of the beam or on not less than 38 mm by 38 mm lumber bolted to the web with not less than 6.3 mm diam bolts spaced not more than 600 mm apart.
Joists referred to in es002909 shall be spliced above the beam with not less than 38 mm by 38 mm lumber at least 600 mm long to support the flooring.
Not less than a 12 mm space shall be provided between the splice required in es002910 and the beam to allow for shrinkage of the wood joists.

Except as provided in es002914, bottoms of floor joists shall be restrained from twisting at each end by toe-nailing to the supports, end-nailing to the header joists or by providing continuous strapping, blocking between the joists or cross-bridging near the supports.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Except as permitted by es002917, where strapping is specified in Span Table et000234, it shall be not less than 19 mm by 64 mm, nailed to the underside of floor joists, located not more than 2 100 mm from each support or other rows of strapping, and fastened at each end to a sill or header.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Where bridging is specified in Span Table et000234, it shall consist of not less than 19 mm by 64 mm or 38 mm by 38 mm cross bridging located not more than 2 100 mm from each support or other rows of bridging.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Where bridging and strapping are specified in Span Table et000234, bridging shall comply with es002915, or consist of 38 mm solid blocking located not more than 2 100 mm from each support or other rows of bridging and securely fastened between the joists, and except as provided in es002917, strapping shall comply with es002914 and be installed under the bridging.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Bridging specified in Span Table et000235 shall consist of bridging as described in es002915, or 38 mm solid blocking located not more than 2 100 mm from each support or other rows of bridging and securely fastened between the joists.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Strapping described in es002914 and es002916b is not required where furring strips complying with et000213 are fastened directly to the joists, or a panel-type ceiling finish complying with ep001029.29.5, ep001029.29.6, ep001029.29.7, ep001029.29.8, or ep001029.29.9 is attached directly to the joists.

National Article Title: Strapping, Bridging, Furring and Ceilings in Span Tables 9.23.4.2.-A and -B
National Sentence Text: Where a ceiling attached to wood furring is specified in Span Table et000235, the ceiling finish shall consist of gypsum board, plywood or OSB not less than 12.7 mm thick, and the furring shall be 19 mm by 89 mm wood furring spaced at not more than 600 mm o.c., or 19 mm by 64 mm wood furring spaced at not more than 400 mm o.c.
Header joists around floor openings shall be doubled when they exceed 1.2 m in length.
The size of header joists exceeding 3.2 m in length shall be determined by calculations.
Trimmer joists around floor openings shall be doubled when the length of the header joist exceeds 800 mm.
When the header joist exceeds 2 m in length the size of the trimmer joists shall be determined by calculations.

National Article Title: Support of Tail and Header Joists
National Sentence Text: When tail joists and header joists are supported by the floor framing, they shall be supported by suitable joist hangers or nailing in accordance with et000189
Non-loadbearing walls parallel to the floor joists shall be supported by joists beneath the wall or on blocking between the joists.

Blocking referred to in es002924 for the support of non-loadbearing walls shall be not less than 38 mm by 89 mm lumber, and except as required for the fastening of walls constructed with required braced wall panels, spaced not more than 1.2 m apart.
Except as provided in es016076, non-loadbearing interior walls at right angles to the floor joists are not restricted as to location.
Loadbearing interior walls parallel to floor joists shall be supported by beams or walls of sufficient strength to safely transfer the specified live loads to the vertical supports.

Unless the joist size is designed to support such loads, loadbearing interior walls at right angles to floor joists shall be located not more than 900 mm from the joist support where the wall does not support a floor, and not more than 600 mm from the joist support where the wall supports one or more floors.

Loadbearing and non-loadbearing walls constructed with required braced wall panels shall be continuously supported by floor joists, blocking or rim joists to allow for the required fastening (see et000189).

Floor joists supporting roof loads shall not be cantilevered more than 400 mm beyond their supports where 38 mm by 184 mm joists are used and not more than 600 mm beyond their supports where 38 mm by 235 mm or larger joists are used.

The cantilevered portions referred to in es002929 shall not support floor loads from other storeys unless calculations are provided to show that the design resistances of the cantilevered joists are not exceeded.

Where cantilevered floor joists described in Sentences es002929 and es002930 are at right angles to the main floor joists, the tail joists in the cantilevered portion shall extend inward away from the cantilever support a distance equal to not less than 6 times the length of the cantilever, and shall be end nailed to an interior doubled header joist in conformance with et000189
The size and spacing of studs shall conform to et000192
Where loadbearing interior walls are not finished in accordance with ep001029.29, blocking or strapping shall be fastened to the studs at mid-height to prevent sideways buckling.
Except as permitted in Sentences es002939 and es002940, all studs shall be placed at right angles to the wall face.
Studs on the flat are permitted to be used in gable ends of roofs that contain only unfinished space or in non-loadbearing interior walls within the limits described in ea001491

Wall studs that support only a load from an attic not accessible by a stairway are permitted to be placed on the flat within the limits permitted in ea001491 provided the studs are clad on not less than one side with plywood, OSB or waferboard sheathing fastened to the face of the studs with a structural adhesive, and the portion of the roof supported by the studs does not exceed 2.1 m in width.
Wall studs shall be continuous for the full storey height except at openings and shall not be spliced except by fingerjoining with a structural adhesive. (See en000327.)

National Article Title: Support for Cladding, Sheathing and Finishing Materials
National Sentence Text: Corners and intersections shall be designed to provide adequate support for the vertical edges of interior finishes, sheathing and cladding materials, and in no instance shall exterior corners be framed with less than the equivalent of 2 studs.

National Article Title: Support for Cladding, Sheathing and Finishing Materials
National Sentence Text: Where the vertical edges of interior finishes at wall intersections are supported at vertical intervals by blocking or furring, the vertical distance between such supports shall not exceed the maximum distance between supports specified in ep001029.29

Where the lintel spanning the opening is more than 3 m long, studs shall be tripled on each side of the opening so that the two inner studs on each side extend from the bottom of the supported lintel to the top of the bottom wall plate, and the outer stud on each side extends from the bottom of the top wall plate to the bottom wall plate.

Except as provided in es002945, where the lintel spanning the opening is not more than 3 m long, studs shall be doubled on each side of the opening so that the inner studs on each side extend from the bottom of the supported lintel to the top of the bottom wall plate, and the outer stud on each side extends from the bottom of the top wall plate to the bottom wall plate.

Single studs are permitted to be used on either side of openings in non-loadbearing interior walls not required to have fire-resistance ratings, provided the studs extend from the top wall plate to the bottom wall plate, or in loadbearing or non-loadbearing interior or exterior walls, provided the opening is less than and within the required stud spacing, and no 2 such openings of full stud-space width are located in adjacent stud spaces. (See en000328.)
Except as provided in es002947, wall plates shall be not less than 38 mm thick, and not less than the required width of the wall studs.
In non-loadbearing walls and in loadbearing walls where the studs are located directly over framing members, the bottom wall plate is permitted to be 19 mm thick.
A bottom wall plate shall be provided in all cases.
The bottom plate in exterior walls shall not project more than one-third the plate width over the support.
Except as permitted in Sentences es002951 to es002953, at least 2 top plates shall be provided in loadbearing walls.
A single top plate is permitted to be used in a section of a loadbearing wall containing a lintel provided the top plate forms a tie across the lintel.

A single top plate is permitted to be used in loadbearing walls where the concentrated loads from ceilings, floors and roofs are not more than 50 mm to one side of the supporting studs and in all non-loadbearing walls.

The top plates need not be provided in a section of loadbearing wall containing a lintel provided the lintel is tied to the adjacent wall section with not less than 75 mm by 150 mm by 0.91 mm thick galvanized steel, or 19 mm by 89 mm by 300 mm wood splice nailed to each wall section with at least three 63 mm nails.
Joints in the top plates of loadbearing walls shall be staggered not less than one stud spacing.
The top plates in loadbearing walls shall be lapped or otherwise tied at corners and intersecting walls in accordance with es002957.
Joints in single top plates used with loadbearing walls shall be tied in accordance with es002957.
Ties referred to in Sentences es002955 and es002956 shall be the equivalent of not less than 75 mm by 150 mm by 0.91 mm thick galvanized steel nailed to each wall with at least three 63 mm nails.

Where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.70 but not more than 1.8, doubled top plates in braced wall bands shall be fastened on each side of a splice with 76 mm long common steel wire nails or spiral nails in accordance with et000080
Except as provided in es002959, openings in non-loadbearing walls shall be framed with not less than 38 mm material the same width as the studs, securely nailed to adjacent studs.

Openings for doors in non-loadbearing walls required to be fire separations with a fire-resistance rating shall be framed with the equivalent of at least two 38 mm thick members that are the same width as the wall plates.
Openings in loadbearing walls greater than the required stud spacing shall be framed with lintels designed to carry the superimposed loads to adjacent studs. (See en000328.)

Except as provided in es002964, where 2 or more members are used in lintels, they shall be fastened together with not less than 82 mm nails in a double row, with nails not more than 450 mm apart in each row.
Lintel members are permitted to be separated by filler pieces.

Spans and sizes of wood lintels shall conform to the spans shown in Span Tables et001073 and et001074 to et000253 for buildings of residential occupancy, where the wall studs exceed 38 mm by 64 mm in size, where the spans of supported joists do not exceed 4.9 m, and where the spans of trusses do not exceed 9.8 m.

In loadbearing exterior and interior walls of 38 mm by 64 mm framing members, lintels shall consist of 64 mm thick members on edge, or 38 mm thick and 19 mm thick members fastened together with a double row of nails not less than 63 mm long and spaced not more than 450 mm apart.

Lintels referred to in es002964 shall be not less than 50 mm greater in depth than those shown in Span Tables et001073 and et001074 to et000253 for the maximum spans shown, and shall not exceed 2.24 m in length.

National Article Title: Requirements for Low to Moderate Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: This Article applies in locations where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is not more than 0.70 and the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is less than 0.80 kPa.

National Article Title: Requirements for Low to Moderate Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: Bracing to resist lateral loads shall be designed and constructed as follows: exterior walls shall be clad with panel-type cladding in accordance with ep001029.27, sheathed with plywood, OSB, waferboard, fibreboard, gypsum board or diagonal lumber sheathing complying with ep001029.23.16 and fastened in accordance with et000190, or finished on the interior with a panel-type material in accordance with the requirements of ep001029.29, or in accordance with Articles ea005085 to ea005088, Part 4, or good engineering practice such as that provided in cwc-egwfc.

National Article Title: Requirements for High Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in ea005082, this Article applies in locations where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.70 but not more than 1.8 and the lowest exterior frame wall supports not more than 1 floor in buildings of heavy construction (see en000707), or the lowest exterior frame wall supports not more than 2 floors in other types of construction, and the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is less than 1.20 kPa.

National Article Title: Requirements for High Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: Bracing to resist lateral loads shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Articles ea005085 to ea005088, Part 4, or good engineering practice such as that provided in cwc-egwfc.

National Article Title: Requirements for Extreme Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Articles ea005082 and ea005083, this Article applies in locations where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 1.8, greater than 0.70 and the lowest exterior frame wall supports more than 2 floors in buildings of light construction, or greater than 0.70 and the lowest exterior frame wall supports more than 1 floor in buildings of heavy construction, or the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 1.20 kPa.

National Article Title: Requirements for Extreme Wind and Seismic Forces
National Sentence Text: Bracing to resist lateral loads shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Part 4, or good engineering practice such as that provided in cwc-egwfc.

Braced wall bands shall be full storey height, be not more than 1.2 m wide, lap at both ends with another braced wall band, be aligned with braced wall bands on storeys above and below, and conform to the spacing and dimensions given in et001209
The perimeter of the building shall be located within braced wall bands.
For split-level buildings, a braced wall band shall be located where there is a change in floor level greater than the depth of one floor joist.

National Article Title: Braced Wall Panels in Braced Wall Bands
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences es016210 to es016213 and ea005088, braced wall panels shall be located within braced wall bands, extend, as applicable, from the top of the supporting footing, slab or subfloor to the underside of the floor, ceiling or roof framing above, and conform to the spacing and dimensions given in et001209

National Article Title: Braced Wall Panels in Braced Wall Bands
National Sentence Text: In basements or crawl spaces where the perimeter foundation walls extend from the footings to the underside of the supported floor, braced wall bands constructed with braced wall panels shall be spaced not more than 15 m from the perimeter foundation walls, 15 m from interior foundation walls, and 15 m from adjacent braced wall bands constructed with braced wall panels. (See en001523.)

National Article Title: Braced Wall Panels in Braced Wall Bands
National Sentence Text: Portions of the perimeter of a single open or enclosed space need not comply with es016209, where the roof of the space projects not more than 3.5 m from the face of the framing of the nearest parallel braced wall band, and the perpendicular plan dimension, that portion of the perimeter structure does not support a floor, the roof of the space is integral with the roof of the rest of the building with framing members not more than 400 mm o.c. where roof sheathing edges are not supported on blocking and not more than 600 mm o.c. where roof sheathing edges are supported on blocking securely fastened between framing members, or constructed with roof framing not more than 400 mm o.c. where roof sheathing edges are not supported on blocking and not more than 600 mm o.c. where roof sheathing edges are supported on blocking securely fastened between framing members, and fastened to the wall framing (see et000189 and ea001481 for balloon framing), and the end-joists or end-rafters for the roof of the space are fastened to a 3-ply, 38 mm × 140 mm built-up column or a 5-ply, 38 mm × 89 mm built-up column that is integral with the wall framing. (See en001562.)

National Article Title: Braced Wall Panels in Braced Wall Bands
National Sentence Text: Walls in detached garages and in accessory buildings serving a single dwelling unit, and the front wall of attached garages serving a single dwelling unit need not comply with es016209 where these walls do not support a floor.

National Article Title: Braced Wall Panels in Braced Wall Bands
National Sentence Text: Braced wall panels in the braced wall band at the front of an attached garage serving a single dwelling unit need not comply with es016209, provided the maximum spacing between the front of the garage and the back wall of the garage does not exceed 7.6 m, there is not more than one floor above the garage, not less than 50% of the length of the back wall of the garage is constructed of braced wall panels, and not less than 25% of the length of the side walls is constructed of braced wall panels.

Required braced wall panels shall be clad with panel-type cladding complying with ep001029.27 and et000189, sheathed with plywood, OSB, waferboard or diagonal lumber sheathing complying with ep001029.23.15 and et001210, and fastened in accordance with ea001462, or finished on the interior with a panel-type material in accordance with the requirements of ep001029.29 and et001210
Except as provided in es016216, required interior braced wall panels shall be sheathed or finished on both sides with a wood-based material, or finished on both sides with gypsum board.

Required interior braced wall panels of wood-based material may be sheathed on one side only, provided the sheathing material is plywood, OSB or waferboard, and the maximum spacing of fasteners along the edge is half of the maximum spacing shown in et001206.

For stacked braced wall bands, where the construction of any one braced wall panel is required to be of a wood-based material, a wood-based material shall be installed in all the required braced wall panels in that braced wall band.
Gypsum board interior finish shall not be considered as an acceptable sheathing material to provide the required bracing in exterior walls. (See en001554.)
At braced wall band spacing intervals of not more than 15 m, braced wall panels shall be constructed with OSB, plywood or diagonal lumber. (See en001554.)

Except as provided in Sentences es016221 and es016222, one exterior wall of the uppermost storey in each orthogonal direction may be set back from the exterior wall of the storey below, provided the adjacent interior braced wall band of the storey below the setback is spaced not more than 10.6 m from the exterior wall of the storey below the setback wall, consists of braced wall panels that are constructed of a wood-based material in conformance with es016215, extends to the foundation, and is not taken into consideration when providing braced wall panels constructed of a wood-based material at spacing intervals of not more than 15 m as per es016219.

Where the exterior wall of the uppermost storey is set back from the exterior wall of the storey below, the roof and floor space supporting the setback wall shall be sheathed with a wood-based material between the exterior wall of the storey below the setback and the adjacent interior braced wall bands of the storey below the setback.

Where the exterior wall of the uppermost storey is set back from the exterior wall of the storey below, the exterior walls perpendicular to the setback wall shall have their top plate connected with nails that are spaced at no greater than half the spacing required in et000189, and have their top plate splices fastened with twice the number of nails specified in Sentences es002957 and es007805.

The maximum distance between adjacent required braced wall panels in a braced wall band, measured from the edge of the panels, may be increased to 7.3 m provided that, throughout the height of the building, the length of any braced wall panel within the braced wall band is not less than 1.2 m.

The maximum spacing between the centre lines of required braced wall bands given in et001209 may be increased from 7.6 m to no more than 10.6 m, provided that the interior braced wall band whose spacing is being increased is replaced with an interior braced wall band that consists of braced wall panels that are constructed of a wood-based material in conformance with es016215, extends to the foundation, and is not taken into consideration when providing braced wall panels constructed of a wood-based material at spacing intervals no greater than 15 m as per es016219.

For each orthogonal direction of the building, the length of required braced wall panels of one exterior wall given in et001209 may be reduced from 40% to no less than 25% of the length of the braced wall band, provided an additional parallel and adjacent interior braced wall band is constructed that is spaced not more than 10.6 m from the exterior wall, consists of braced wall panels that are constructed of a wood-based material in conformance with es016215 and whose lengths sum to no less than 25% of the length of the braced wall band, extends to the foundation, and is not taken into consideration when providing braced wall panels constructed of a wood-based material at spacing intervals no greater than 15 m as per es016219.

Where the length of required braced wall panels of an exterior wall is reduced as described in es016225, the ratio of the length of braced wall panels in the respective upper braced wall bands to the length of braced wall panels in the reduced exterior braced wall band shall not exceed 2.
Roof rafters and joists and ceiling joists shall be continuous or shall be spliced over vertical supports that extend to suitable bearing.
Roof and ceiling framing members shall be doubled on each side of openings greater than 2 rafter or joist spacings wide.
The length of end bearing of joists and rafters shall be not less than 38 mm.
Rafters shall be located directly opposite each other and tied together at the peak, or may be offset by their own thickness if nailed to a ridge board not less than 17.5 mm thick.
Except as permitted in es002971, framing members shall be connected by gusset plates or nailing at the peak in conformance with et000189

Where the roof framing on opposite sides of the peak is assembled separately, such as in the case of factory-built houses, the roof framing on opposite sides is permitted to be fastened together with galvanized-steel strips not less than 200 mm by 75 mm by 0.41 mm thick spaced not more than 1.2 m apart and nailed at each end to the framing by at least two 63 mm nails.
Rafters shall be shaped at supports to provide even bearing surfaces and supported directly above the exterior walls.
Hip and valley rafters shall be not less than 50 mm greater in depth than the common rafters and not less than 38 mm thick, actual dimension.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: Ceiling joists and collar ties of not less than 38 mm by 89 mm lumber are permitted to be assumed to provide intermediate support to reduce the span for rafters and joists where the roof slope is 1 in 3 or greater.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: Collar ties referred to in es002974 more than 2.4 m long shall be laterally supported near their centres by not less than 19 mm by 89 mm continuous members at right angles to the collar ties.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: Dwarf walls and struts are permitted to be used to provide intermediate support to reduce the span for rafters and joists.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: When struts are used to provide intermediate support they shall be not less than 38 mm by 89 mm material extending from each rafter to a loadbearing wall at an angle of not less than 45° to the horizontal.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: When dwarf walls are used for rafter support, they shall be framed in the same manner as loadbearing walls and securely fastened top and bottom to the roof and ceiling framing to prevent over-all movement.

National Article Title: Intermediate Support for Rafters and Joists
National Sentence Text: Solid blocking shall be installed between floor joists beneath dwarf walls referred to in es002978 that enclose finished rooms.

Except as provided in es002983, roof rafters and joists shall be supported at the ridge of the roof by a loadbearing wall extending from the ridge to suitable bearing, or a ridge beam supported by not less than 89 mm length of bearing.

Except as provided in es002982, the ridge beam referred to in es002980 shall conform to the sizes and spans shown in Span Table et001073, provided the supported rafter or joist length does not exceed 4.9 m, and the roof does not support any concentrated loads.

The ridge beam referred to in es002980 need not comply with es002981 where the beam is of not less than 38 mm by 140 mm material, and the beam is supported at intervals not exceeding 1.2 m by not less than 38 mm by 89 mm members extending vertically from the ridge to suitable bearing.
Where the roof slope is 1 in 3 or steeper, ridge support need not be provided when the lower ends of the rafters are adequately tied to prevent outward movement.
Ties required in es002983 are permitted to consist of tie rods or ceiling joists forming a continuous tie for opposing rafters and nailed in accordance with et000193
Except as permitted in es008978, ceiling joists referred to in es002984 shall be tied to the base of every rafter.

Where ceiling joists referred to in es002984 are raised above the base of the rafters, the connections between the rafters and the ceiling joists shall be designed in accordance with es008085b or es008085c.

Ceiling joists referred to in es002984 that are spliced to make a continuous joist shall be fastened together at each splice with at least one more nail than required for the rafter-to-joist connection shown in et000193
Members referred to in Sentences es008977 and es002985 are permitted to be fastened together either directly or through a gusset plate.

Roof joists supporting a finished ceiling, other than plywood, OSB or waferboard, shall be restrained from twisting along the bottom edges by means of furring, blocking, cross bridging or strapping conforming to ea001483

Except as permitted in es002989, ceiling joists supporting part of the roof load from the rafters shall be not less than 25 mm greater in depth than required for ceiling joists not supporting part of the roof load.
When the roof slope is 1 in 4 or less, the ceiling joist sizes referred to in es002988 shall be determined from Span Tables et000236 to et000239 and et001073 for roof joists.
Wood roof trusses shall be designed in accordance with good engineering practice such as that described in tpic_tdps.
The joint connections used in trusses described in es002990 shall be designed in conformance with the requirements in ep001024.3.1 (See en000329.)

All member bracing shall be installed as per the truss design drawings, and continuous lateral bracing shall be adequately anchored to the roof and ceiling diaphragms at intervals no greater than 6.10 m o.c.
Subflooring shall be provided beneath finish flooring where the finish flooring does not have adequate strength to support the specified live loads (see ep001029.30.3).
Except as provided in es002998, wood-based panels for subfloors shall conform to csao121 csao151 csao153 csao325, or csao437.0.
Particleboard subflooring may be used only where a building is constructed in a factory so that the subfloor will not be exposed to the weather.
Subflooring described in es002998 shall conform to grade D-2 or D-3 in ansia208.1.

Subflooring described in es002998 shall have its upper surface and all edges treated to restrict water absorption, where the subfloor is used in bathrooms, kitchens, laundry rooms or other areas subject to periodic wetting. (See en000330.)

Where the edges of panel-type subflooring are required to be supported (see es003441), such support shall consist of tongue-and-groove panel edges or not less than 38 mm by 38 mm blocking securely nailed between framing members.
Plywood subflooring shall be installed with the surface grain at right angles to the joists and with joints parallel to floor joists staggered.

OSB subflooring conforming to csao325, or to O-1 and O-2 grades in csao437.0, and waferboard subflooring conforming to R-1 grade in csao437.0 shall be installed so that the direction of face orientation is at right angles to the joists and the joints parallel to the floor joists are staggered. (See en000331.)
Except as provided in Sentences es008435 and es008436, subfloors shall conform to either et000195 or et000196.

Where the finished flooring consists of not less than 19 mm matched wood strip flooring laid at right angles to joists spaced not more than 600 mm o.c., subflooring shall be permitted to consist of not less than 12.5 mm thick plywood, 12.5 mm thick OSB conforming to O-2 grade, 12.7 mm thick OSB conforming to O-1 grade, 12.7 mm thick waferboard conforming to R-1 grade, or OSB conforming to 2R32/2F16 grade.
