Except where the flooring consists of ceramic tiles applied with adhesive, where a separate panel-type underlay or concrete topping is applied to a subfloor on joists spaced not more than 400 mm o.c., the subfloor is permitted to consist of not less than 12.5 mm thick plywood, 12.5 mm thick OSB conforming to O-2 grade, 12.7 mm thick OSB conforming to O-1 grade, 12.7 mm thick waferboard conforming to R-1 grade, or OSB conforming to 2R32/2F16 grade.
When resilient flooring is applied directly to an OSB, waferboard, particleboard or plywood subfloor, the subfloor shall be fastened to the supports with annular grooved nails.
Lumber subflooring shall be laid at an angle of not less than 45° to the joists.
Lumber subflooring shall be fully supported at the ends on solid bearing.
Lumber for subflooring shall be of uniform thickness and not more than 184 mm wide.

Except where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is less than0.8 kPa and the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is less than or equal to 0.70, continuous lumber or panel-type roof sheathing shall be installed to support the roofing.
Wood-based panels used for roof sheathing shall conform to the requirements of csao121 csao151 csao153 csao325, or csao437.0.
Plywood roof sheathing shall be installed with the surface grain at right angles to the roof framing.

OSB roof sheathing conforming to csao325, or to O-1 and O-2 grades as specified in csao437.0, shall be installed with the direction of face orientation at right angles to the roof framing members. (See en000331.)

Panel-type sheathing board shall be applied so that joints perpendicular to the roof ridge are staggered where the sheathing is applied with the surface grain parallel to the roof ridge, and the thickness of the sheathing is such that the edges are required to be supported.
A gap of not less than 2 mm shall be left between sheets of plywood, OSB or waferboard.
Lumber roof sheathing shall not be more than 286 mm wide and shall be applied so that all ends are supported with end joints staggered.

Lumber roof sheathing shall be installed diagonally, where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 0.70 but not greater than 1.2, or the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 0.80 kPa but less than 1.20 kPa.

Lumber roof sheathing shall be designed according to Part 4, where the seismic spectral acceleration, Sa(0.2), is greater than 1.2, or the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure is equal to or greater than 1.20 kPa.
Where panel-type roof sheathing requires edge support, the support shall consist of metal H clips or not less than 38 mm by 38 mm blocking securely nailed between framing members.
The thickness or rating of roof sheathing on a flat roof used as a walking deck shall conform to either et000195 or et000196 for subfloors.
The thickness or rating of roof sheathing on a roof not used as a walking deck shall conform to either et000197 or et000198.

Asphalt-coated or asphalt-impregnated fibreboard not less than 11.1 mm thick conforming to ulcs706 is permitted to be used as a roof sheathing over supports spaced not more than 400 mm o.c. provided the roofing consists of a continuous sheet of galvanized steel not less than 0.33 mm in thickness, or a continuous sheet of aluminum not less than 0.61 mm in thickness.
All edges of sheathing described in es003020 shall be supported by blocking or framing.
Exterior walls and gable ends shall be sheathed when the exterior cladding requires intermediate fastening between supports or if the exterior cladding requires solid backing.
Where wall sheathing is required for the purpose of complying with this Section, it shall conform to either et001065 or et000200. (See also ea004854)
Gypsum sheathing, rigid insulation and fibreboard shall not be used for the attachment of cladding materials.
Lumber wall sheathing shall be applied so that all ends are supported.
Where lumber wall sheathing is required to provide bracing according to ea001492, it shall be applied with end joints staggered.
A gap of not less than 2 mm shall be left between sheets of plywood, OSB, waferboard or fibreboard.

Where the bottom portions of mansard style roofs are vented, the vertical framing members behind the sloping portions shall be considered on the same basis as exterior wall studs and shall conform to Articles ea004870 to ea004874
This Section applies to sheet steel studs for use in non-loadbearing exterior and interior walls.
Where loadbearing steel studs are used, they shall be designed in conformance with ep001024.
Steel studs and runners shall conform to aisis201.
Metal thickness specified in this Section shall be the minimum base steel thickness exclusive of coatings.
Screws for the application of cladding, sheathing or interior finish materials to steel studs, runners and furring channels shall conform to astmc954 or astmc1002.

National Article Title: Cladding, Sheathing and Interior Finish Required
National Sentence Text: Cladding or sheathing, and interior finish shall be installed on steel stud framing and shall be fastened with screws spaced at the appropriate spacing described in ep001029.29, and penetrating not less than 10 mm through the metal.

National Article Title: Size and Spacing of Studs in Interior Walls
National Sentence Text: Except as required in Articles ea001547 and ea001548, the size and spacing of steel studs for non-loadbearing interior walls shall conform to et000201
Except as required in ea001548, steel studs in non-loadbearing interior walls shall have a metal thickness of not less than 0.46 mm.
Runners for interior and exterior non-loadbearing walls shall have a thickness not less than the thickness of the corresponding studs and shall have not less than 30 mm flanges.

Where openings for doors in non-loadbearing fire separations required to have a fire-resistance rating do not exceed 1 200 mm in width, the width of steel studs shall be not less than 63 mm, and the metal thickness shall be not less than 0.46 mm.
Where openings described in es003052 exceed 1 200 mm in width, the width of steel studs shall be not less than 91 mm, and the metal thickness shall be not less than 0.85 mm.
The distance to the first stud beyond the jamb of any door opening in a fire separation required to have a fire-resistance rating shall not exceed 400 mm.

Where the distance between the framing over the opening referred to in es003054 and the top runner exceeds 400 mm in such walls, intermediate support shall be installed at intervals of not more than 400 mm above the opening.

National Article Title: Size and Spacing of Studs in Exterior Walls
National Sentence Text: The size and spacing of non-loadbearing steel studs for exterior walls shall conform to et000202
Runners shall be provided at the tops and bottoms of walls.

Runners required in es003057 shall be securely attached to the building at approximately 50 mm from the ends, and at intervals of not more than 600 mm o.c. for interior walls and 300 mm o.c. for exterior walls.
Fasteners used for attachment described in es003058 shall consist of the equivalent of 63 mm nails or 25 mm screws.
Studs at openings and which are not full wall height shall be supported by a runner at the ends of the studs, securely fastened to the full length studs at the sides of the opening.

Steel studs used in walls required to have a fire-resistance rating shall be installed so that there is not less than a 12 mm clearance between the top of the stud and the top of the runner to allow for expansion in the event of fire.
Except as provided in ea001555, studs in walls referred to in es003061 shall not be attached to the runners in a manner that will prevent such expansion.
Framing above doors with steel door frames in non-loadbearing fire separations required to have a fire-resistance rating shall consist of 2 runners on the flat fastened back to back. (See en000336.)
The upper runner required in es003063 shall be bent at each end to extend upwards not less than 150 mm and fastened to the adjacent studs.
A gypsum board filler piece, the width and length of the runner, shall be provided between the door frame referred to in es003063 and the adjacent runner.
Steel studs shall be installed with webs at right angles to the wall face and, except at openings, shall be continuous for the full wall height.
Corners and intersections of walls shall be constructed to provide support for the cladding materials.
Studs shall be doubled on each side of every opening where such openings involve more than one stud space, and shall be tripled where the openings in exterior walls exceed 2.4 m in width.
Studs described in es003068 shall be fastened together by screws, crimping or welding to act as a single structural unit in resisting transverse loads.
Studs shall be attached to runners by screws, crimping or welding around wall openings and elsewhere where necessary to keep the studs in alignment during construction.
Where clearance for expansion is required in ea001551, attachment required in es003070 shall be applied between studs and bottom runners only.
Openings for fire dampers in non-loadbearing fire separations required to have a fire-resistance rating shall be framed with double studs on each side of the opening.

The sill and header for openings described in es003072 shall consist of a runner track with right angle bends made on each end so as to extend 300 mm above the header or below the sill and fastened to the studs.
The openings described in es003072 shall be lined with a layer of gypsum board not less than 12.7 mm thick fastened to stud and runner webs.
This Section is concerned with heat, air and water vapour transfer and measures to control condensation.

All walls, ceilings and floors separating conditioned space from unconditioned space, the exterior air or the ground shall be provided with thermal insulation conforming to ep001029.25.2 and ep001029.37, an air barrier conforming to ep001029.25.3 and ep001029.37, and a vapour barrier conforming to ep001029.25.4, and constructed in such a way that the properties and relative position of all materials conform to ep001029.25.5 (See en000996.)
Insulation and sealing of heating and ventilating ducts shall conform to Sections ep001029.32, ep001029.33and ep001029.37

All walls, ceilings and floors separating heated space from unheated space, the exterior air or the exterior soil shall be provided with sufficient thermal insulation to prevent moisture condensation on their room side during the winter and to ensure comfortable conditions for the occupants. (See en000253.)
Except as required in es003081, thermal insulation shall conform to the requirements of astmc726 cgsb-51.25 cgsb51-gp-27m ulcs701 ulcs702, ulcs703 ulcs704, ulcs705.1 or ulcs706.
The flame-spread ratings requirements contained in the standards listed in es003080 shall not apply. (See en000338.)
Insulation in contact with the ground shall be inert to the action of soil and water and shall be such that its insulative properties are not significantly reduced by moisture.
Insulation shall be installed so that there is a reasonably uniform insulating value over the entire face of the insulated area.
Insulation shall be applied to the full width and length of the space between furring or framing.

Except where the insulation provides the principal resistance to air leakage, thermal insulation shall be installed so that at least one face is in full and continuous contact with an element with low air permeance. (See en000339.)
Insulation shall be installed over the full height of foundation walls enclosing a basement or heated crawl space. (See also en001746.)

Insulation around concrete slabs-on-ground shall be located so that heat from the building is not restricted from reaching the ground beneath the perimeter, where exterior walls are not supported by footings extending below frost level.

Where insulation is exposed to the weather and subject to mechanical damage, it shall be protected with not less than 6 mm preservative-treated plywood, or 12 mm cement parging on wire lath applied to the exposed face and edge.
Insulation located in areas where it may be subject to mechanical damage shall be protected by a covering such as gypsum board, plywood, particleboard, OSB, waferboard or hardboard.
Insulation in factory-built buildings shall be installed so that it will not become dislodged during transportation.
Except as provided in Sentences es003093 to es003097, loose-fill insulation shall be used on horizontal surfaces only.

Where loose-fill insulation is installed in an unconfined sloped space, such as an attic space over a sloped ceiling, the supporting slope shall not be more than 4.5 in 12 for mineral fibre or cellulose fibre insulation, and 2.5 in 12 for other types of insulation.
Loose-fill insulation is permitted to be used in wood-frame walls of existing buildings. (See en000340.)

Where blown-in insulation is installed in above-ground or below-ground wood-frame walls of new buildings, the density of the installed insulation shall be sufficient to preclude settlement, the insulation shall be installed behind a membrane that will permit visual inspection prior to the installation of the interior finish, the insulation shall be installed in a manner that will not interfere with the installation of the interior finish, and no water shall be added to the insulation, unless it can be shown that the added water will not adversely affect other materials in the assembly.
Water repellent loose-fill insulation is permitted to be used between the outer and inner wythes of masonry cavity walls. (See en000341.)

Where soffit venting is used, measures shall be taken to prevent loose-fill insulation from blocking the soffit vents and to maintain an open path for circulation of air from the vents into the attic or roof space, and to minimize airflow into the insulation near the soffit vents to maintain the thermal performance of the material. (See ea004821)
Spray-applied polyurethane insulation shall be installed in accordance with ulcs705.2.

Wall, ceiling and floor assemblies separating conditioned space from unconditioned space or from the ground shall be constructed so as to include an air barrier system that will provide a continuous barrier to air leakage from the interior of the building into wall, floor, attic or roof spaces, sufficient to prevent excessive moisture condensation in such spaces during the winter, and from the exterior or the ground inward sufficient to prevent moisture condensation on the room side during winter, ensure comfortable conditions for the occupants, and minimize the ingress of soil gas. (See en000342.)

Air barrier systems shall possess the characteristics necessary to provide an effective barrier to air infiltration and exfiltration under differential air pressure due to stack effect, mechanical systems or wind.
Where polyethylene sheet is used to provide airtightness in the air barrier system, it shall conform to cgsb-51.34.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Where the air barrier system consists of an air-impermeable panel-type material, all joints shall be sealed to prevent air leakage.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in es002464, where the air barrier system consists of flexible sheet material, all joints shall be sealed, or lapped not less than 100 mm and clamped, such as between framing members, furring or blocking, and rigid panels.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Where an interior wall meets an exterior wall, ceiling, floor or roof required to be provided with air barrier protection, the air barrier system shall extend across the intersection.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Where an interior wall projects through a ceiling or extends to become an exterior wall, spaces in the wall shall be blocked to provide continuity across those spaces with the air barrier system in the abutting walls or ceiling.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Where an interior floor projects through an exterior wall or extends to become an exterior floor, continuity of the air barrier system shall be maintained from the abutting walls across the floor assembly.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Penetrations of the air barrier system, such as those created by the installation of doors, windows, electrical wiring, electrical boxes, piping or ductwork, shall be sealed to maintain the integrity of the air barrier system over the entire surface.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Where access hatches and sump pit covers are installed through assemblies constructed with an air barrier system, they shall be weatherstripped around their perimeters to prevent air leakage.

National Article Title: Continuity of the Air Barrier System
National Sentence Text: Clearances between chimneys or gas vents and the surrounding construction that would permit air leakage from within the building into a wall or attic or roof space shall be sealed by noncombustible material to prevent such leakage.

National Article Title: Air Leakage Control in Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: Masonry walls required to provide a barrier to the ingress of air from the ground shall include a course of masonry units without voids, or be sealed with flashing material extending across the full width of the masonry.

National Article Title: Air Leakage Control in Masonry Walls
National Sentence Text: The masonry course or flashing described in es008318 shall be located at the level of the adjoining floor and be sealed to it in accordance with ea004795, or in the absence of a floor, be located at the level of the ground cover required by ea001325 and be sealed to it.

National Article Title: Air Leakage Control in Underground Roofs
National Sentence Text: Waterproofing systems for roofs of underground structures shall be sealed to the air barrier in the walls.
Materials used to provide a barrier to the ingress of air through floors-on-ground shall conform to cgsb-51.34.

Where the floor-on-ground is a concrete slab, the air barrier shall be installed below the slab, or applied to the top of the slab, provided a separate floor is installed over the slab. (See en000302.)
Where the air barrier installed below a floor-on-ground is flexible sheet material, joints in the barrier shall be lapped not less than 300 mm. (See en000302.)
Where installed in conjunction with a framed floor-on-ground or above a floor-on-ground, the air barrier shall be installed in accordance with ea001566
A floor-on-ground shall be sealed around its perimeter to the inner surfaces of adjacent walls using flexible sealant.

All penetrations of a floor-on-ground that are required to drain water from the floor surface shall be sealed in a manner that prevents the upward flow of air without preventing the downward flow of liquid water.

Thermally insulated wall, ceiling and floor assemblies shall be constructed with a vapour barrier so as to provide a barrier to diffusion of water vapour from the interior into wall spaces, floor spaces or attic or roof spaces.
Except as provided in es014601, vapour barriers shall have a permeance not greater than 60 ng/(Pa×s×m2) measured in accordance with astme96m using the desiccant method (dry cup).

Thermally insulated foundation wall assemblies are permitted to be constructed with variable-permeance vapour barriers having a permeance not greater than 60 ng/(Pa×s×m2) using the desiccant method (dry cup) and greater than 300 ng/(Pa×s×m2) using the water method (wet cup) measured in accordance with astme96m.(See en001471.)
Where the intended use of the interior space will result in high moisture generation, the assembly shall be designed according to Part 5. (See en001524.)
Where polyethylene is installed to serve only as the vapour barrier, it shall comply with Clause 4.4, Thermal Stability, and Clause 5.7, Oxidative Induction Time, of cgsb-51.34.
Membrane-type vapour barriers other than polyethylene shall conform to the requirements of cgsb-51.33.

Membrane-type vapour barriers other than polyethylene that are susceptible to deterioration under prolonged exposure to direct ultraviolet radiation shall be covered, or only be installed in locations that are not exposed to direct ultraviolet radiation after the completion of construction. (See en001323.)
Where a coating is applied to gypsum board to function as the vapour barrier, the permeance of the coating shall be determined in accordance with cgsb-1.501.
Where foamed plastic insulation functions as the vapour barrier, it shall be sufficiently thick so as to meet the requirement of es008448.
Products installed to function as the vapour barrier shall protect the warm side of wall, ceiling and floor assemblies.

Where different products are used for the vapour barrier and the insulation, the vapour barrier shall be installed sufficiently close to the warm side of the insulation to prevent condensation at design conditions. (See Notes en000345 and en001571.)

Where the same product is used for the vapour barrier and the insulation, the product shall be installed sufficiently close to the warm side of the assembly to prevent condensation at design conditions. (See Notes en000345, en001571 and en001569)

Except as provided in Sentences es016155 to es000038, sheet and panel-type materials incorporated into assemblies described in ea001557 shall conform to ea005037, where the material has an air leakage characteristic less than0.1 L/(s×m2) at 75 Pa, and a water vapour permeance less than 60 ng/(Pa×s×m2) when measured in accordance with astme96m using the desiccant method (dry cup) (see en000948), and the intended use of the interior space where the materials are installed will not result in high moisture generation. (See en001571.)
Where the intended use of the interior space will result in high moisture generation, the assembly shall be designed according to Part 5.
Wood-based sheathing materials not more than 12.5 mm thick and complying with ea004853 need not comply with es008439. (See en000949.)

Where a material has a water vapour permeance not less than 30 ng/(Pa×s×m2) and a thermal resistance not less than 0.7 (m2×K)/W and the heating degree-days of the building location are less than 6000, the assembly need not comply with es008439.

Sheet and panel-type materials described in ea004854 shall be installed on the warm face of the assembly (see also ea004856), at a location where the ratio between the total thermal resistance of all materials outboard of its innermost impermeable surface and the total thermal resistance of all materials inboard of that surface is not less than that required by et000203, or outboard of an air space that is vented to the outdoors.
For walls, the air space described in es008440c shall comply with es008467a.

For the purpose of this Section, the term “roof” shall mean sloped or near-horizontal assemblies that protect the spaces beneath them, including platforms that effectively serve as roofs with respect to the accumulation or drainage of precipitation. (See en001243.)
For the purpose of this Section, the term “roofing” shall mean the primary covering for roofs.

Roofs shall be protected with roofing, including flashing, installed so as to effectively shed water, prevent the ingress of water and moisture into building assemblies and occupied space, and minimize the ingress of water due to ice damming into building assemblies.
Compliance with es003118 shall be demonstrated by conforming to the remainder of this Section, or Part 5.
Methods described in csaa123.51, are permitted to be used for the installation of asphalt shingles in lieu of the methods described in this Section.
Where materials used for the preparation of the substrate for roofing are covered in the scope of a standard listed in et000000, they shall conform to that standard.
Where roofing materials are covered in the scope of a standard listed in et000057, they shall conform to that standard.
Materials listed in Tables et000000 and et000057 shall be installed in conformance with the manufacturer's written instructions. (See es005424.)
Nails used for roofing shall be corrosion-resistant roofing or shingle nails conforming to astmf1667, or csab111.
Nails shall have sufficient length to penetrate through, or 12 mm into, roof sheathing.
Nails used with asphalt roofing shall have a head diameter of not less than 9.5 mm and a shank thickness of not less than 2.95 mm.

Nails used with wood shingles or shakes shall have a head diameter of not less than 4.8 mm and a shank thickness of not less than 2.0 mm and shall be stainless steel, aluminum or hot-dipped galvanized. (See en000346.)
Staples used to apply asphalt or wood shingles shall be corrosion-resistant and shall be driven with the crown parallel to the eaves.
Staples used with asphalt shingles shall be not less than 19 mm long, 1.6 mm diam or thickness, with not less than a 25 mm crown, except that an 11 mm crown may be used as provided in es003169.
Staples used with wood shingles shall be not less than 29 mm long, 1.6 mm diam or thickness, with not less than a 9.5 mm crown and shall be stainless steel or aluminum. (See en000346.)
Except as provided in Sentences es003129 and es008453, the slopes on which roof coverings may be applied shall conform to et001066

Asphalt and gravel or coal tar and gravel roofs may be constructed with lower slopes than required in es003128 when effective drainage is provided by roof drains located at the lowest points on the roofs.

Profiled metal roof cladding systems specifically designed for low-slope applications are permitted to be installed with lower slopes than required by es003128, provided they are installed in conformance with the manufacturer's written recommendations.

Except where back-slope will not adversely affect adjacent supported or supporting constructions due to water ingress, roofs and constructions that effectively serve as roofs shall be constructed with sufficient slope away from exterior walls, and guards that are connected to the roof, or to a construction that effectively serves as a roof, by more than pickets or posts. (See Notes en001243, en001244 and en001251.)

The slope required by es007627 shall be sufficient to maintain a positive slope after expected shrinkage of the building frame, where these surfaces are supported by exterior walls and exterior columns (see en001251), and once design loading is taken into consideration, where these surfaces are cantilevered from exterior walls.

Except where the omission of flashing will not adversely affect adjacent supported or supporting constructions, flashing shall be installed at junctions between roofs and walls that rise above the roof, and guards that are connected to the roof by more than pickets or posts.
For the purpose of es008414, roofs shall include platforms that effectively serve as roofs with respect to the accumulation or drainage of precipitation.
Sheet metal flashing shall consist of not less than 1.73 mm thick sheet lead, 0.33 mm thick galvanized steel, 0.33 mm thick copper, 0.35 mm thick zinc, or 0.48 mm thick aluminum.
Where sloping surfaces of shingled roofs intersect to form a valley, the valley shall be flashed.
Valley flashing shall be installed over continuous sheathing.
Closed valleys shall not be used with rigid shingles on slopes of less than 1 in 1.2.
Open valleys shall be flashed with at least one layer of sheet metal not less than 600 mm wide, or 2 layers of roll roofing.

The bottom layer of roofing required in es003134 shall consist of at least Type S smooth roll roofing or Type M mineral surface roll roofing (mineral surface down) not less than 457 mm wide, centred in the valley and fastened with nails spaced not more than 450 mm o.c. located 25 mm away from the edges.

The top layer of roofing required in es003134 shall consist of at least Type M mineral surface roll roofing (mineral surface up), 914 mm wide, centred in the valley, applied over a 100 mm wide strip of cement along each edge of the bottom layer, and fastened with a sufficient number of nails to hold it in place until the shingles are applied.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: The intersection of shingle roofs and masonry walls or chimneys shall be protected with flashing.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: Counter flashing required in es003137 shall be embedded not less than 25 mm in the masonry and shall extend not less than 150 mm down the masonry and lap the lower flashing not less than 100 mm.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: Flashing along the slopes of a roof described in es003137 shall be stepped so that there is not less than a 75 mm head lap in both the lower flashing and counter flashing.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: Where the roof described in es003137 slopes upwards from the masonry, the flashing shall extend up the roof slope to a point equal in height to the flashing on the masonry, but not less than 1.5 times the shingle exposure.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: The intersection of shingle roofs and walls clad with other than masonry shall be protected with flashing.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: Flashing required in es003141 shall be installed so that it extends up the wall not less than 75 mm behind the sheathing paper, and extends not less than 75 mm horizontally.

National Article Title: Intersection of Shingle Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: Along the slope of the roof, the flashing required in es003141 shall be stepped with not less than a 75 mm head lap.

National Article Title: Intersection of Built-Up Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: The intersection of built-up roofs with masonry walls or chimneys shall have a cant strip at the intersection, and a roofing membrane shall be mopped over the cant strip and not less than 150 mm up the wall.

National Article Title: Intersection of Built-Up Roofs and Masonry
National Sentence Text: Counter flashing installed over the intersection referred to in es003144 shall be embedded not less than 25 mm in the masonry, and shall be of sufficient length to extend down not less than 150 mm, lapping the membrane on the masonry not less than 100 mm.

National Article Title: Intersection of Built-Up Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: The intersection of built-up roofs with walls clad with other than masonry shall have a cant strip at the intersection.

National Article Title: Intersection of Built-Up Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: The roofing membrane shall be mopped over the cant strip referred to in es003146.

National Article Title: Intersection of Built-Up Roofs and Walls other than Masonry
National Sentence Text: Flashing plies shall extend not less than 150 mm up the wall referred to in es003146 behind the sheathing paper.
Except as otherwise permitted in es003153, chimney saddles shall be installed where the upper side of a chimney on a sloping roof is more than 750 mm wide.
Chimney saddles shall be covered with sheet metal or roofing material of weight and quality equivalent to the roofing.
Saddles shall be flashed where they intersect the roof.
The intersection of the saddle and the chimney shall be flashed and counterflashed as described in ea001578

A chimney saddle need not be installed if the intersection between the chimney and roof is protected by sheet metal flashing that extends up the chimney to a height equal to at least one sixth the width of the chimney, but not less than 150 mm, and up the roof slope to a point equal in height to the flashing on the chimney, but not less than 1.5 times the shingle exposure.
Flashing described in es003153 at the chimney shall be counterflashed as required by ea001578

Except as provided in es003156, eave protection shall be provided on shingle, shake or tile roofs, extending from the edge of the roof a minimum of 900 mm up the roof slope to a line not less than 300 mm inside the inner face of the exterior wall.

Eave protection is not required over unheated garages, carports and porches, where the roof overhang exceeds 900 mm measured along the roof slope from the edge of the roof to the inner face of the exterior wall, on roofs of asphalt shingles installed in accordance with ep001029.26.8, on roofs with slopes of 1 in 1.5 or greater, or in regions with 3 500 or fewer degree-days.

Eave protection shall be laid beneath the starter strip and shall consist of No. 15 asphalt-saturated felt laid in two plies lapped 480 mm and cemented together with lap cement, Type M or S roll roofing laid with not less than 100 mm head and end laps cemented together with lap cement, glass fibre or polyester fibre coated base sheets, or self-sealing composite membranes consisting of modified bituminous coated material.

Except as required in es003159, when underlay is used beneath shingles, it shall be asphalt-saturated sheathing paper weighing not less than 0.195 kg/m2, or No. 15 plain or perforated asphalt-saturated felt.
Underlay used beneath wood shingles shall be breather type.
When used with shingles, underlay shall be installed parallel to the eaves with head and end lap of not less than 50 mm.
The top edge of each strip of underlay referred to in es003160 shall be fastened with sufficient roofing nails to hold it in place until the shingles are applied.
The underlay referred to in es003160 shall overlap the eave protection by not less than 100 mm. (See ea001611 for underlay beneath wood shakes.)
Coverage shall be not less than 2 thicknesses of shingle over the entire roof, disregarding cutouts.

A starter strip shall be installed along the lower edge of the roof so that it extends approximately 12 mm beyond the eaves and rake of the roof and fastened along the bottom edge with nails spaced not more than 300 mm o.c.

Starter strips shall be at least Type M mineral-surfaced roll roofing not less than 300 mm wide, shingles of the same weight and quality as those used as a roof covering with tabs facing up the roof slope, or pre-manufactured starter strips installed with sealant at the eaves.
Starter strips need not be provided where eave protection of not less than Type M mineral-surfaced roll roofing is provided.
Shingles shall have a head lap of not less than 50 mm.
Except as provided in es003169, shingles shall be fastened with at least 4 nails or staples for 1 m wide shingles so that no nails or staples are exposed.
Where staples with an 11 mm crown are used, shingles shall be fastened with at least 6 staples.
Fasteners may be reduced for narrower shingles in proportion to the width of the shingle or when shingles incorporating interlocking devices are used.
Fasteners referred to in Sentences es003168 and es003169 shall be located 25 mm to 40 mm from each end of each strip shingle with other fasteners equally spaced between them.
Fasteners referred to in Sentences es003168 and es003169 shall be located not less than 12 mm above the tops of the cutouts.
Shingle tabs shall be secured by a spot of plastic cement not exceeding 25 mm diam under the centre of each tab or by interlocking devices or self-sealing strips.
Shingles on hips and ridges shall be applied so they extend not less than 100 mm on either side of the hip or ridge, and shall be lapped not less than 150 mm.
Shingles referred to in es003174 shall be fastened with nails or staples on each side located not more than 25 mm from the edge and 25 mm above the butt of the overlying shingle.
Eave protection shall conform to ep001029.26.5
Flashing shall conform to ep001029.26.4
Except for the first 2 courses, coverage shall be not less than 3 thicknesses of shingle over the entire roof, disregarding cutouts.
A starter strip shall be installed as in ea001588
Starter strips required in es003179 shall be laid in a continuous band of cement not less than 200 mm wide.
Shingle tabs shall be secured with cold application cement applied at the rate of not less than 0.5 L/m2 of cemented area, or hot application asphalt applied at the rate of 1 kg/m2 of cemented area.
The first course of shingles shall be secured by a continuous band of cement along the eaves applied so that the width of the band equals the shingle exposure plus 100 mm.
The succeeding courses of shingles shall be secured by a continuous band of cement applied so that the width of the band equals the shingle exposure plus 50 mm.
The band required in es003183 shall be located not more than 50 mm above the butt of the overlying course of shingles.
Shingles on hips and ridges shall be not less than 300 mm wide applied to provide triple coverage.

Shingles referred to in es003185 shall be cemented to the roof shingles and to each other with a coat of cement and fastened with nails or staples located 40 mm above the butt of the overlying shingle and 50 mm from each edge.
Flashing shall conform to ep001029.26.4
Shingles shall be fastened in accordance with ea001590
Except as provided in es008437, decking for wood shingled roofs may be continuous or spaced.
Western cedar shingles shall be not less than No. 2 grade.
Eastern white cedar shingles shall be not less than B (clear) grade.
Wood shingles shall be not less than 400 mm long and not less than 75 mm or more than 350 mm wide.
Shingles shall be spaced approximately 6 mm apart and offset at the joints in adjacent courses not less than 40 mm so that joints in alternate courses are staggered.
Shingles shall be fastened with 2 nails or staples located approximately 20 mm from the sides of the shingle and 40 mm above the exposure line.
The exposure of wood roof shingles shall conform to et000205
Flashing shall conform to ep001029.26.4
Eave protection shall conform to ep001029.26.5
Shakes shall be not less than 450 mm long and not less than 100 mm nor more than 350 mm wide with a butt thickness of not more than 32 mm and not less than 9 mm.
Where eave protection is not provided, an underlay conforming to the requirements in ea001585 for wood shingles shall be laid as a strip not less than 900 mm wide along the eaves.

A strip of material similar to that described in es003199 not less than 450 mm wide shall be interlaid between each course of shakes with the bottom edge of the strip positioned above the butt line at a distance equal to double the exposure of the shakes.
Interlaid strips referred to in es003200 shall be lapped not less than 150 mm at hips and ridges in a manner that will prevent water from reaching the roof sheathing.
Shakes shall be spaced 6 mm to 9 mm apart and the joints in any one course shall be separated not less than 40 mm from joints in adjacent courses.
Shakes shall be fastened with nails located approximately 20 mm from the sides of the shakes and 40 mm above the exposure line.
The exposure of wood shakes shall not exceed 190 mm for shakes not less than 450 mm long, and 250 mm for shakes not less than 600 mm long.
Flashing shall conform to ep001029.26.4
Eave protection shall conform to ep001029.26.5
Shakes shall be not less than No. 1 or Handsplit grade.
The quantities of bituminous materials used on built-up roofs shall conform to et000206
Coal-tar products and asphalt products shall not be used together in built-up roof construction.
Bitumen roofing felts shall be at least No. 15 felt.

Aggregate used for surfacing built-up roofs shall be clean, dry and durable and shall consist of particles of gravel, crushed stone or air-cooled blast furnace slag having a size of from 6 mm to 15 mm.
The minimum amount of aggregate surfacing per square metre of roof surface shall be 15 kg gravel or crushed stone or 10 kg crushed slag.
Flashing for built-up roofs shall conform to ep001029.26.4
Built-up roofing shall consist of not less than 3 mopped-down layers of roofing felt flood coated with bitumen.
In hot process applications each layer of bitumen-saturated felt shall be laid while the bitumen is hot, with each layer overlapping the previous one.
The full width under each lap referred to in es003214 shall be coated with bitumen so that in no place does felt touch felt.
Felt shall be laid free of wrinkles and shall be rolled directly into the hot bitumen and broomed forward and outward from the centre to ensure complete adhesion.

Except as permitted in es003218, built-up roofing applied over wood, plywood, OSB or waferboard roof sheathing shall be laid over an additional base layer of felt laid dry over the entire roof deck with not less than a 50 mm headlap and a 50 mm sidelap between each sheet.
Where plywood, OSB or waferboard roof sheathing is used, the dry layer of felt required in es003217 may be omitted when the joints are taped and the sheathing is primed with asphalt.

Roofing shall be securely attached to the decking or where insulation is applied above the deck, the insulation shall be securely attached to the deck before the first layer of felt is fastened to the insulation.
Except as permitted in es003223, a cant strip shall be provided at the edges of roofs.
At least 2 plies of the roofing membrane shall be carried over the top of the cant strip.
Flashing shall extend over the top of the cant strip and be shaped to form a drip.
The cant strip required in es003220 need not be provided where a gravel stop is installed at the edge of roofs.

The roofing membranes shall be carried over the edge of the roof before the gravel stop referred to in es003223 is fastened and 2 plies of roofing membrane mopped to the top surface of the gravel stop before the flood coat is applied.
The gravel stop referred to in es003223 shall extend over the edge of the roof to form a drip or shall be flashed so that the flashing extends over the edge to form a drip.
Wide selvage asphalt roofing shall provide double coverage over the entire roof surface.
Plies of selvage roofing shall be cemented together to ensure a watertight joint.
Sheet metal roofing shall be not less than 0.33 mm thick galvanized steel, 0.46 mm thick copper, 0.46 mm thick zinc, or 0.48 mm thick aluminum.

Except as provided in es008437, where sheet metal roofing is not supported by roof decking but spans between spaced supports, the panels shall be designed to support the specified live loads for roofs.

Except as provided in es008437, where glass-reinforced polyester roofing panels are not supported by roof decking but span between spaced supports, the panels shall be designed to support the specified live roof loads.
Hot applied rubberized asphalt roofing shall be installed in accordance with cgsb-37.51.
Polyvinyl chloride sheet applied roofing membrane shall be installed in accordance with cgsb37-gp-55m.
Except as provided in es008437, concrete roof tiles shall be installed according to csaa220s. (See en000347.)
When roof drains are provided they shall conform to Part 7.
Where downspouts are provided and are not connected to a sewer, extensions shall be provided to carry rainwater away from the building in a manner which will prevent soil erosion.

Where lumber, wood shingles, shakes, fibre-cement shingles, planks and sheets, plywood, OSB, waferboard, hardboard, vinyl, insulated vinyl, polypropylene, aluminum or steel, including trim and soffits, are installed as cladding on wood-frame walls or above-ground flat insulating concrete form walls exposed to precipitation, the cladding assembly shall comply with Subsections ep001029.27.2 to ep001029.27.15, or Part 5.

Where stucco is installed as cladding on wood-frame walls, above-ground flat insulating concrete form walls or masonry walls exposed to precipitation, the cladding assembly shall comply with Subsections ep001029.27.2 to ep001029.27.5, and ep001029.28, or Part 5.

Where masonry serves as cladding on wood-frame walls, above-ground flat insulating concrete form walls or masonry walls exposed to precipitation, the cladding assembly shall comply with Subsections ep001029.27.2 to ep001029.27.4, and ep001029.20, except for masonry veneer, which shall be attached to above-ground flat insulating concrete form walls in accordance with es014607, or Part 5.

Where asphalt shingles are installed as cladding on wood-frame walls exposed to precipitation, the cladding assembly shall comply with Subsections ep001029.26.7 and ep001029.27.2 to ep001029.27.4, or Part 5.

Where an exterior insulation finish system is installed as cladding on wood-frame, masonry, cold-formed steel stud, above-ground flat insulating concrete form or cast-in-place concrete walls exposed to precipitation, the cladding assembly shall comply with Subsections ep001029.25.5, ep001029.27.2 to ep001029.27.4, and ep001029.27.14, or Part 5. (See en000950.)

Where cladding materials other than those described in Sentences es008460 to es000044 are installed, or where the cladding materials described in Sentences es008460 to es000044 are installed on substrates other than those identified in Sentences es008460 to es000044, the materials and installation shall comply with Part 5.

National Article Title: Minimizing and Preventing Ingress and Damage
National Sentence Text: Except where exterior walls are protected from precipitation or where it can be shown that precipitation ingress will not adversely affect occupant health or safety, exterior walls shall be designed and constructed to minimize the ingress of precipitation into the assembly, and prevent the ingress of precipitation into interior space. (See en001246.)

National Article Title: Minimizing and Preventing Ingress and Damage
National Sentence Text: Except where exterior walls are protected from specific mechanisms of deterioration, such as mechanical impact and ultraviolet radiation, exterior walls shall be designed and constructed to minimize the likelihood of their required performance being reduced to an unacceptable level as a result of those mechanisms.

Except as provided in es008468, a cladding assembly is deemed to have a capillary break between the cladding and the backing assembly, where there is a drained and vented air space not less than 9.5 mm deep behind the cladding, over the full height and width of the wall (see also ea001649), an open drainage material, not less than 10 mm thick and with a cross-sectional area that is not less than 80% open, is installed between the cladding and the backing, over the full height and width of the wall, the cladding is loosely fastened to the backing and behind each cladding component there is a clear air space that is continuous for the full width of the component, not less than 10 mm deep at the bottom of the component, and not less than 6 mm deep over not less than 90 mm for every 230 mm of exposed height of the component, the wall is a masonry cavity wall or the cladding is masonry veneer constructed according to ep001029.20, or the cladding conforms to ep001029.27.14

The drained and vented air space, and drainage material described in es008476 may be interrupted by penetrations for windows, doors and services, flashing, and furring, provided the furring does not make up more than 20% of the furred area.

Where a construction projects over the top of the drained and vented air space described in es008467a or over the drainage material described in es008467b, the air space or drainage material shall not be contiguous with concealed spaces in the projecting construction.

Exterior walls exposed to precipitation shall be protected against precipitation ingress by an exterior cladding assembly consisting of a first plane of protection and a second plane of protection, where such walls enclose spaces of residential occupancy or spaces that directly serve spaces of residential occupancy.

Except as provided in es008472, exterior walls exposed to precipitation shall be protected against precipitation ingress by an exterior cladding assembly consisting of a first plane of protection and a second plane of protection incorporating a capillary break, where the number of degree-days is less than 3400 and the moisture index is greater than 0.90, or the number of degree-days is 3400 or more, and the moisture index is greater than 1.00. (See es000114 and ex000108 for information on the moisture index.)

In exterior walls described in es008471, the first and second planes of protection need not incorporate a capillary break, where it can be shown that omitting the capillary break will not adversely affect the performance of the building assemblies, the building is an accessory building, or the wall is constructed of non-moisture-sensitive materials, and intersecting or supported floors are also constructed of non-moisture-sensitive materials, or is constructed as a mass wall of sufficient thickness to minimize the transfer of moisture to the interior.

National Article Title: First and Second Planes of Protection
National Sentence Text: Where walls required to provide protection from precipitation comprise cladding assemblies with first and second planes of protection, the first plane of protection shall consist of cladding with appropriate trim, accessory pieces and fasteners, and be designed and constructed to minimize the passage of rain and snow into the wall by minimizing holes and managing precipitation ingress caused by the kinetic energy of raindrops, surface tension, capillarity, gravity, and air pressure differences (see ep001029.27.4), the second plane of protection shall be designed and constructed to (see ep001029.27.3) intercept all rain and snow that gets past the first plane of protection, and effectively dissipate any rain or snow to the exterior, and the protection provided by the first and second planes of protection shall be maintained at wall penetrations created by the installation of components and services such as windows, doors, ventilation ducts, piping, wiring and electrical outlets, and at the interface with other wall assemblies.
A clearance of not less than 200 mm shall be provided between finished ground and cladding that is adversely affected by moisture, such as untreated wood, plywood, OSB, waferboard and hardboard.
A clearance of not less than 50 mm shall be provided between a roof surface and cladding that is adversely affected by moisture, such as untreated wood, plywood, OSB, waferboard and hardboard.

National Article Title: Elements of the Second Plane of Protection
National Sentence Text: The second plane of protection shall consist of a drainage plane having an appropriate inner boundary and flashing to dissipate rainwater to the exterior.

National Article Title: Elements of the Second Plane of Protection
National Sentence Text: Except for cladding systems conforming to ep001029.27.14, the inner boundary of the drainage plane shall comply with Articles ea004870 to ea004874

National Article Title: Elements of the Second Plane of Protection
National Sentence Text: The protection provided by the second plane of protection shall be maintained at wall penetrations created by the installation of components and services such as windows, doors, ventilation ducts, piping, wiring and electrical outlets, and at the interface with other wall assemblies.

National Article Title: Elements of the Second Plane of Protection
National Sentence Text: Flashing material and its installation shall comply with Articles ea004875 and ea004876
Sheathing membranes shall conform to the performance requirements of cgsb-51.32.
Except as provided in Articles ea001537 to ea004874, at least one layer of sheathing membrane shall be applied beneath cladding.
Sheathing membrane required in es008480 shall be applied so that joints are lapped not less than 100 mm.
Where sheathing membrane required in es008480 is applied horizontally, the upper sheets shall overlap the lower sheets.

National Article Title: Insulating Sheathing in lieu of Sheathing Membrane
National Sentence Text: Where non-wood-based rigid exterior insulating sheathing, or exterior insulating sheathing with an integral sheathing membrane is installed, a separate sheathing membrane is not required.

National Article Title: Insulating Sheathing in lieu of Sheathing Membrane
National Sentence Text: Where insulating sheathing is installed as provided in es003034, sheathing panels subject to moisture deterioration shall be sealed at all joints, and the joints of sheathing panels not subject to moisture deterioration shall be sealed at all joints, or lapped or tongue and groove, and detailed to ensure drainage of water to the exterior. (See en000333.)

National Article Title: Sheathing Membranes in lieu of Sheathing
National Sentence Text: Except as provided in ea004874, where no sheathing is used, at least 2 layers of sheathing membrane shall be applied beneath the cladding. (See ea001528 and en000334.)

National Article Title: Sheathing Membranes in lieu of Sheathing
National Sentence Text: All joints in the sheathing membrane required in es003036 shall occur over framing, and the membrane shall be fastened to the framing with roofing nails or staples spaced not more than 150 mm along the edges of the outer layer of sheathing membrane.

National Article Title: Sheathing Membranes in lieu of Sheathing
National Sentence Text: Wall sheathing is permitted to be used in lieu of one layer of sheathing membrane required in es003036, and its thickness need not conform to et001065.

Sheathing membrane is permitted to be omitted beneath cladding when the joints in the cladding are formed to effectively prevent the passage of wind and rain in conformance with es008487 or es003042, as applicable.

Cladding consisting of sheets of plywood, hardboard, OSB, waferboard or fibre cement is considered to meet the requirements of es003039, provided the cladding is applied so that all edges are directly supported by framing, the vertical joints between adjacent sheets are sealed and covered with battens, shiplapped, or otherwise matched to provide weathertight joints, and the horizontal joints between adjacent sheets are sealed and shiplapped, or otherwise matched to provide weathertight joints.
Metal siding consisting of sheets of metal is considered to meet the requirements of es003039 where the joints between sheets are of the locked-seam type.
Flashing shall consist of not less than 1.73 mm thick sheet lead, 0.33 mm thick galvanized steel, 0.46 mm thick copper, 0.46 mm thick zinc, 0.48 mm thick aluminum, or 1.02 mm thick vinyl.

Except as provided in es008490, flashing shall be installed at every horizontal junction between cladding elements, every horizontal offset in the cladding, and every horizontal line where the cladding substrates change and where the substrates differ sufficiently for stresses to be concentrated along that line, or the installation of the cladding on the lower substrate may compromise the drainage of moisture from behind the cladding above. (See en001249.)

Flashing need not be installed as described in es008489 where the upper cladding elements overlap the lower cladding elements by not less than 25 mm, where the cladding above and below the joint is installed outboard of a drained and vented air space (see es008467a), and the horizontal detail is constructed so as to minimize the ingress of precipitation into the air space, or at horizontal construction joints in stucco, where the joint is finished with an expansion-contraction strip, and the cladding is installed outboard of a drained and vented air space (see es008467a).

Flashing shall be installed over exterior wall openings where the vertical distance from the bottom of the eave to the top of the trim is more than one-quarter of the horizontal overhang of the eave. (See en001250.)

Flashing described in Sentences es008489 and es008491 shall extend not less than 50 mm upward inboard of the sheathing membrane or sheathing installed in lieu of the sheathing membrane (see ea001537), have a slope of not less than 6% toward the exterior after the expected shrinkage of the building frame, terminate at each end with an end-dam with a height in millimetres not less than 25 mm or 1/10 the value of the 1-in-5 driving rain wind pressure in Pa, and at the height defined in es008492c1, extending to the face of the adjacent cladding, lap not less than 10 mm vertically over the building element below, and terminate in a drip offset not less than 5 mm outward from the outer face of the building element below. (See en001251.)

Where the sills of windows and doors installed in exterior walls are not self-flashing, flashing shall be installed between the underside of the window or door and the wall construction below. (See en001252.)
Sealant shall be provided where required to prevent the entry of water into the structure.
Sealant shall be provided between masonry, siding or stucco and the adjacent door and window frames or trim, including sills, unless such locations are completely protected from the entry of rain.

Sealant shall be provided at vertical joints between different cladding materials unless the joint is suitably lapped or flashed to prevent the entry of rain. (See Articles ea005062, ea001392 and ea001689)

Sealants shall be a non-hardening type suitable for exterior use, selected for their ability to resist the effects of weathering, and compatible with and adhere to the substrate to which they are applied. (See en001525.)
Sealants shall conform to astmc834 astmc920 astmc1184 or astmc1311.
Backer rod shall conform to astmc1330. (See en001525.)
Except as permitted by Sentences es003253 to es014608, cladding shall be fastened to the framing members or furring members, or to blocking between the framing members.

Vertical lumber, stucco lath or reinforcing, vertically applied vinyl siding, vertically applied insulated vinyl siding, and polypropylene siding are permitted to be attached to sheathing only where the sheathing consists of not less than 14.3 mm lumber, 12.5 mm plywood or waferboard, or 11 mm OSB.

Vertically applied metal siding and wood shingles and shakes are permitted to be attached to the sheathing only where the sheathing consists of not less than 14.3 mm lumber, 7.5 mm plywood, or 7.5 mm OSB or waferboard.

Where wood shingles or shakes are applied to sheathing which is not suitable for attaching the shingles or shakes, the shingles or shakes are permitted to be attached to a wood lath not less than 38 mm by 9.5 mm thick securely nailed to the framing and applied as described in ea001661
Cladding, trim and furring members are permitted to be attached to the web fastening strips of flat wall insulating concrete form units using screws in accordance with es014607.
Blocking for the attachment of cladding shall be not less than 38 mm by 38 mm lumber securely nailed to the framing and spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.
Except as permitted in es003256, furring for the attachment of cladding shall be not less than 19 mm by 38 mm lumber when applied over sheathing.

When applied without sheathing, furring referred to in es003260 shall be not less than 19 mm by 64 mm lumber on supports spaced not more than 400 mm o.c., or 19 mm by 89 mm lumber on supports spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.
Furring referred to in es003260 shall be securely fastened to the framing, and spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.
Nail or staple size and spacing for the attachment of cladding and trim to wood framing, furring members or blocking shall conform to et000207.

Screw size and spacing for the attachment of cladding, trim and furring members to the web fastening strips of flat wall insulating concrete form (ICF) units shall conform to et000484 where the 1-in-50 hourly wind pressure (HWP) is less than or equal to 0.60 kPa. (See en001474.)
Nails or staples for the attachment of cladding and wood trim shall be corrosion-resistant and shall be compatible with the cladding material.
Fasteners for metal cladding shall be positioned to permit expansion and contraction of the cladding.
Fasteners for vinyl siding, insulated vinyl siding and polypropylene siding shall be installed in the centre of the slots of the nail hem.
Fasteners for shakes and shingles shall penetrate through the nail-holding base or not less than 19 mm into the framing.
Fasteners for vinyl cladding, insulated vinyl cladding and polypropylene cladding shall penetrate through the nail-holding base or not less than 32 mm into the framing.
Fasteners for cladding other than that described in Sentences es003266 and es013808 shall penetrate through the nail-holding base or not less than 25 mm into the framing.
Lumber siding shall be sound, free of knot holes, loose knots, through checks or splits.
Drop, rustic, novelty, lapped board and vertical wood siding shall be not less than 14.3 mm thick and not more than 286 mm wide.
Bevel siding shall be not less than 5 mm thick at the top, and not less than 12 mm thick at the butt for siding 184 mm or less in width, and 14.3 mm thick at the butt for siding wider than 184 mm.
Bevel siding shall be not more than 286 mm wide.
Lumber siding shall prevent water from entering at the joints by the use of lapped or matched joints or by vertical wood battens.
Siding shall overlap not less than 1 mm per 16 mm width of lumber, but not less than 9.5 mm for matched siding, 25 mm for lapped bevel siding, or 12 mm for vertical battens.
Shingles and shakes shall conform to csao118.1 or csao118.2.
Western cedar shakes shall be not less than No. 1 or Handsplit grade, and western cedar shingles not less than No. 2 grade, except that No. 3 grade may be used for undercoursing.
Eastern white cedar shingles shall be at least B (clear) grade, except that C grade may be used for the lower course of double course applications.
Shingles and shakes shall be not less than 65 mm or more than 350 mm wide.

Shingles or shakes shall be fastened with nails or staples located approximately 20 mm from each edge and not less than 25 mm above the exposure line for single-course applications, or approximately 50 mm above the butt for double-course applications.
In single-course application, joints in succeeding courses shall be offset not less than 40 mm so that joints in any 2 of 3 consecutive courses are staggered.
In double-course application, joints in the outer course shall be offset from joints in the under-course by not less than 40 mm, and joints in succeeding courses shall be offset not less than 40 mm.
When lath is used with double-course application [see es003256], it shall be spaced according to the exposure and securely fastened to the framing.
The butts of the under-course of the application referred to in es003281 shall rest on the top edge of the lath.
The outer course of the application referred to in es003281 shall be fastened to the lath with nails of sufficient length to penetrate through the lath.
The butts of the shingles or shakes shall be so located that they project not less than 12 mm below the bottom edge of the lath referred to in es003281.
If wood lath is not used, the butts of the under-course shingles or shakes of the application referred to in es003281 shall be located 12 mm above the butts of the outer course.
The exposure and butt thickness of shingles and shakes shall conform to et000208
Plywood cladding shall be exterior type conforming to hpvahp1 csao121 csao151 or csao153.
Plywood cladding shall be not less than 6 mm thick when applied directly to sheathing.
When applied directly to framing or over furring strips, plywood cladding thickness shall conform to et000209
The thickness of grooved or textured plywood cladding shall be measured at the point of least thickness.
The edges of plywood cladding shall be treated with a suitable paint or sealer.
Plywood applied in panels shall have all edges supported.
Not less than a 2 mm gap shall be provided between panels referred to in es003302.
Vertical joints in cladding referred to in es003302 shall be protected with batten strips or sealant when the plywood joints are not matched.
Horizontal joints in cladding referred to in es003302 shall be lapped not less than 25 mm or shall be suitably flashed.
Plywood applied in horizontal lapped strips shall have not less than a 2 mm gap provided at the butted ends, which shall be caulked.
The horizontal joints of siding described in es003306 shall be lapped not less than 25 mm.
Wedges shall be inserted under all vertical butt joints and at all corners when horizontal lapped plywood is applied without sheathing.
Hardboard cladding shall conform to ansia135.6.

Hardboard cladding shall be not less than 9.5 mm thick when applied over sheathing that provides continuous support or over furring or framing members not more than 400 mm o.c., or 11.1 mm thick when applied over furring or framing members not more than 600 mm o.c.
Where hardboard cladding is grooved, the grooves shall not extend more than 1.5 mm into the minimum required thickness.(See en000348.)
Hardboard cladding applied in panels shall have all edges supported with not less than a 5 mm gap provided between sheets.
Vertical joints in cladding described in es003314 shall be protected with batten strips or sealant when the joints are not matched.
Horizontal joints in cladding described in es003314 shall be lapped not less than 25 mm or shall be suitably flashed.
Hardboard applied in horizontal lapped strips shall have not less than a 5 mm gap provided at the butted ends, which shall be sealed or otherwise protected with suitable mouldings.
The horizontal joints of siding described in es003317 shall overlap not less than 1 mm per 16 mm width of siding board but not less than 9.5 mm for matched joint siding or 25 mm for lapped siding.
Not less than 3 mm clearance shall be provided between hardboard cladding and door or window frames.
OSB and waferboard cladding shall conform to csao437.0.
OSB conforming to O-2 grade shall be not less than 6.0 mm thick where applied directly to sheathing.
OSB conforming to O-2 grade applied directly to framing or over furring strips shall conform to the thickness shown for plywood in et000209 (See en000349.)
OSB conforming to O-1 grade and waferboard conforming to R-1 grade shall be not less than 7.9 mm thick where applied directly to sheathing.

Where applied directly to framing or over furring strips, OSB conforming to O-1 grade and waferboard conforming to R-1 grade shall be not less than 9.5 mm thick on supports spaced not more than 400 mm o.c., and 12.7 mm thick on supports spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.
OSB and waferboard applied in panels shall have all edges supported and treated with a primer or sealer.
Not less than a 3 mm gap shall be provided between sheets in cladding described in es003325.
Vertical joints in cladding described in es003325 shall be protected with batten strips or sealant when the OSB and waferboard joints are not matched.
Horizontal joints in cladding described in es003325 shall be lapped not less than 25 mm or shall be suitably flashed.
Not less than a 3 mm clearance shall be provided between OSB and waferboard cladding and door or window frames.
Steel sheet cladding, including horizontal and vertical strip steel siding, flashing and trim accessories, shall have a minimum thickness of 0.33 mm, and conform to cssbi23m. (See en001325.)
Horizontal and vertical strip aluminum siding, including flashing and trim accessories, shall conform to cgsb-93.2. (See en001254.)

Aluminum sheet cladding shall conform to cgsb-93.1 and shall have a thickness of not less than 0.58 mm, except that siding supported by backing or sheathing shall have a thickness of not less than 0.46 mm. (See en001254.)
Vinyl siding shall conform to astmd3679.
Insulated vinyl siding shall conform to astmd7793.
Rigid vinyl soffits shall conform to astmd4477.
Where vinyl siding, insulated vinyl siding or rigid vinyl soffits are required to have a flame-spread rating, the rating shall be determined in accordance with ulcs102.2.
The attachment of vinyl siding and insulated vinyl siding shall conform to the requirements in ep001029.27.5
Polypropylene siding shall conform to astmd7254.
Where polypropylene siding is required to have a flame-spread rating, the rating shall be determined in accordance with ulcs102.2.
The attachment of polypropylene siding shall conform to the requirements in ep001029.27.5

Except as provided in es000046, this Subsection applies to exterior insulation finish systems (EIFS) that are covered in the scope of ulcs716.1, and have a geometrically defined drainage cavity with a minimum cavity depth of 10 mm and an open area equal to not less than 13% of the area of a full-size EIFS panel. (See en000951.)
EIFS that are not covered by es000045 shall comply with Part 5.
The materials used in EIFS shall conform to ulcs716.1.
The substrate on which the EIFS is installed shall be compatible with that particular system (see en000952), and comply with the structural requirements for sheathing materials stated in ep001029.23
The design and installation of EIFS on the substrate described in es000048 shall comply with ulcs716.2 and ulcs716.3.
Sheathing shall be provided beneath stucco applied over wood-frame walls except as permitted in ea001696
Where applied beneath stucco, sheathing shall conform to ep001029.23.16
Stucco lath or reinforcing shall be used to attach stucco to any substrate other than masonry.

Stucco lath or reinforcing shall be used to attach stucco to masonry where the masonry is soft-burned tile or brick of less strength than the stucco, or the masonry surface is not sound, clean and sufficiently rough to provide a good key.
Stucco applied over masonry chimneys shall be reinforced.
Stucco finish shall not be applied over concrete masonry units less than one month old unless the units have been cured by the autoclave process.
Stucco shall be not less than 200 mm above finished ground level except when it is applied over concrete or masonry.

Flashing and caulking used with stucco shall conform to Subsections ep001029.27.3 and ep001029.27.4, except that if aluminum flashing is used, it shall be separated from the stucco by an impervious membrane or coating. (See ea005062 for caulking around window frames.)
Portland cement shall conform to csaa3001.
Aggregate shall be clean, well-graded natural sand or sand manufactured from crushed stone, gravel or air-cooled blast furnace slag and shall contain no significant amounts of deleterious material.
Aggregate grading shall conform to et000210
Water shall be clean and free of significant amounts of deleterious material.
Fasteners for stucco lath or reinforcing shall be corrosion-resistant and of a material other than aluminum.
Nails for stucco lath or reinforcing shall be not less than 3.2 mm diam with a head diameter of not less than 11.1 mm.
Staples for stucco lath or reinforcing shall be not less than 1.98 mm diam or thickness.

Staples and nails for attaching stucco lath or reinforcing to vertical surfaces shall be of sufficient length to penetrate 25 mm into framing members or to the full depth of the sheathing where the sheathing is used for attachment.
On horizontal surfaces nails for stucco lath or reinforcing shall be not less than 38 mm long.
Rib lath or expanded metal stucco mesh shall be copper-alloy steel coated with rust-inhibitive paint after fabrication, or galvanized.
Woven or welded wire mesh shall be galvanized.

Sheathing need not be provided beneath stucco where not less than 1.19 mm diam galvanized wire is applied horizontally to the framing at vertical intervals of not more than 150 mm, or where paper-backed welded wire metal lath is used.
Stucco lath shall conform to et000211
Stucco lath shall be held not less than 6 mm away from the backing by means of suitable self-furring devices.
Stucco lath shall be applied with the long dimension horizontal.
Horizontal and vertical joints in stucco lath shall be lapped not less than 50 mm.
End joints of stucco lath shall be staggered and shall occur over framing members.

External corners of stucco lath shall be reinforced with a vertical strip of lath or reinforcing extending not less than 150 mm on both sides of the corner, or the lath or reinforcing shall extend around corners not less than 150 mm.
Stucco lath shall be fastened in conformance with ep001029.27.5
Fasteners on vertical surfaces shall be spaced not more than 150 mm o.c. vertically and 400 mm o.c. horizontally, or 100 mm o.c. vertically and 600 mm o.c. horizontally.
Nailing patterns other than those required in es003363 are permitted to be used provided there are at least 20 fasteners per square metre of wall surface.

Fasteners on horizontal surfaces shall be spaced not more than 150 mm o.c. along the framing members when members are spaced not more than 400 mm o.c., and 100 mm o.c. along members when members are spaced not more than 600 mm o.c.
Stucco mixes shall conform to et000212
Pigment if used shall consist of pure mineral oxides inert to the action of sun, lime and cement.
Pigment shall not exceed 6% of the Portland cement by weight.
Materials shall be thoroughly mixed before and after water is added.
Stucco shall be applied not later than 3 h after the initial mixing.
The base for stucco shall be maintained above freezing.
Stucco shall be maintained at a temperature of not less than 10°C during application, and for not less than 48 h afterwards.

National Article Title: Number of Coats and Total Thickness
National Sentence Text: Stucco shall be applied with at least 2 base coats and one finish coat, providing a total thickness of not less than 15 mm, measured from the face of the lath or the face of the masonry where no lath is used.
The first coat shall be not less than 6 mm thick, measured from the face of the lath or masonry, fully embedding the lath.
The surface of the first coat shall be scored to provide a key with the second coat.
The second coat shall be not less than 6 mm thick.
The surface of the second coat shall be lightly roughened to provide a key with the finish coat if the finish coat is other than stone dash.
When the finish coat is other than stone dash, the base shall be dampened but not saturated before the finish coat is applied.
The thickness of the finish coat shall be not less than 3 mm.
When a stone dash finish is used, the stone shall be partially embedded in the second coat before the second coat starts to set or stiffen.
A wall or ceiling finish shall also conform to the appropriate requirements in Sections ep001029.10 and ep001029.11, in addition to the requirements in this Section.

Waterproof finish shall be provided to a height of not less than 1.8 m above the floor in shower stalls, 1.2 m above the rims of bathtubs equipped with showers, and 400 mm above the rims of bathtubs not equipped with showers.
Waterproof finish shall consist of ceramic, plastic or metal tile, sheet vinyl, tempered hardboard, laminated thermosetting decorative sheets or linoleum.
Wood furring for the attachment of wall and ceiling finishes shall conform to et000213
Furring shall be fastened to the framing or to wood blocks with not less than 51 mm nails.
Application of plaster wall and ceiling finishes, including installation of metal or gypsum lath, shall conform to csaa82.30.
The requirements for application of gypsum board in this Subsection apply to the single layer application of gypsum board to wood furring or framing using nails or screws.
Except as provided in es008975, gypsum board applications not described in this Subsection shall conform to csaa82.31.
The application of gypsum board to flat insulating concrete form (ICF) walls shall conform to astmc840. (See en001090.)
Gypsum products shall conform to astmc1178m or astmc1396m, except that the flame-spread rating of gypsum board shall be determined in accordance with ulcs102.
Maximum spacing of supports for gypsum board applied as a single layer shall conform to et001067
Gypsum board supporting insulation shall be not less than 12.7 mm thick.

The length of fasteners for gypsum board shall conform to et000215, except that lesser depths of penetration are permitted for assemblies required to have a fire-resistance rating provided it can be shown, on the basis of fire tests, that such depths are adequate for the required rating.
Nails for fastening gypsum board to wood supports shall conform to astmf1667, or csab111.
Screws for fastening gypsum board to wood supports shall conform to astmc1002.
For single-layer application on a ceiling, nails shall be spaced not more than 180 mm o.c. on ceiling supports, or every 300 mm o.c. along ceiling supports, in pairs about 50 mm apart.
Where the ceiling sheets are supported by the wall sheets around the perimeter of the ceiling, this support may be considered as equivalent to nailing at this location.

Except as required by es008499, for single-layer application on walls, nails shall be spaced not more than 200 mm o.c. on vertical wall supports, or every 300 mm o.c. along vertical wall supports, in pairs about 50 mm apart.

For single-layer application on walls, where gypsum board provides required bracing in braced wall panels, lateral support for studs, or fire protection, nails shall be spaced not more than 200 mm o.c. on vertical wall supports, and top and bottom plates. (See ea001492 and ep001029.10)
The uppermost nails on vertical wall supports shall be not more than 200 mm below the ceiling.
Nails shall be located not less than 10 mm from the side or edge of the board.
Nails shall be driven so that the heads do not puncture the paper.
For single-layer application on a ceiling, screws shall be spaced not more than 300 mm o.c. on ceiling supports.
Where the ceiling sheets are supported by the wall sheets around the perimeter of the ceiling, this support may be considered as equivalent to screwing at this location.

Except as required by es008504, for single-layer application on walls, screws shall be spaced not more than 300 mm o.c. on vertical wall supports where the supports are more than 400 mm o.c., or not more than 400 mm o.c. on vertical wall supports where the supports are not more than 400 mm o.c.

Except as provided in es008505, for single-layer application on walls, where gypsum board provides required bracing in braced wall panels, lateral support for studs, or fire protection, screws shall be spaced not more than 300 mm o.c. on vertical wall supports, and top and bottom plates. (See ea001492 and ep001029.10)
Where a fire-resistance rating is determined based on et000261, es008504 need not apply for the purpose of fire protection.
Screws shall be located not less than 10 mm from the edge of the board.
Screws shall be driven so that the heads do not puncture the paper.
In cold weather, heat shall be provided to maintain a temperature not below 10°C for 48 h prior to taping and finishing and maintained for not less than 48 h thereafter.
Except as provided in Sentences es003403 and es003404, the minimum thickness of plywood interior finish shall conform to et000216
A manufacturing tolerance of −0.4 mm may be applied to the thicknesses listed in et000216
No minimum thickness is required where plywood is applied over continuous backing.
